past: all the hair metal bands

<question from>



Michael.

</question from>



<question>



Has anyone here actually listened to a Jonas Brothers song the whole way?



To be honest I have never listened to a Jonas Brothers song....and I don't ever intend to.



</question>



<additional details>



So I can't really say they suck...i'm not even sure what they sound like!



I only heard like a 5 second snippet of one of their songs on the commercial...that's it.

<question>



I can't 'belt out' songs?



Well at the moment, I'm trying to teach myself how to sing properly.
I'm doing well so far, I can sing in tune and with my diaphragm etc etc
But when I try and sing powerfully (like belting out songs etc) I can not do it.



I'm guessing there's just different muscles involved, and if I practice 'belting' out enough, I'll be able to do it eventually?



I can sing quite powerfully when I do it in an 'opera' voice actually, but I don't really want to use that singing style.



</question>

<answer>



Well I know you're wanting songs, but check out these bands.



Interpol, My Morning Jacket, Razorlight, Bloc Party, Band of Horses, Telepopmusik, Kings of Convience,The Cat Empire,  Royksopp, Eels, The Flaming Lips, Rogue Waves, of Montreal, The Whitlames, Mates of State, Iron and Wine, Stars, Citizen Cope, Copeland, The Frames, The Knife, Uh Huh Her, Rilo Kiley, Feist, Poe, Bernard Fanning, Blue King Brown, Sarah Blasko, Powderfinger, The Presets.



I also suggest checking out Pandora radio at www.pandora.com. You can type in any song or band that you love and they will make a personalized radio station for you. All you have to do is rate each song they throw your way so that they can be "in tune" to what you personally like. They do a great job at finding awesome unique bands/songs for just your taste! Its great. I don't know what I do with out Pandora at times.



Source(s):



www.pandora.com



</answer>

Twisted Sister - i dont really listen to them

okay, that last part didn't make sense,

<question>



Not just another "recommend me some Black Metal bands" question.?



This is a challenge.



I've asked for people to list some Black Metal bands that I havn't heard of before but all people seem to come up with is the obvious ones (Emperor, Mayhem, ect.), or they just post links to a ready-made list.



So here's how it's going to be.



You list as many Black Metal bands that you don't think I've heard of (and I've heard of quite a few), along with what they sound like (you can just compare them to other bands here for convenience's sake), one song that you think deserves a mention and the album it's on.



I'm not looking for obvious ones to get me started off here, I've been listening to metal for years and I want to see what you can come up with, so the more obscure, the better.



As you know, there's 10 points going for the best answer.



</question>



</answer from>

<question>



What is the title of this song? When was it released?



It's gettin' hot in here, so take off all your clothes



I am inside ohh I wanna take my clothes off...



what are some songs (hiphop/pop/rock) about the hot summer.



</question>



<answer from>

Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 451 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hot in Herre by Nelly



It was released in May 2002 I think.



Another summer song is summer time by New Kids on The Block



</answer>



<answer from>



Xaring
Member since: 05 November 2007
Total points: 250 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



"Hot in Herre" is a popular song and single performed by the hip-hop artist Nelly, and was released in May 14, 2002 as the first single on his album Nellyville. The song's producers were The Neptunes. It is best known for the lyrics, "It's gettin' hot in here / So take off all your clothes".



5)Sittin' Sidewayz - Paul Wall



4 | Lighters Up - Lil' Kim



3 | Go Crazy (Remix) - Young Jeezy ft. Jay-Z and Fat Joe



2 | Lose Control - Missy Elliot



1 | Ridin' - Chamillionaire ft. Krayzie Bone



Best Summer Rap Songs (2006)



5 | Bumping My Music - Ray Cash ft. Scarface | Watch Video



4 | Mighty "O" - OutKast | Listen



3 | Number 1 - Pharrell ft. Kanye West | Listen



2 | Kick Push - Lupe Fiasco | Listen



1 | Touch It(Remix) - Busta Rhymes ft. Mary J Blige, Lloyd Banks, Papoose, DMX, Rah Diggah



</answer>



<answer from>

Entertainment & Music

<question from>



jMan
Member since: 01 August 2007
Total points: 389 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What would you need to take to a weekend festival? E.g. Reading?



I want to know the small things like phones, lighter etc



</question>



<answer from>



Running Away Into You
Member since: 12 October 2008
Total points: 859 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok this is what i take to Leeds festival every year.



- 2 jeans ( in case it rains, i have one dry set for the night and wet for the day)



- 2 t shirts ( same reason,  you really dont want to be soaking wet at night since it gets really cold)



- Mobile phone (try not to take your best one on the off chance it goes missing) - they should have a Nokia tent there where you can charge your phone up for about £3 also they charge every phone not just Nokias



- Beer ( that's if you drink alcohol) - if you are bringing spirits i.e vodka, you have to pour it into plastic containers since glass bottles are prohibited



- Money (I normally take about £100 but i never spend it, also take as much as you think you will need but remember not to lose it.  Also everything there is a rip off, a burger costs about £7 and a can of coke costs about £2



- Food (i normally take them pasta things where you just rip open the packet and pour it into some hot water) - since you really dont want to have to slice, cut and prepare all your meals



- a small camping gas cooker (these are perfect and cheap)



- lighter ( always comes in handy



- flashlight (wow these things come in handy when you need a piss at night or you are stumbling back to your pit in the dark)



- sleeping bag & tent (obviously) - if your worried that your tent might get robbed,, ive been to festivals for about 12 years now and not once have i been robbed since theres alot of security



- wash kit & toilet roll - but i recommend you dont have a crap there since the toilets are just gross



thats the bare essentials you will need, just remember what you take is what you have to carry since at Leeds the car park to the camp sites is about 2 miles away, also DO NOT BRING A SUITCASE you are there for a weekend and everyone will laugh at you since you have to trek it across the grass you will look like a tit



another note, bring condoms if you wish but just remember these girls havent washed properly for a few days



</answer>



<answer from>



The Gallant Gael
Member since: 16 June 2008
Total points: 1719 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You already know what to take: Phones, Lighters etc!



</answer>



<answer from>



Paloma d
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 790 (Level 2)



</answer from>

OK&gt; you need dope...and a girl willing to do some quite adventurous sex things.In the open (or in a tent which is virtually the open). The dope will come in handy in convincing her about that...so pack plenty!!!



then you want a fair amount of booze, some clean underwear, headache tablets, a water bottle and lots of condoms.



Have a blast!!!



Source(s):

Oh I miss it!!!



Don't forget the lube...or the condoms will break and then...babies mean no more music festivals. and an STD means no more sex!!!



</answer>

Outside, Earthling, Hours, Heathen and Reality.

<question>



A question about song lyrics by M.I.A?



OK. The lyrics go "you can watch tv and watch the media president bush doing take over. Kate moss ETC. Great song, and I need the title. I love M.I.A I already searched her myspace and her website. And all the responses on yahoo say it's untitled but tht isn't helping any



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It's called MIA (nicknamed "Pop")



You can watch TV and watch the media
President Bush doing takeover
Kate Moss in ads for mascara
All my youth the young offender
The bill payers, the drug dealers
Girls who are magazine covers
The part-time jobbers at the call center
No career plans cause you won't go far
Put away change for Ibiza and
Check your credit on your new Nokia



You can be a follower but who's your leader?
Break the cycle or it will kill ya (X2)
You leader, you lead, uh, do what you do
What really good's gonna happen to you? (X2)



Your prime minister to your employer
Ego lovers need more power
Trendsetters make things better
Don't sell out to be product pushers
The gyro casher and baby makers
Try something new cause it ain't over
All poor people from all over
Lottery's got a rollover



You can be a follower but who's your leader?
Break the cycle or it will kill ya (X2)



Cherokee Indian, Iraqi and Indians
Girls and me girls when they come to the fellas and
Japanese, Moroccan, Caribbean, African
That's your life but who the ****'s your president?
You don't get my life cause I don't have a side and I
Spread dat boy 'im a mile wide and I
Got brown skin, I'm a west Londoner
Educated, but a refugee, still.
You wanna boy, you're old, you go
You wanna fight, you suck, you blow



</answer>

<original file>14015.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk103881.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Kirk H
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I just started playing guitar, is this normal?



I just started playing guitar and I'm having a lot of trouble with upstrokes (dragging the pick across the strings towards the ceiling). I don't know if this is a problem all beginners face or if it's just me. I also have trouble sometimes strumming chords that require certain strings not to be strummed. Some advice or tips would be very appreciated.



</question>



<answer from>



Kim B
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 126 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My friend is a great guitar player ...and he said he learned by simply taking time everyday and practice.  You will find the rhythm slowly but surely......



</answer>



<answer from>



polarbea...
Member since: 16 August 2006
Total points: 7568 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Keep your swinging arm parallel to the body top up and down. You can also keep your arm still and "flick" your wrist. Try a very soft pick.



When in doubt about chording, just play the highest tuned 4 strings.
Rock on!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr TEL
Member since: 06 July 2006
Total points: 2691 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, it's normal. So is putting your fingers on the wrong strings. Just keep the rhythm going with your right hand. These things will soon straighten themselves out.



</answer>

<question>



What are the meanings to the lyrics of the song "Sex Type Thing" by Stone Temple Pilots?  ?



And would it be a good song to sing to this cute girl I like?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Some people think it is about rape through the eyes of the rapist, blaming the victim for his actions.  Or it could just be about a guy who's eager to get into someone's pants.  Either way, I don't think it's a good song to sing to someone you like; it's a little aggressive.



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music

<question from>



ft28.fl1...
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 1103 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



In the song by Glen Campbell is the "Wichita Lineman" a euphemism?



</question>



<answer from>



mary g
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 236 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i don't think so - it's a place isnt it? what euphemism do you think it is ?



</answer>



<answer from>



P. W
Member since: 11 June 2008
Total points: 3949 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



For what?



</answer>



<answer from>



Capt Jack
Member since: 10 May 2006
Total points: 4060 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The bloke who wrote the song saw a bloke in the middle of nowhere, up a pole fixing the wires. He imagined how the man must be missing his wife.  There's not much more to it than that, but it is a beautiful song.



Pedants have picked up that he didn't do his research into the employment structures of linemen, but it is all a work of poetic fiction.



</answer>



<answer from>



carr7853
Member since: 21 August 2006
Total points: 743 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, it refers to guys working on the high tension electricity network (I think). That line about needing a vacation but it not looking like rain is a reference to when they get time off, i.e. when it's raining (?). Anyway what could it be a euphemism for? His drug habit? His d*ck?



</answer>

<category>

<question from>



marvin h
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 1 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is a good mpc to start of with for a beginner. ?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I hear good things about the 2000XL because its pretty much the go-to MPC with regards to having features...But not too many features to confuse you with.



The 1000 is good except i hear there is something bogus about the chopping..Like you can only chop a loop and lay it down in a specific order..



Sign up here and you can get even more information/e-books/forum threads about MPC's



MPC-forums.com



And if you get up to scratch with the MPC, Try www.mpc-samples.com for good disk packs for loops/samples etc .



</answer>

<original file>14941.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk104909.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



i luff you
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Does anyone know any good indie bands?



</question>



<answer from>



rennamix
Member since: 19 January 2007
Total points: 307 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There is so much in the indie genre!!! Here is just a few.



Indie Rock - Pixies, Radiohead, Artic Monkeys, Kings of Leon, Placebo, The Flaming Lips, Spoon, R.E.M., Wilco, Travis, Mew, Kings of Convience, The Mars Volta, Interpol, Modest Mouse, The Shins.



Indie Pop - Lykke Li, Peter Bjorn and John, MGMT, Mates of State, Ivy, Sondre Leche, Sparklehorse, Fiest, Architecture in Helsinki, Bloc Party, Jem.



Indie Electronica- Royksopp, Imogen Heap, Lali Puna, Asobi Seksu, Bjork, Ladytron, Goldfrapp, mum, Air, The Knife, Daft Punk, Thievery Corporation, The Prodigy, Moloko, Telepopmusik.



Alternative Indie - Radiohead, Weezer, Beck, Death Cab for Cutie, Sonic Youth, The Strokes, Incubus, Bat for Lashes, Tori Amos, The Decemberists, Pixies, Pavement, K's Choice, Mazzy Star, Aqualung.



Hope that helps!!!!!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you sooo much (:



</asker's comment>

I can still remember how that music used to
make me smile
And I knew that if I had my chance
I could make those people dance
And maybe they'd be happy for a while



Did you write the book of love
And do you have faith in God above
If the Bible tells you so
Now do you believe in Rock 'n' roll
And can music save your mortal soul
And can you teach me how to dance real slow



Well, I know that you're in love with him
'Cos I saw you dancin' in the gym
You both kicked off your shoes
Man, I dig those rhythm and blues



I was a lonely teenage broncin' buck
With a pink carnation and a pick-up truck
But I knew that I was out of luck
The day the music died
I started singing



Bye, bye, Miss American Pie
Drove my Chevy to the levee
But the levee was dry
And good old boys were drinkin' whiskey and rye
Singing this'll be the day that I die
This'll be the day that I die



I met a girl who sang the blues
And I asked her for some happy news
But she just smiled and turned away
When I went down to the sacred store
Where I'd heard the music years before
But the man there said the music wouldn't play



Well now, in the streets the children screamed
The lovers cried, and the poets dreamed
But not a word was spoken
Tho church bells all were broken
And the three men I admire the most
The Father, Son and the Holy Ghost
They caught the last train for the coast
The day the music died



We started singin'



Bye, bye, Miss American Pie
Drove my Chevy to the levee
But the levee was dry
And good old boys were drinkin' whiskey and rye
Singing this'll be the day that I die
This'll be the day that I die

Singing this'll be the day that I die

Satan's Sidekick

<answer>



They were good all the way from the beginning of their career through the album "Permanent Vacation".  After "Permanent Vacation" they became a wussy band that appealed mostly to 13 and 14 year old girls.  Songs such as "Crazy", "Crying", and "What It Takes" pushed the band over "wuss cliff".  The only album after Permanent Vacation that had any guts was "Honkin' On Bobo".  Their greatest work was the first album and "Toys In The Attic".



</answer>

<answer>



Depends what your into, but they do have a wide range of songs, they have 3 different era's (I guess) from thrash to just metal, to hard rock, try these:



Seek and Destroy - From their first album, thrash metal at it's finest, if your not too into the intro riff's your prolly not gonna dig them to much, hah.



Creeping Death - Just badass. :D From Ride the Lightning, the middle part with the backing vocals... awesome, especially live, not to mention good lyrics.



For Whom the Bell Tolls - Another awesome intro, sounds like a guitar, but it's a bass intro... look up Cliff Burton. One of their few/their only song from their "early days" which doesn't include a solo, but, really, another awesome song live, well, all three mentioned are.



Fade to Black - Their first "slow" more harmonic song, but it progresses, the lyrics and just in general the song were ground breaking at the time.



Master of Puppets - This goes without saying, overall their best, in many people's opinions, check the 2 solo's in the middle, the first a slower more harmonic one, then the drums kick in and it gets even faster, check the second solo especially.



Battery - Starts out with a clean crisp intro, and kick's into heavy drums, not including Damage Inc and maybe Metal Militia, it's prolly their heaviest song, but the best of the "heaviest." Imo.



One - Epic song, especially live, it's about how a landmine caused a dude to lose his limbs, speech, hearing, though, sight and etc, yet is still kept alive, fictional? Maybe, but the music video with the movie based on it... awesome, that's not even mentioning it's prolly one of the best progressive songs ever, imo, kicks into heavy stuff, awesome solo.



Enter Sandman - Most said they totally changed their style and sold out, they kinda did, but I don't know anyone who doesn't like this song, never mind can't stand it, you might have heard this, don't miss.



The Unforgiven - From their self titled album, the same as Enter Sandman, this is a unique song, a slower one, don't miss.



Nothing Else Matters - Not metal by any means, but, still... epic song, youtube Nothing Else Matters rock am 2008.



That was hard, i'd recommend listening to their 3 instrumentals... To Live is to Die (Cliff Burton tribute song, middle intro is... yeah) Orion and the Call of Ktulu.
Others; Harvester of Sorrow, Welcome Home (sanitarium), the Four Horsemen, Ride the Lightning, Blackened, Sad But True, Wherever I May Roam, The Memory Remains, Fuel, their cover of Turn the Page (check it, def).



Hope that helped, try listening to all 10 above, give them a chance, they are all so different. Actually, live versions of just Creeping Death (seattle 89', Rock am Ring 2008) youtube em, really show how they have evolved. Hope ya like, sorry for the overuse of badass, but back in the day.. they were!



</answer>



<answer from>



Riana ♥ GN'R
Member since: 08 June 2008
Total points: 2005 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



They're great! I'll give you some of my faves:
Nothing Else Matters
Enter Sandman
The Unforgiven
The Unforgiven II
Wherever I May Roam
The Day That Never Comes
Fuel
Seek And Destroy



</answer>



<answer from>



Yeah, She Wants the KP
Member since: 05 April 2008
Total points: 14079 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



As has been stated, htat depends entirely on ones personal taste.



I happen to love em.  Have listened to them since 1985, and don't regret a second of it.



Their first 4 albums (Kill Em All, Ride the Lightning, Master of Puppets and And Justice For All) are masterpieces of Thrash Metal, and Master of Puppets is one of the best Metal albums (well..IMO, THE best) ever composed).  Many of their songs during this era were long, but also were very complex, mixed with an amazing brutality. (but no tthe Brutal with ZERO melody that is so popular with todays Deathcore crowd)  Personally I think their weakest link in htese is their first, Kill Them All, because it was their most narrow and non-diverse album.  It is importnat more for what it represented (the birht of Thrash) than for its musical merits.



After these, you have the "Accessible" Years.  Hear Metallica played a softer blend of Metal with Alt and Southern Rock.  these were the Black Album, Load and Reload.  Some call them sellouts, some feel they lost their way, and some would say this is their best stuff.  THe songs were shorter, and they did generally simplify their style.  Decide for yourself.
Personally not my favorite stuff, but they Load and Rleoad were still overall good Alt Rock albums (though Re-Load is IMO, their weakest offering, period)



RIBIRTH:  Started with the critical failure of St Anger.  IMO actually a Better album than Re-Load, but also very disjointed, and not yet focused.  Actually really catches the turmoil  they had just gone through.  Followed up with Death MAgnetic, which I feel is their best album since And Justice for All.  A thoroughly Modern Metal album  that blends elements from ALL of Metallica's past albums..and yet still is it's own.



Now that we have looked at WHAT Metallica is..let me list some good tracks.



"Best" (now there is a Loaded term)
Orion
For Whom the Bell Tolls
One
Fade to Black
And Justice for All
Master of Puppets
Call of Ktulu  (S&M version)
Anaethsesia (pulling Teeth)
Sanitarium
The Thing That Should Not Be (S&M version)



Best OVERALL Metallica: (gives a feel for ALL their stuff)
Jump in the Fire (Kill Em All)
Fade to Black (Ride the Lightning)
Master of Puppets (Master of Puppets)
One (And Justice For All)
The God that Failed (Black)
King Nothing (Load)
Devils Dance (Reload)
No Leaf Clover (S&M)
Turn the PaGE (Garage Inc)
St Anger (St Anger)
Broken Beat and Scarred (Death Magnetic)



Most Accesible:
Fade to Black
Unforgiven
The Day that Never Comes
Unforgiven II
Until it Sleeps
Hero of the Day
One
Sanitarium
Wherever I May Roam
Fuel



Just my thoughts on it, as a LONG time metalhead, and Metallica fan.. Of course...some of what was amazing to me, might not stand out to you..because while when Metallica did it..they broke new ground..but in the decades since...otherrs have doen the same stuff..and you are more likely to have heard the bands that came AFTER before you heard Metallica...which will make it seem less impressive, potentially.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jessicat...
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 566 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<original file>17037.html</original file>

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



robbon92...
Member since: 20 June 2007
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Looking for a song that contains the words hams can't dance but they'll steal your money?



i believe it is from late 80's or early 90's



</question>



<answer from>



Seek
Member since: 22 June 2008
Total points: 407 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



lol wth



</answer>



<answer from>



milletto...
Member since: 02 October 2006
Total points: 5024 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The song was originally called "Zants Can't Dance", by John Fogerty (ex-Creedence Clearwater Revival).  He wrote the song about Fantasy Records chief Saul Zaentz (now deceased).  Fogerty hated Zaents because he owned the old Creedence songs, and Fogerty had vowed never to perform Creedence songs again.  Zaents sued Fogerty over the above song, and he was forced to change the title to "Vanz Can't Dance".  At the time, he said "I don't know what all the fuss is about.  I just wrote a song about a pig who can't dance..."



It appeared on Fogerty's "Centrefield" album.



</answer>

bladerhi...

<answer>



I'm assuming you only want singers and bands from the 80's.  Almost everything I've listed below is either a female solo singer or a band with a female lead singer (in almost all cases, the other band members are male, with the Go-Go's one of the few exceptions). Also, I've not listed New Order. They do have one female member, but she plays keyboards and never sings for them.  I hope this helps!



The Flying Lizards, Concret Blonde, Toni Basil, Berlin, Bananarama, The Waitresses, The Weathergirls, Anne Clark, Everything But The Girl, Eurythmics, The Go-Go's, The Cover Girls, Expose, Madonna, Gloria Estefan, Nina, Debbie Harry, Blondie, Bonnie Hayes, Haysi Fantayzee, Grace Jones, Cyndi Lauper, Valerie Poxleitner (Lights), Anabel Lamb, Hazel O'Connor, The Nuns, Matha and the Muffins, Romeo Void, Sparks, Missing Persons, Jane Siberry, The Other Two, Gitanne Demone, Christian Death, Rachel Sweet, Vicious Pink, Tom Tom Club, No Shuz, Stacy Q



</answer>

<question>



Question for Joy Division fans about Ceremony?



Is this live performance on May 2nd 1980 the only existing Joy Division performance of Ceremony? What happened to the rest of the lyrics...I read somewhere when they mixed it, it mixed out Ian Curtis's voice until the last part where he sings "I break them down".



I wanted to hear the whole thing in it's entirety. Would've been cool if he stayed alive to finish off the song and record it in the studio.

Jamie

Jamie ♥

<answer from>



Mama Jamie ♥
Member since: 18 June 2008

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



In the Still contemplation on the little booklet, it says " I just read a post on Neworderonline claiming that Tony Wilson trimmed off the start of Ceremony to make it seem even more like a bootleg..."



Pretty much I think that's the only version they actually have recorded. I wish they could have recorded a studio version of it because it's a great song.



EDIT: I found this version...But the one you posted and this one are the only ones I can find...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LaiOgToof...



EDIT 2: I'm always glad to help out a fellow Joy Division fan =)
I love answering questions relating to Joy Divison, so if you can think of more. BRING EM ONNNN!!!

<asker's comment>



Thanks for the link Jamie I really appreciate it.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



David Brent
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 272 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The sound engineer for the show that night messed up good & proper.He mixed Curtis's vocals far too low for the first half of the song.There is another demo version on the "Heart & Soul" box set which Peter Hook recovered, but not with much better vocal quality.There are bootleg recordings which crowd members made in which all the vocals can be heard. but the treble is terrible.
When Bernard Sumner did the vocals for the New Order version, he had to put Curtis's vocals through a graphic equalizer to figure out the lyrics.



</answer>



<answer from>



MEDS [DF]
Member since: 16 February 2008
Total points: 7275 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't like New Order very much to be honest, there are only two recordings of the song.



</answer>





















<original file>17731.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk108009.txt</current file name>




<category>

<question from>



Lilli
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Jack's mannequin general admission ticket=wherever we want?



I'm looking at buying concert tickets for jack's mannequin's concert in syracuse, NY in november. my friend already bought hers, and they are general admission but they said section D. when i search for tickets on ticket master they say general admission section G. are we going to be in separate sections or will we both be able to stand together in the middle? i want to make sure before i buy tickets.
Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



xstarstr...
Member since: 13 October 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



General admission means its a room with no seats so basically, first come first serve.



You'll be in the same area but might get separated by the crowd if anything.



</answer>



<answer from>



Andy
Member since: 20 December 2006
Total points: 500 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can go wherever you want. They list the sections on the tickets because that shows them the current sold capacity, as if there were seats.



</answer>



<answer from>



tnesti
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is tricky.  If I were you, I would contact the venue and ask specifically.  General Admission typically means you can stand where you like.  However, I have been to General Admission concerts where it's General Admission by section.  For example, I bought a Section 2 General Admission ticket.  So I couldn't be on the floor (Section 1), but I could be on the first tier of seating above there wherever I wanted.  So do be careful.  Like I said, contacting the venue and asking specifically could be the best way to go.



Source(s):



Experience with the same situation.



</answer>



<answer from>



MiNdLeSS
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 153 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



ya wherever you want and there isn't sections you just stand wherever



</answer>

dca

</answer from>



<answer>



It is always better to start with a classic guitar as it strengthens your fingers especially your finger tips but the best way to start is to learn the basic chords g c f a b and d you could always use stickers at first to mark them on your guitar and practise every day there are lots of beginners books out there which show finger placings as tabliture as quite hard ro read Good luck



</answer>

<answer>



The Wedding Song (There is Love) by Peter, Paul, and Mary, is one of the purist song about love.



Noel Paul Stookey claims he felt divinely inspired when he wrote this song.  Paul Stookey created a charity organization called The Public Domain Foundation to receive the royalties from "The Wedding Song (There Is Love)" and distribute them to charity. The organization's web site states that it has donated over $1.5 million.



Source(s):



http://www.tabcrawler.com/search.php?sho...



</answer>

<question from>



codmiver...

</question from>



<question>



I found that on a guitar website ( 20 bpm faster) what does it mean ?



</question>



<answer from>



Anakin
Member since: 23 March 2007
Total points: 229 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



20 beats per minute



</answer>



<answer from>



tjcmstab...
Member since: 19 August 2008
Total points: 760 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe bpm means beats per minute.



Source(s):



Took music lessons.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mother Russia [RIP дедушка]
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 7603 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



20 "Beats per Minute" or sometimes "beats per measure"



it depends



</answer>



<answer from>



River Euphrates
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 593 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



'bpm' means 'beats per minute'



It refers to the tempo or speed of the song.



'20 bpm faster' might refer to starting out playing a song slowly in order to learn it, and then increase speed by 20bpm increments until you can play it full speed.



There are programs and equipment for slowing down music without changing the pitch to allow you to learn parts that are difficult (if not impossible) to figure out full speed.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bob S
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 222 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer from>



HELLO! My Name is Hugh Jorgan...
Member since: 08 March 2008
Total points: 3084 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



My favorite is actually Sin After Sin. For some reason, it's always sat really well with me, and I love Simon Phillips' drumming. I love every song.



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sin_After_S...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I love Simon Phillip's drumming too.  My theory on SAS is Priest went more in the prog direction instead of punk.  Their albums after SAS were indellably influenced by Punk Rock.  Stained Class is really their first consistent "metal" album.  I love Sin After Sin.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Watson
Member since: 02 May 2008
Total points: 1704 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. Defenders of the Faith
2. Sin After Sin
3. Sad Wings of Destiny
4. Painkiller
5. TIE between British Steel and Rocka Rolla



Glad to see I'm not the only one who likes their oldest albums. In my opinion, Nostradamus was their weakest, most boring album. Halford is just getting too old, the songs were too monotonous and seemed to stretch on forever, etc. And that's coming from a guy who calls Judas Priest his 2nd favorite band.



</answer>

<question from>



V.
Member since: 24 June 2007
Total points: 4 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can I teach myself to screamo for my band? seriously...?



I am a singer in a band and can not scream for anything. I want to be able to incorporate more screaming into my music to make it more emotional. Any suggestions....



</question>



<answer from>



Escapeth...
Member since: 01 November 2008
Total points: 157 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



well my band does it and im am the screamo guy



u need to idnetify waht type of scream u wnt, liike underoath screamo, or like alesna scream



then u would probaly need to say a few words shouting, then sort of incorparte the sound you want



you also need to be able to control your breathing because, i remeber when we started doing that i collapsed becuase i ran out of breath, but are a singer and you shouldve already learnt that.



Also, dnt try to hard to sound good, just let it flow and keep practicing



dwnload some songs, that have differnt types of sreamo sound, get the lyrics and try do it.



hope you find that helpfulll



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks it is good to know it is all about the breathing. thanks again.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



GuitarRo...
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 165 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just DO It...



Take some songs, play em, and just work around with them, scream along with them and test your voice.
That's the thing, everyone has a unique voice, so play around with it..



whisper and clench your throat like you are gargling, and keep a little spit/water in your mouth.
Typically screamers have a water bottle with them on stage and stuff.



</answer>



<answer from>



bnobez
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 125 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you have no idea at all, search youtube for screamo voice lessons. Learn to control your diaphragm and scream from it. Control your breathing--take in lots of air. Like I said, youtube is a great place to get some lessons.



Source(s):



youtube.com



</answer>



<answer from>



b
Member since: 19 September 2006
Total points: 1475 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



maybe take some breath control lessons?



</answer>

<question>



Joy Division.  Which is better: Unknown Pleasures or Closer?



I'll wait to see what you say before I give my opinion.



</question>



<answer from>



Mama Jamie ♥
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 2357 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I used to think Closer was better, but I fell in love with Insight and Candidate all over again, plus I love Disorder, She's Lost Control, and Shadowplay, so now I say Unknown Pleasures.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Unknown pleasures ("UP") is slightly better than Closer.  I love the intentional minimalism of Closer, and no experimental rock album does minimalism better (in my opinion).  But UP is unique, brilliant, tragic and beautiful at the same time.  True art.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Writer, Paperbag Writer.
Member since: 08 March 2006
Total points: 8048 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



I prefer Unknown Pleasures. I simply find it to be a more enjoyable, engaging listen. Though Closer is a bit more 'cohesive' overall, the individual songs aren't as strong.



</answer>



<answer from>



David Brent
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 272 (Level 2)

<original file>19886.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk110402.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



bostonon...
Member since: 01 March 2008
Total points: 859 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What are the Top 3 Comeback Albums?



It has happened to some of the best bands, they're at the top of the world, then crash back and go out of whack with their music. Then they become reinspired by going back to their roots, or in some cases, reinventing themselves.



You could call this a comeback. But what are the 3 biggest comeback albums ever?



My Answer:



Album (Artist)



Brave New World (Iron Maiden)-This is the same band that put out The Number of the Beast, Powerslave, Killers, etc. After Bruce left in 93, they brought in Blaze Bayley. Needless to say, the band was going to an all time low. They lost Bruce, they lost Adrian Smith, and going to rock bottom.



2000 came, so did Bruce, so did Adrian, and a three guitar system. They came out with their now trademark theatrical musical approach that I was all for when it came out. At over an hour, it's Maiden going back to what they were doing before, being on top of the heavy metal world.



Back in Black (AC/DC)-How do you recover after you lose your lead singer? Do you call it quits, do you start a side project? NO. You go out and get a new singer and churn out one of the heavyiest records of all time (Hard to believe come from a classic rock band). This is a record to party to, get drunk to, and to have 40 minutes of great sex. What more can you want?



Painkiller (Judas Priest)-The Priest of the late 80s was such an embarassment to the Metal Gods. They came out with Turbo in 1986, synthesizers and in the process losing their core sound. Then Ram it Down came out in 1988, uninspired and made me wanna Ram it Down the toilet when I got it as a X-Mas gift (the remastered version). It is Painkiller in which Priest realized they were a heavy metal band, not a commerical one.



Without a doubt, it is a statement when they came out with this album. It is 50 minutes of thrash, fast guitar work, and fist-pumping anthems. Rob Halford absolutely outdid himself on his vocal performance, from the title track to the closer "One Shot at Glory," it is one of the 15 albums I can listen to back and forth, without skipping, shuffling, or getting bored. All Hail the Metal Gods.



</question>



<answer from>



LittleLo...
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 227 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Death Magnetic - Metallica
Black Ice - AC/DC



and i would agree with brave new world - I adore that album!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jimmy Jazz
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 14693 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



Military



</answer from>



<answer>



The Doors:



I think LA Woman was pretty awesome after a couple so-so albums (Morrison Hotel, The Soft Parade).



Motorhead:



Orgasmatron.  After Fast Eddie Clarke left the band they got Brian Robertson from Thin Lizzy and did Another Perfect Day which is really weird considering the awesome run of albums they had just put out (Overkill, Bomber, Ace Of Spades, Iron Fist).  It was like, what the hell is this?  But then Orgasmatron came out, and they're back baaybe!!!



</answer>

thanks song by himself or withthe hot boys

<answer>

The first single with The Hot Boys was called 'We On Fire', released in 1997.

Entertainment & Music

<question from>



yooo
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 206 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Electric Guitar whammy bar, help?



I'm gonna be picking up a right handed guitar with a whammy bar on it, but i'm left handed, or at least I prefer to play left handed.



Is there anyway I can use the whammy bar whilst playing left handed? Can I not just move the bar around? Doubt it, but, do I need to buy a left handed bar, if so, is fitting that easy?



There's a similar question been answered, I was wondering if anyone can go more in depth? I'll be buying a Schecter Damien FR guitar, if that matters.



Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



the wrath of alien
Member since: 04 April 2007
Total points: 24083 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Jimi Hendrix flipped his axe, to where the whammy bar was on top instead of bottom of the tremolo/bridge



it'll be different, but it will work



</answer>



<answer from>



dmbdotn
Member since: 05 April 2008
Total points: 373 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's possible Hendrix played with one and was able to pull it off when he used his. Try one in the store see if it gets in your way of strumming etc. see if its comfortable. Even then it may just be something you have to get used to. Also don't know much about the Damien by I own a Schecter S/H body, I love it. They are great guitars, very well built and great price. Duncan designed pickups are lacking though... upgrade.



</answer>

<answer>



Okay hun, so hears the deal.
I'm in musical theatre and the first thing they tell you to do is to SING LOUD. cause if no one can hear you, they don't know what's going on. So that's tip number one.



Number two : Your voice is good for an ammature i guss, but you need singing lessons, so they can show you how to use your voice in the proper ways. But you're not too bad.



It also depends on like how old you are and your vocal chords, older girls and boys tend to have stronger voices, so i think it also comes with alot of practice.



But over i think the first one is the best because your voice is stronger and there's a little more emotion.



But overall, you're good, but singing lessons will do you NO wrong!



♥ Hope it helps hun :)

<question>



What genre is Missing by Evanescence?



can it be classified as rock or gothic rock when it has no metal?



a mellow drum loop, acoustic guitar, string section, vibraphone, vocals



please include a definition for the genre chosen and why it matches



</question>



<answer from>



Faradin
Member since: 29 April 2007
Total points: 353 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It would have to be confined to gothic rock just because of the band itself--it's a mellow song, but it definitely doesn't stray too far from Evanescence's style, so it can't be considered anything unique.



</answer>



<answer from>



joshnodo...
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>

evanescence's missing is in fact alternative!
wiki said so

<question from>



Ski Cap. [The Anti-Genius]
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 3058 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Rap and Hip-Hop



</question from>



<question>



RHH: Is HH as accomodating/open minded as some of its fans make out?



Basically, One of the answers i ever gave in this section was on "why i love hip hop?" And i said that hip hop embraces other genres in the context of THE MUSIC. I was thinking about how true that is outside of the music.



Strangely Enough, I was talking to a friend of mine who's only into classical/avant garde kinda music and she basically said, Hip Hop promotes racial discrimination and serious cases of superiority complexes amongst its fans. She went a little deeper/louder but i'll give you the gist.



Thoughts?



</question>



<answer from>



bonniethon (orain luaidh)
Member since: 26 September 2007
Total points: 14477 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rap and Hip-Hop



</answer from>



<answer>



As a white girl from Scotland whose favourite rapper is Chuck D, I do think hip hop is open minded.



How does hip hop promote racial discrimination? I've never experienced that. Hip hop talks on issues of race, yes, and I think to a non-HH fan who doesn't listen properly, it may seem discriminatory, but it really isn't on closer inspection.



I'm not just blindly supporting hip hop by saying that - most of my favourite hip hop is the stuff that gets accused of racism, so it's not like I'm not aware of what's said, but you have to listen to it in context and understand WHY it's being said - and why it needs to be said.



As for the superiority complex. Hmm. Confidence and bragging are a part of hip hop, always have been. That's like saying boxing promotes the same.



Hip hop is such a hugely varied genre that for every guy talking about his chain, there's another one talking about how much he hates that stuff. So Hip Hop doesn't really "promote" anything and isn't responsible for what individual rappers choose to talk about.



In short, I disagree with your friend.



Source(s):



http://102room.blogspot.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



insane ppl love this avatar
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 3137 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



IT CATERS TO MY BLACK RACE



</answer>



<answer from>



latj
Member since: 10 November 2007
Total points: 44287 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Rap and Hip-Hop



Etiquette



</answer from>



<answer>



Hip hop is an entire culture...to varied and too wide to be "racist" or promote "racial discrimination.  You've got extremists and then you've got "peace keepers".  You've got NWA and you've got Pharcyde, De La Soul & Common.  The scale tips both ways and evens itself out.  Saying that everyone fits into one basket or stereotype is wrong.  The person you were talking to clearly is talking about "gangsta" rap, not all types of rap.



There are so many sub-generes of rap that this clearly is an untrue statement.
Peace & Love :)



</answer>



<answer from>



C@P'N CHRON!C
Member since: 10 November 2007
Total points: 762 (Level 2)



</answer from>

</answer>

<answer>



since listening to hip hop, i've become a more acceptable person, regarding ethnicity and religion (especially those of the muslim faith), I think hip hop unifies those residents of the world willing to contribute. One of my favorite compilation albums is the Unbound Project, which is dedicated to Mumia Abu Jamal, a black individual, but even though it's dedicated to him, I can relate, I've seen not only my people being opressed but i've seen this world's residents die for "freedom", die for "money", die for "religion" and die for each other all to be remembered by God during resurrection. And that is what hip hop has taught me. We're all in this together



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



Mrs. Sag Ninja*Black President
Member since: 09 November 2006
Total points: 10457 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rap and Hip-Hop



</answer from>



<answer>



The most prominent figures in hip hop are minorities who use the medium as a means of discussing the things that they feel, think and experience.  It just so happens that for many minorities, the issues we face are racial or societal.  Using your platform to discuss thoughts or opinions you have doesn't mean that you are promoting them, you are simply venting.  It is always amazing to me that Hip Hop takes so many punches, when there are Rock songs that talk about rape, murder, prostitution, devil worshipping, etc. and some of these songs have been out for decades, yet we constantly have to justify our genre.



</answer>

<question from>



Nick K
Member since: 20 January 2008
Total points: 4838 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Why is the official Ohio Rock n Roll song about Prostitution?



If you don't know the song, it is "Hang on Sloopy"



Yes, "Hang on Sloopy", is about protistution.



the question is,



s it r e e a l y about prostitution?



The song lyrics seem to paint that picture



"sloopy lives in a very bad part of town" could mean that she may not be all that good either and maybe had a rough life



"I don't care what your daddy do" the word daddy could easily be interpreted as a pimp



"Sloopy wears a red dress" is a key line to associate the song with prostitution.  In many cultures the color red is used to identify prostitutes, sometimes refering them to "lady in a red dress"
of the Netherlands "Red Light district.  In the 17trh century prostitues normally wore red shoes.



Could this song that many people dance to and sign along at parties be about prostitution?



</question>



<additional details>



I have a rock and roll music and criticism class



Its AWESOME!!!!
teahcer kinda looks like Lewis Black, the comedian



and makes us laugh a lot.



I have the class, and  am thinkign about doing my big presentation about this.



</additional details>



<answer from>



padraig
Member since: 21 April 2006
Total points: 3015 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Despite your(?) hypothesis, there is no reason to believe the song is about prostitution. Based on the information I have come across, the name "Sloopy" most likely came from Dorothy Sloop, who was a Jazz singer from Steubenville, Ohio. She performed in the New Orleans area using the name "Sloopy."



Source(s):



I'm from Ohio and so were the McCoys. :)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



many songs can be interpreted many ways.
But you have to have evidence  to support it.



Both of us make valid claims.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



mad embalmer from the north II
Member since: 26 September 2007
Total points: 2528 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why not, the bubblegum tune Yummy Yummy is about oral sex



No, really, it is about oral sex...Yummy Yummy Yummy I got love in my tummy.....I read an interview of the person who wrote the song and he was amazed it received mainstream play. He said it was about that.



</answer>

<original file>21665.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk112380.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Tenn.Bre...
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 717 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Who are the most influential bands of today, and why?



</question>



<additional details>



luv sucks :) I understand where you are coming from with your kids and all but I know you think there is more meaningful music than that but Im still gonna give ya a thumbs up for effort



</additional details>



<answer from>



luvsucks
Member since: 20 September 2007
Total points: 241 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i'm going for hannah montanna and jonas brothers. MY KIDS REALLY LOOK UP TO THEM....



</answer>



<answer from>



I love the good old U.S.A.!!!
Member since: 15 August 2007
Total points: 1367 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well that's a hard choice to make because there are plenty of bands out there that are very influential. There are many genres that have influence on a certain genre which makes the genres become more popular.
In my opinion I would have to say KoRn.
Korn came into the public ears back in 1994 when they released their first album self titled "KoRn". During this time hard rock or Metal was near its down fall and was slowly fading away.During that era of music Kurt Cobain killed himself which devastated the word of grunge and hard rock. His death left no future for Nirvana and Hard Rock was dying. Metallica stopped making good music after the Black album and decided to cut their hair and claimed themselves that Metal was officially dead. When all hoped seemed lost, Korn came in to the music world with the new genre of "Nu Metal". The new genre became very popular and influenced bands such as Slipknot,which is also a very influential band of today. Korn became a multi platinum band and changed the music industry for ever in a ways people could not imagine. To make things short. In the end if it wasn't for Korn, Metal and Hard rock would not be as big as it is today. There are many bands that were influenced by Korn. Korn may not be important to other genres but they are important to the genre of Metal.



Source(s):



My own knowledge.



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



Are these good quality guitars?



They look exactly like Gibsons but they're cheaper. Is that because of the quality or name brand? (p.s. I'm using it to play bands like Paramore, The Academy Is..., Fall Out Boy, Good Charlotte, Brand New, etc.)



http://cgi.ebay.ca/GrassRoots-SG-SERIES-...



http://cgi.ebay.ca/GrassRoots-Les-Paul-S...



</question>



<answer from>



Psyopus
Member since: 22 June 2008
Total points: 3652 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's really had to tell when there are no sound samples to play.... I suggest going to a guitar or instrument shop and test them out there because while somebody else may like how they sound, you might hate it.



My friend has a similar les paul and it sounds decent, but like I said before test them out yourself...



</answer>



<answer from>



dmbdotn
Member since: 05 April 2008
Total points: 389 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wll I will say chances are it's not going to sound like a Gibson. The craftsmenship will not be at the same level. However you don't have to buy the most expensive guitars out there to get a great sound, or the sound that YOU want. Try one out if you can and look for samples like someone else said. But, most of all definately if you can try it yourself. You'll know if it sounds right, feels right, etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



paragong
Member since: 22 June 2006
Total points: 1783 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



they seem ok but until you play them you don't really know if they are any good



</answer>



<answer from>



John S
Member since: 29 January 2007
Total points: 382 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i've never heard of this brand. i know you can get quality guitars for much cheaper prices. if you're a gibson guy, go with epiphone



</answer>



<answer from>



Another Internet Hero
Member since: 09 September 2006
Total points: 16382 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've come across that brand before, "Grassroots". You won't find it in an America/Canadian store I'm afraid. It is an exclusively Japanese company, that's why you probably won't recognize the name. They don't sell them in shops outside there so...



Being Japanese I expect the quality to be really good but to be sure, I'd try looking for some review sites first but I don't think you'd have anything to worry about regarding the company. And the fact that they are cheaper than Gibson is no surprise because Gibson really is full of themselves. Sorry to say, good as they are they should not cost that much (Gibsons I mean). If you want a Gibson but don't have the cash, go for Epiphone (basically the cheaper version, but owned by the Gibson company).



</answer>

<question from>



xyz
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 892 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Question about my left thumb behind the fretboard when playing guitar?



Whenever I run down scales or just pick individual notes, my left thumb is directly behind the fretboard and is straight. But whenever I play a chord (not including barre chords), my thumb completely wraps around. Is this a normal style of playing?



</question>



<answer from>



GuitarRo...
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 199 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



As it has already been said, it is all about comfortability. I always for some reason thought it was like a bad habit, and not very professional, but hell I do the same thing all the time. I actually prefer the thumb wrapped around, cause it doesn't put so much pressure on your thumb's knuckle, haha.



But whatever is good for you dude!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



,



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



A Kind Of Magic [hates Obama]
Member since: 28 May 2007
Total points: 3182 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



Doesn't matter if it is normal, as long as you are comfortable.



As far as your thumb wrapping around, that is common.  Some guitarists use their thumb to fret the low E string.



</answer>



<answer from>



Don S
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 1604 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go for what you know.



</answer>



<answer from>



FFAFØ (Pro Metalcore)
Member since: 15 April 2008
Total points: 10689 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



whatever is comfy for you is the best way dude



</answer>

<answer from>



crimsonk...
Member since: 18 December 2006
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



honestly It can mean a few things.
1. smoking weed obviously. Or high on some other kind of drug.
2. I think its about a female who gets a 'high' from money(paper) and she tends to bounce from relationship to relationship(fly like planes)
Hence the whole, " All I want to do is (Bang bang, cocking noise, CaChing!) and take your money!" To me this is about a female who uses and abuses people for money.



3. it really means whatever you want it to!



Hope I helped.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chloe P
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



"I fly like paper, get high like planes"



are the lyrics. It's M.I.A. -Paper Planes



meaning your cool if your "fly.



high like planes meaning "getting high"..



However I think the song has some underlying cultural tones seeing that MIA is originally from Sri Lanka.



I think its just regarding the way people or children live in third world countries. They do whatever to make a living, selling visas... i also think "bang bang bang bang" and "kaaa ching".. basically is having sex (bang), and getting money for it. "kaa ching" prostitution



</answer>

<question>



Whos better klashnekoff or lil wayne? decide?



klashnekoff who is from london in the uk has only sold around a hundred thousand or maybe less in his career. but has delivery flow and lyrics on his side which he always spits over uncompromising and clever beats.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n0CKHGgxr...
i could never say lil wayne is the best rapper alive because his name and those words just dont go together in a sentance.despite this he has sold 1.4 million in a week.he tends to spit over candy *** beats which if you break down are extremely simple. his simple lyrics and simple metaphors and similies are easy to decifer and his word play is at best average.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SePRNJtJQ...
i have made this commparison to show what hip hop still just about  is 'klashnekoff' and what it is becoming 'lil wayne'. and for the record im not saying in any way that klashnekoff is an amazing rapper hes good, im trying to make the point he clearly has more abilty but record sales are not backing this up
record sales doesn't mean quality
i was also going to compare immortal technique to little wayne instead
but it really doesnt matter who i line him up against unless its souldga boy



</question>



<additional details>



yeah the parragraphs long



wanted to make a point and also  to make a solid argument to back up my point of view.

<question from>



The Schecterizer
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 215 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Help Writing Song Lyrics?



I want to write song lyrics, and I have some topics, the thing is I can't find a way of writing them. My genre is rock, heavy metal etc. I like Avenged Sevenfold and Slipknot lyrics, and I admire the way they can write lyrics with alot of subliminal meaning in it, and the language being amazing without being flowery.



Any tips on how to write lyrics?



</question>



<answer from>



Shyy Babii«
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 499 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



From the heart =]]



</answer>



<answer from>



TehUber1
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 154 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A way of writing song lyrics is too write your life in a song and over exaggerate emotions, this has been done many times. Over all you can rhyme lyrics like this.



Another way to write lyrics is too look around you and start with a particular topic which you can focus on which can give you help.



Hope it helps and good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



UNEEK
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Any little thing that pops into your head, write it down.



It just might eventually be the key to A song. Most of the time, a whole song isn't going to pop into your head. However if you use the little pieces and put them together the best way you feel fit. You'll do fine.



Source(s):



I write my own lyrics also



</answer>

...To answer your question:



Obama winning has not eradicated racism in America...  there will always be racism in America but Obama’s victory is proof that race relations have begun to improve. America is finally begun to reconcile its differences with people of color and live up to its creed. Obama alone cannot save the world, He's not God, he's not the Messiah.. That is not his job. His job is to Govern our nation.



To people who say Obama's Victory will not change the Dynamics in Hip Hop You're wrong...  people have forgotten that Hip Hop is deeply rooted in social perception and that perception is indeed reflected in Hip Hop... Yesterday People of color and an entire generation were granted a new reality thus Hip hop was granted a new reality because Art  imitates life....

<question>



Which band should I try first: Dillinger Escape Plan, Protest The Hero, BTBAM, or Human Abstract?



Also, what are their best albums?



</question>



<additional details>



@ Adam

@ DB



WELL THEN DON'T %$#@!&^ ANSWER!!!

<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Dillinger - Miss Machine and Irony is a Dead Scene feat Mike Patton and Ire Works



BTBAM - Colors (prog) and Alaska (metalcore with prog. influences). If you want a more Deathcore sound, listen to The Silent Circus



PTH- Kezia and Fortress are about the same. If you want a more Hardcore Punk sound check out "A Calculated use of Sound"



</answer>

<question from>



Charles B
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 91 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



On what album does the Beach Boys' "Feel Flows" originally appear?



Just curious.



</question>



<answer from>



emmy b
Member since: 07 September 2007
Total points: 588 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Surf's Up i think



</answer>



<answer from>



mel
Member since: 30 March 2007
Total points: 64962 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



"Feel Flows" is a song written by Carl Wilson and Jack Rieley for the American pop band The Beach Boys. It was released on their 1971 album Surf's Up.



Carl Wilson's lead vocals were recorded using reverse echo.



Source(s):



wikki poob



</answer>

<answer>



If we change the word "Jams" to "tenants," I believe we end up with the same result either way:



"Kick out the tenants," or
"Kick the tenants out."



It would appear that the Jams end up homeless no matter what.



Be a darling and let them rent some space in a jar in your fridge or cupboard, or on the airwaves in your home. But do be diligent about collecting the rent--the Jams are tricky and will try to get out of paying what they owe.



</answer>

<answer>



Yeah burn it first - they will probably give you another copy anyway but just in case :-) also, for future reference - you can expect broken covers with starting out bands that are on tour (like if u buy their cd for $5 or $10) so dont take it back then cuz chances are most of them are like that (i should know - its my job to go and sell the stuff for them) but if you buy it from a store you should expect better quality than that.

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



SolOfChs...
Member since: 11 June 2008
Total points: 360 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How many pedal does a guitarist really need?



well so far i have a JH-1 wah pedal and a BBE green screamer
so 2 so far...
how much more pedals do i need
and please dont suggest any multi fx pedals cuz they sound like crap thanks
also im running through a marshall 100dfx and a Fender hotrod deluxe



</question>



<answer from>



hairhorn
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 1702 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



as many as it takes



</answer>



<answer from>



Calskii
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 547 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i go from my fender 50's reissue strat into a digitech xp-100 whammy wah, use the wah settings on the pedal then straight into my fender front man 100 watt. I use the distortion from the amp. Ive always used this setup at gigs and shows, and its never failed me.



I own a boss dd-3 delay pedal and a eh small clone pedal, but never use them live.



It all depends on what soudn you need, if your playing metal then you need good disotrtion, psychedelic rock then you need vibrato/phaser etc.



A good guitarist can make his sound interesting without effects, and running your guitar through heaps of pedals will dampen the overall tone and is a pain to control on stage!



</answer>



<answer from>



Bloc Partier
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



(H) realistically like 7, but if you're like me, you want to own them all (Y).



also depends on the genre you play



</answer>

The Man
Member since: 06 September 2008

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



have u ever felt like a burden
to everybody u know
tryin ur best but still learnin
just how to go with the flow



have u ever felt ur unwanted
it's like nobody cares
about u/ just wantin
for this world to be fair



Chorus:



I want to be wanted
i want to be loved
i want to lighten the burden
enough is enough



I want to be wanted
I want to be loved
i want to lighten the burden
am I asking too much?
End chorus



sorry i'm such a burden
maybe i should just leave
all the bridges i'm burnin
are just too much for me



i want you to know
i wish it wasn't this way
I dont want to go
but goodbye is all i can say



Chorus:
I want to be wanted
I want to be loved
I want to lighten the burden
It has become too much



I want to be wanted
I want you to know
we're best friends forever
but it's time for me to go



</answer>

Glockwor...

<answer>



I don't know. I don't really get underground music, because it's hard to find out about it.

<question from>



Xx.Toin....
Member since: 27 September 2008

</question from>



<question>



Rock and Roll Time Line? where can i get one?



Music assignment `needs to be handed up tomorrow.  I can't get the answers for my knowledge question and time line is the main thing missing along with the main rockstars and fashion sense. your help would be great. and help me soooooooooo much!!

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Ren
Member since: 11 February 2008
Total points: 289 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Do Women have Falsettos?



it's been bugging me for a while now. My professional chior director says there's singing with your diaphargm and singing with your throat for girls but we do not have a falsetto. the notes just get too high for us.



Now, my school choir director agrees with this guy who claims he can't read music and seems a little bit too full of his decent singing which is often overpraised that women can have a falsetto.



so which is it?
Need 2 Know! Thanks



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



falsetto is a vocal register, so yes, women can have it too. it's almost like a head voice, what sets them apart is that while a properly trained head voice is clear and firm, falsetto is airy, and, like the name says, sounds 'fake'.



by the way, DON'T EVER SING WITH YOUR THROAT! there isn't such thing. chest, middle and head voices are not about using either diaphragm or throat but where the sound is ressonating. for example, if you hold your hand to you chest while you sing in chest voice, you'll feel a slight vibration!



</answer>

<original file>3447.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk116588.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Kevin
Member since: 12 August 2008
Total points: 65 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What should I look for when purchasing a Microphone?  (Music Production)?



Hello,



I am looking into buying a decent microphone for laying vocals over my tracks. I currently use "Reason" to produce my tracks and use Adobe Audition 3.0 to multitrack. My system consists of a Windows OS with a X-Fi Xtreme Gamer Sound Card.



I am aware that under most circumstances I will need a Pre-Amp, Spit-Gaurd and of course a Microphone. I know some microphones are crazy expensive but I'd like to keep my budget around $2000 for everything.



Do you guys have any suggestions and why? I really do not know much about microphones so please feel free to enlighten me. Thanks for you're time and info!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Most studios use a condenser microphone for vocals and acoustic instruments. Condenser microphones are rarely used for vocals on stage because (a good one) can pick up a pen drop across the room. They are also fairly delicate. If you drop one it's not uncommon for it be damaged perminately.



Cardioid (aka Dynamic) microphones such as the Sennheiser e835 or Sure SM58 work better on the road and  on a stage. You can toss these around and not have to worry at all. The good ones (such as the models mentioned) do an excellent job at picking up what's right in front of them, but they lack the warmth and clarity of a good condenser microphone.



Condenser microphones require a pre-amp that supports phantom power and a spit-guard/pop filter, Cardiod microphones do not.



My favorite budget end condensers are those made by Audio-Technica. I have their AT2020 ($100.00) and AT4050 ($540.00) and both of these microphone do an amazing job on vocals and acoustic guitar for the price.



I have a SURE SM58 that I use for live vocals and if I plug it into my setup (M-Audio interface into PC) and lay vocal tracks even the AT2020 blows it away.The AT4050 has aged-gold components, dual-diaphragm and other features that I couldn't exactly tell you what they do, but the sound is  a bit clearer. I like using the AT4050 for vocals and the AT2020 for my guitar, but I've switched them around before and the difference is very nominal considering the price gap. If you're working on building a pro-studio I'd recommend the AT4050 because it has really high-end condenser features at a very good price (some competitors want $1000+ for the same features), if you're just building a home studio, the AT2020 or AT4040 will do just fine.



One other thing, if you're going to record a style of music where the vocalist has to scream a lot (rock, metal) you may consider sticking with the good dynamic mic like the Sure SM58. A lot of vocalist in these genres still perfer a dynamic microphone in the studio because it's more tolerant to their style (screams will force your peaks into the red pretty quick with a condenser, you can try getting the vocalist to back up a bit, but sometimes it's just best to use a dynamic mic).



Also in situations where the whole band is performing togeather in an open area the vocalist has to use a dynamic microphone. A lot of bands still record this way, U2's last album How To Dismantle an Atomic Bomb was recorded this way and Bono used a SM58 on most of the studio tracks.



</answer>
