<current file name>yqa_uk117125.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



METALLICA FAN (Joshua W. D.)
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 760 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Starting a band, need to sing LIKE.....!!!!!??



JAMES HETFIELD!, I'm taking lessons to get my voice cracks under control, but I need to sound like James did on kill em' all, and the lightning to the nations album by diamond head. ANY suggestions?



I'm getting a band together, I have a guitar and I will be the lead singer and rhythm guitarist.So any helpful tips would be nice :) thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Jdeats
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 284 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If you talked to a style coach they would tell you to work out breaks/cracks, pitch problems, support/breath control, etc.. first. In other words they would say come and see me when you get done with the vocal coach.



But assuming you have all that under control. The first thing is your voice type has to match up. James is a Baritone, he hits a few sweet high notes, but he also hits his share of low notes. If you're voice sits naturally in the higher register (Tenor) then you could trash your voice trying to sing like him. If you have that out of the way then the thing to do is to just take a few of his songs, break them down into 30 second intervals and try to mimic everything he's doing. Every moan, growl, scream, etc... Record your! Listen to the playback, then listen to james. Make notes of what you hear differently then try to correct those things. If you're hearing James do things with his voice you're not able to do, then you need to identify why that is. Is he going outside your range? Is he holding a note longer than you can comfortably? If you're having those sort of issues, you need to work on techniques with your voice coach to correct support and to try and extend range (sounds like you're already doing this trying to work out your cracks).



Metallica has enough live material on CD that you need not go to the studio recording for comparison. Quality live recordings are always better to work with as studio takes can consist of many vocal takes cut & pasted togeather... A quality live recording provides a good reference for what the singer can really do when you strip away all the studio toys and give him basic EQ, compression, etc...



Sorry, I know this isn't a great answer, hopefully I've given some perspective.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



that was, I have a 83 style James voice, just wondering how to capture his sound.



Thanks!



</asker's comment>

<question>



I can't 'belt out' songs?



Well at the moment, I'm trying to teach myself how to sing properly.
I'm doing well so far, I can sing in tune and with my diaphragm etc etc
But when I try and sing powerfully (like belting out songs etc) I can not do it.



I'm guessing there's just different muscles involved, and if I practice 'belting' out enough, I'll be able to do it eventually?



I can sing quite powerfully when I do it in an 'opera' voice actually, but I don't really want to use that singing style.



</question>



<answer from>



psycho man
Member since: 09 February 2006
Total points: 1612 (Level 3)



</answer from>

<answer from>



fieldhoc...
Member since: 01 August 2008
Total points: 75 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



try using your diaphragm more and try different styles until you find yours that fits to your voice.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rick M
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 1038 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you sing with a pointed tone, you can belt out any song.
a pointed tone is when you have 50% of air coming from you mouth and 50% from your nostril. it's not singing through your nose either.
this is called the pointed tone method. I taught it for years. it gives you a good solid tone and gives you the effect of singing with authority.
too much air from the mouth and you sound mushy. too much from the nostril and you sound sharp. it takes a lot of work. but it does work
also try running the scales several times a day.



</answer>

<original file>4510.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk117770.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Keane
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What makes a truly great cover version and why?



Yahoo! Staff Note:  This is the real Keane.



For further details about how you can see them live in concert check out http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



</question>



<answer from>



jfh29er
Member since: 27 May 2006
Total points: 594 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There has to be a combination of a great choice of song (NOT necessarily a great song), a great artist and the song should be covered in a way that makes the new version a good recording in its own right.  It's pointless covering a song if you're bringing nothing new to the table.



A great cover version is very rarely better than the original, and neither should they often be considered to be, but it may compare and enjoyment of the original should not be hindered by the existance of a cover.



Deciding how to cover a song and making a good job of it should follow similar principles to writing and recording an original song.  The effort levels often compare and often need to for the cover to be a success.



To sum up, for a cover to be great the artist must be great, the choice of song must be great and the cover should be created and not carried out.



A carbon copy will never a great cover make.



Greatest cover ever?  Well it's a pointless argument because everyone knows that if Nirvana had actually CREATED a fully-mixed and mastered studio-recorded version of My Sharona nothing else would've come close.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Really liked your answer Jay29erboy.  Thanks for answering and hope to you enjoy the gig this Thursday!  Richard.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



A great cover version is a song which was previously very easy going and melodic that has had a bit of heavy oompf added to it.

A heavy base line can make all the differnce to a tune.

Dean L

JOEL S

<answer>



For anyone who says that "a cover is never better than the original" is WAY off base!



*Sarah McLachlan's version of XTC's 'DEAR GOD' was amazing...even Andy Partridge has said it was the way the should have been done!*



*Sinead O'Connor's cover of Prince's 'NOTHING COMPARE 2 U' was superior to his version because she let the emotions take the song, not the over production of the music.*



*Check out Whiskeytown's take on 'A SONG FOR YOU' by Gram Parsons.  Raw in it's simplistic beauty.*



Covering some songs are needless and pointless...but if any cover song turns you on the the music of the original artist, then that can never be a bad thing.



</answer>



<answer from>



djleecla...
Member since: 19 October 2006
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A truly great cover version may change the mood, the theme, the perception of the original meaning, or may even cross-over musical boundaries. However, a truly great cover version may also serve as a timely reminder of how tastes change (sometimes old songs only become classics in later generations when covered). Either way creating a truly great cover version has to be about seeing it from a new point of view, and with inspiration.



By the way, I thought you guys were great at V this year - it made my weekend!



</answer>

jonnymc

<answer>



a good cover happens when the cover artist sings a clear interpretation of the original with their own sound. a great cover happens when the cover artist takes the song and makes it their own tastefully and musically. it's hard to make a good cover out of a bad song though, so i think it's all about which song and what the final product makes the audience feel.

<answer>



Honestly, I don't like covers. They usually piss me off.



However, If you really want to do one avoid doing anything by the Beatles. No one can top the Beatles.



Also, doing a really loud, fast-paced song in a slow, accustic way would be good. Like a Nirvana song or something (not that I don't like Nirvana, I just think their songs sound great accustic)



Someone said that doing a song that's unexpected is good, and that's true. For example when Johnny Cash did "Personal Jesus" or Bowling for Soup did "Baby One More Time" or Sly and the Family Stone's version of "Que Sera, Sera". That's always kinda cool.



Or maybe if you do a song that everyone's forgotten about, like Nirvana did a version of Leadbelly's "Where Did You Sleep Last Night?" (originally from the '30's) on that MTV Unplugged CD-thingy.



Anyway, if you're going to do a cover, don't make it a single, only make original songs singles.



Well, that's my opinion. :)



</answer>

<answer>



A good cover is one that understands the emotion or thought behind the original, and finds another way to express it.



If you listen to Murray Head's "Say It Ain't So Joe" and then Roger Daltrey's version, the mood's totally different and Roger's not really understood the song.



But listen to Johnny Cash singing "Hurt", and he tackles the song from a completely different angle than NIN did, yet it works, almost better than the original.



Some favourites:
Cheap Trick: "Ain't That a Shame"
Bryan Ferry: "These Foolish Things"
Cowboy Junkies: "Sweet Jane"
Hooters: "Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds"
Icicle Works: "Needle & the Damage Done"
Icehouse: "Love Like Blood"
Manic Street Preachers: "Rock n Roll Music"
Shawn Colvin: "Tenderness on the Block"
Stevie Ray Vaughan: "Superstition"

<answer>



Good question, first of all it has to be a great song to start with, (worth covering), secondly the band have to put a new twist on the song (no point recording exactly the same sound again) and lastly, there has to be sufficient time between the two different artists recording it.



The best example of a cover version that covers the points above is Stevie Wonder's version of "We can work it out" by the Beatles. The harmonica is amazing !!!



Phil



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr Blues
Member since: 05 October 2006
Total points: 1306 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sometimes cover versions are done for all the wrong reasons, it seems some artists just cant be bothered to come up with an original song, so in order to keep in the public eye they just do a cover version.
In my opinion the best cover versions are those songs that the artists really admire and truly want to improve on.
Also some songs are just too well done to be covered and any attempt to do so is almost an insult to some of the great artists.



</answer>



<answer from>



christine s
Member since: 20 October 2006
Total points: 121 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Can you put your original stamp on the song without having to betray the integrity of the original? (Jerry Lee Lewis' new cd has some good examples) Is there any good/appropriate/timely reason to sing the song in the first place? (ex: War, what is it good for?)



I have heard some great covers  - check out some of Springsteen & the E Street Band in their earliest shows, or consider a very, very young, upcoming band Comic Book Heroes - they do a cover of Purple People Eaters - geared for young (teen) listeners- yet with an original stamp on it to make it their own.  They make that song worth listening to -- and isn't that the heart of the matter?



In the end, it has to be the combination of a very talented singer paired with an honest, original arrangement of the song.



In other words, don't sing Roy Orbison's 'Crying' if you are not KD Lang.  And, please, do not ever listen to that songbook by Rod Stewart - it is the antithesis to good song covering.



Finally, if you are covering another artist's stuff, you better be bringing your best game -- if you are a guitar band, let's hear it; if you have the pipes, show off with an acoustic version; if you are known for a certain style, put your stamp on it (See: Pearl Jam's cover of 'Leaving Here')



</answer>



<answer from>



cjmurdoc...
Member since: 19 October 2006
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

Katie Hallz

<answer>



In my opinion, a great cover version has to have the same, if not better, spirit in the song. Someone took time to write and sing that song, so show the same emotions and respect to the song, after all the song will sell you as a band, and if you have the same drive as the person who wrote it in the first place surely it will sell. You must also add a few spicy ingredients giving it a bit more edge and style than the original.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sarah .
Member since: 18 July 2006
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Think of something that appeals to everyone emotionally... something that everybody can relate to. Like maybe something or someone who inspires you, or something you're obsessed with.



Now variety. Switching speeds is one way to go. Half of the reason why people get sick of a song is because it's the same speed... over and over again. Changing speeds throughout the song will have people sitting on the edge of their seat, anticipating what will come next. Also, you could try changing beats and tones. I suggest combining all three approaches.



And finally, be original. As corny as it sounds, don't sing something unless you really mean it. People can see, and hear, if you don't agree with what you're singing/saying. If you are making it you're own, I swear to bob, it makes it so much better.



Good luck!



Source(s):



I've been singing since I was 7, and I've been a loyal choir junkie since the second grade. I also have been in a lot of vocal lessons.



</answer>

<question from>



Jaty

</question from>



<question>



From which website I can Download Free MP3 Songs?



</question>



<answer from>



submissi...
Member since: 27 January 2008
Total points: 162 (Level 1)

<question from>

<question>



What is a peoples favourite  by Scott McKenzie ?



Do you like this one ?



"If You're Going to San Francisco" by Scott McKenzie



http://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=EmyaDrAzq6...



Thank You.



</question>



<answer from>



Thunderh...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 311 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Butch UK
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 2521 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes very much , it reminds me of my youth, and a particular girl , oohhh what a summer, thanks.and  good night.



</answer>



<answer from>



xanna d
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 1900 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Scott McKenzie was a one-hit wonder, and the San Francisco song was his big moment.  FYI, Scott was in a folk group (The Journeymen) with John Phillips, later of the Mamas and Papas.  Originally named Phil Blondheim, Scott changed his name, taking the middle name of John's daughter Laura McKenzie Phillips (later famous for her role on One Day at a Time - and her drug problems).



Source(s):



http://www.scottmckenzie.info/story.html



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr Nice Guy
Member since: 12 March 2007
Total points: 2930 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



i've been wondering why you have asked such questions all evening, and give us the actual name of probably the only song that the artist is known for. Are you bored or what, and your questions are mostly aimed at a certain age group, and defo not anyone born in the last 20 years!

Lyrics to Walk Away :
Vocalizing: Ooh, Ooh, Ooh, Ooh, Ooh.



I guess I should've known better,
to believe I'm a lucky chain, Oh.
I lent my heart out forever,
and finally learned each other's names.



I tell myself, "this time it's different."
No goodbyes, cause eyes can't bear to say it.
"I'll never survive on one that's coming",
If I stay, Ooh!



Just Walk Away! Ooh, and don't look back.
Cause if my heart breaks, It's gonna hurt so bad.
You know I'm strong, but I can't take that.
Before It's too late. Oh, just Walk Away!
(Walk, Walk, Walk Away) Ooh, just Walk Away!
(Walk, Walk, Walk) Away-aye-aye, yeah.



I really wish I could blame you, but I know
That it's no one's fault. No, No. No, No
Cinderella with no shoe, and
the prince that doesn't know he's lost.
He says that her face is so familiar, and
Goodbye with just the same old song.
But this time I will not surrender!
'Cause I'm gone, Ooh, yeah!



Just Walk Away! Ooh, and don't look back.
Cause if my heart breaks, It's gonna hurt so bad.
You know I'm strong, but I can't take that.
Before It's too late. Oh, just Walk Away!
(Walk, Walk, Walk Away) Ooh, just Walk Away!
(Walk, Walk, Walk) Away-aye-aye, yeah.



Ooh, I've got to let it go.
Start protecting my heart and soul.
Cause I don't think I'll survive a goodbye again.
Not again!



Just Walk Away! Ooh, and don't look back.
Cause if my heart breaks, It's gonna hurt so bad.
You know I'm strong, but I can't take that.
Before It's too late. (Before It's Too Late!)
Oh, just Walk Away!
(Walk, Walk, Walk Away) Walk Away, Walk Away, yeah!
(Walk, Walk, Walk Away!) Walk Away, Walk Away, All right!
(Walk Away, Walk Away, Yeah, Walk Away!) Walk Away, Walk Away.
(Oh, Walk, Walk, Walk Away!) Walk Away, Walk Away, Ooh..

<answer>



"Safety Dance" by Men Without Hats.  I couldn't change the station fast enough when that was a hit in the 80s, but now that I don't have to hide from it 400 times a day, I actually like it.



Another example is "I'll Be Good to You" by the Brothers Johnson.  I hated that song when it was a hit, but I heard it the other day on the 70s station and found myself singing along.

<answer from>



Daft
Member since: 07 February 2008
Total points: 6802 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Good q!



I usually skipped "Phantom" when I would listen to Justice's Cross album...But then I went back and realized it was the best song.



With In Rainbows from Radiohead - I always started listening to the album by the second track, "Bodysnatchers".  But then I finally listened to "15 Steps" on shuffle one day, and that was it for me.  I gave it all my attention for weeks.  "15 Steps" is just amazing, the beats are incredibly captivating, and the song is at its best when the song gets all its instruments in.



Same for Spoon's Ga Ga Ga Ga Ga.  I always flew past "Don't Make Me A Target."  Never thought I'd like it.



The one time I regretted this overlooking thing the most, was with A Ghost Is Born from Wilco.  I didn't like the album at all the first time I listened to it, and when I did like it, I never liked "Hell Is Chrome" or any of the first four songs.  It took me the longest time imaginable to like "Hell Is Chrome".  But now it is definitely a favorite.



Another one is "Place To Be" from Nick Drake.  Never liked the dang Pink Moon album.  But then I gave his so-called "popular" songs a listen, and still didn't like it.  After a several tries I gave up, only to try again, and find that I liked only one song from the whole album - which is "Place To Be".



And I've always missed out on "Jet" by Paul McCartney.  For the longest time I hated that song so much.  Now I have no reason to.



Sorry for having such a long answer!



</answer>

<original file>7156.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk120709.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Chris
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 779 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



The Golden Era Of Hip Hop Questions?



Do you think hip hop will ever be like "The Golden Era" again?



If you think it will then what will it take for hip hop to get back to "The Golden Era"?



Also do you think hip hop has a future?



</question>



<answer from>



shelivad...
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 165 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Rap/Hip Hop is formed from uttering rhymes over repetitive beats making it impossible for it to evolve and advance forward, the only reason it was so well received during the 1980's was because those artists were original.



</answer>



<answer from>



mako
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 358 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think the hip hop underground is going strong. There's a lot of insanely good rap out there, but the general public made rap sooooooooo shitty. Everything on the radio, at clubs, etc just sucks. I think hip hop has potential. It's relatively new, so there are lots of possibilities for the future. I mean if rock is still alive for as long as its been, rap will make it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mace Windu
Member since: 11 August 2006
Total points: 2887 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



While anything is possible, I doubt it.
Back in the late 80s, there still was a balance of small labels and big labels putting out rap music, helping to result in a variety of rap styles, including bohemian, pop, rock-rap, gangsta, Afrocentric, jazzy, romantic, great DJ and MC pairings, etc., etc. There was a style for almost any taste. The rap was coming from a real place. While rap was gaining more mainstream popularity at the time, again the small/independent labels was keeping it grounded, and mainstream labels had yet to take over the industry through mega-mergers.



Sure, hip-hop does have a future, but it comes through the underground, not through the mega-labels that control the stores, the radio and TV.



The Internet is largely a wasted resource because today's youth are more concerned with instant gratification and ringtones, not substance. Everything (that includes rock) seems to be about having an instant, catchy hit.



</answer>

<answer from>



Eirin
Member since: 22 July 2006
Total points: 420 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Could it be "give the girl" instead of "give the world"?



I found two possibilities: New York Dolls - Great Big Kiss ('92) and Bruce Springsteen - Give the Girl a Kiss (released late 90s). NYD doesn't sound at all like the Black Crowes though, and the Springsteen song wasn't that well-known.



http://www.springsteenlyrics.com/lyrics/...
http://www.stlyrics.com/songs/n/newyorkd...



I don't know if either one is right, but I couldn't find anything that matched the lyrics you gave. Any other info?



</answer>

<question>



Not just another "recommend me some Black Metal bands" question.?



This is a challenge.



I've asked for people to list some Black Metal bands that I havn't heard of before but all people seem to come up with is the obvious ones (Emperor, Mayhem, ect.), or they just post links to a ready-made list.



So here's how it's going to be.



You list as many Black Metal bands that you don't think I've heard of (and I've heard of quite a few), along with what they sound like (you can just compare them to other bands here for convenience's sake), one song that you think deserves a mention and the album it's on.



I'm not looking for obvious ones to get me started off here, I've been listening to metal for years and I want to see what you can come up with, so the more obscure, the better.



As you know, there's 10 points going for the best answer.



</question>











<original file>8887.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk122631.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music

</category>



<question from>



mattitud...
Member since: 16 May 2008
Total points: 71 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Has angus young always been a schoolboy?



in the jail break film clip when ac/dc is singing on the rocks why is angus young (lead gitar) not in the schoolboy outfit?



</question>



<answer from>



Rod Mc Rod
Member since: 06 July 2008
Total points: 2267 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



When the band started in the early 70s, he actually was still at school, and came to gigs without changing. He couldn't drink at the bars AC/DC played in because he was underage.



He doesn't strictly adhere to the uniform code in all clips and performances, but the cap is usually there.



</answer>



<answer from>



suumagoo
Member since: 27 November 2006
Total points: 1026 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes he has....the original schoolboy was Bon Scott, but he passed away...(i am about 85% sure of, so dont quote me....Im getting ld and I was so stoned back in those days anything could be true!!! ) tee-hee



</answer>



<answer from>



AC/DC FREAK
Member since: 12 June 2007
Total points: 5735 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



i think the idea was still being considered as a permanent signature
the album was from 1975- only 2 years since they made their debut

<question>



Can anyone send me the lyrics of " AS LONG AS YOU LOVE ME " from Backstreet boys..?



plz. don't send any link.
Send the song copied from the link.
I do not have access to music links.



</question>



<answer from>



Zarinthe...
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Although loneliness has always been a friend of mine
I'm leaving my life in your hands
People say I'm crazy and that I am blind
Risking it all in a glance
And how you got me blind is still a mystery
I can't get you out of my head
Don't care what is written in your history
As long as you're here with me



Chorus:
I don't care who you are
Where you're from
What you did
As long as you love me
Who you are
Where you're from
Don't care what you did
As long as you love me



Every little thing that you have said and done
Feels like it's deep within me
Doesn't really matter if you're on the run
It seems like we're meant to be



Chorus



Bridge:
I've tried to hide it so that no one knows
But I guess it shows
When you look into my eyes
What you did and where you are comin' from
I don't care, as long as you love me, baby.



Chorus



Who you are
Where you're from
Don't care what you did
As long as you love me
(Repeat to fade)



Source(s):



http://www.lyrics007.com/Backstreet%20Bo...

I'm leaving my life in your hands



People say I'm crazy and that I am blind



Risking it all in a glance



And how you got me blind is still a mystery



I can't get you out of my head

Where you're from



Don't care what you did

Feels like it's deep within me



Doesn't really matter if you're on the run



It seems like we're meant to be

I've tried to hide it so that no one knows



But I guess it shows



When you look into my eyes



What you did and where you are comin' from



I don't care, as long as you love me, baby.



Chorus



Who you are



Where you're from



Don't care what you did



As long as you love me

Risking it all in a glance

I can't get you out of my head
Don't care what is written in your history
As long as you're here with me

Where you're from
What you did
As long as you love me

Where you're from
Don't care what you did
As long as you love me



Every little thing that you have said and done
Feels like it's deep within me
Doesn't really matter if you're on the run
It seems like we're meant to be

But I guess it shows
When you look into my eyes

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Summertime
By George Gershwin



"Summertime,
And the livin' is easy
Fish are jumpin'
And the cotton is high



Your daddy's rich
And your mamma's good lookin'
So hush little baby
Don't you cry



One of these mornings
You're going to rise up singing
Then you'll spread your wings
And you'll take to the sky



But till that morning
There's a'nothing can harm you
With daddy and mamma standing by



Summertime,
And the livin' is easy
Fish are jumpin'
And the cotton is high



Your daddy's rich
And your mamma's good lookin'
So hush little baby
Don't you cry"



Loads of people have sung it including Ella Fitzgerald.

<category>



Entertainment & Music

</category>



<question from>



Emma Bunton
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is it about your favourite song that makes it so special to you?



Watch my Yahoo! Answers question live on video here: http://uk.video.yahoo.com/video/play?vid...



For more information on the Spice Girls http://uk.launch.yahoo.com/spice-girls/



</question>



<answer from>



peterf19...
Member since: 14 July 2006
Total points: 343 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The music and lyrics combined, can sometimes reach right in to your heart and really pull you, and make you feel that the song was written specifically for you, even though the song was written about something the writer was feeling at the time. Thats the mark of a good songwriter, they will have some kind of empathy with the audience. It doesn't have to be a well known well loved song. It's easy to answer this question by stating a well known song, as some have, but that doesn't really explain the why.



One that does it for me is 'Is it any wonder' by the Chamelons, who you probably won't have heard of, yet the song might have been written about a situation I faced some yeard ago. Beautiful song.



Source(s):



Me.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Wonderful answer, many thanks.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



what makes a tune special to me is if it carries you away in your mind.



It can be thread bare and rambunctious like Missy Elliot's White Horse or have beautifully crafted and delicate production like Madonna's Ray of Light.



Mind you some hardcore acid techno kinda tickles the neurons too ;)



</answer>

<answer>



For me it is the feel of the song, and how it comes across. My favourite song is a 1971 live version of Stagnation by the band Genesis. This has much clearer lyrics than the original studio version on Trespass (1970), and is more atmospheric.



Also, In My Own Dream by The Butterfield Blues Band. Maybe that sums things up. But another favourite is I Used To Be A King by Graham Nash.



But another firm favourite is A Fantasia on Christmas Carols, by Ralph Vaughan Williams.



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Just me
Member since: 04 March 2008
Total points: 393 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Why is 'in the air tonight' by Phil Collins rock music?



For my music assignment



</question>



<answer from>



Megafunk
Member since: 01 November 2006
Total points: 4744 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It doesn't turn to rock until towards the end when the drums kick in and then it could be described as rock for the rest of the song after that. I dunno what genre you could put on that song. "Romantic-Rock" perhaps?? lol



</answer>



<answer from>



shelivad...
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 190 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The sound of rock often revolves around the electric guitar or acoustic guitar, and it uses a strong back beat laid down by a rhythm section of electric bass guitar, drums, and keyboard instruments.



"In the Air Tonight" by Phil Collins is classifiable as Soft Rock and also a  Ballad because it has a slower tempo.



</answer>



<answer from>



Fonzie T
Member since: 20 May 2006
Total points: 42447 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



I have a tough time calling that song rock. It's a pop song in my book. Yeah, it kicks up near the end, but I've heard plenty of louder pop songs.



I'd love to talk to the person who gave you the assignment.



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



Han
Member since: 30 June 2008
Total points: 907 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sure you can - you just have to be very very good at it.



You can play for an orchestra, or do session music and earn money that way.  Consider having a back up plan, or something you can fall back on, as saxophonist work might not always be that steady.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



Here are some I found.  See the source links for some of the lyrics, information, etc.

"Carrot Juice is Murder" by The Arrogant Worms

"In This World (Murder)" by Good Charlotte

"Meat is Murder" by The Smiths

"Be Healthy" by Dead Prez

The "Veggie Boards" link below has some other ideas as well, and would be an excellent source for further information.

All of these are about being vegetarian, but note that the Arrogant Worms one is a joking attack of vegetarianism.

EDIT: THERE IS one more I should mention.  It's not really about being vegetarian, but about the revenge of the animals.  It's called "Cows With Guns" and can be found here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FQMbXvn2R...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KmK0bZl4I...

<question>



Binaural music?



Do you have beta and gamma musics?

Do you know websites?

<answer from>



The Rugby Player
Member since: 24 April 2007
Total points: 61431 (Level 7)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



I am not sure if the following sites are of interest.



December 2006
Binaural Beats Delta Brain Waves. Brain Injury Years Later. Brain Based Classroom. ... Musics Effect Onthe Brain. Signs Symptoms Of A Brain Tumor. Fighting ...
br7in.com/archive-200612.html - 524k - Cached
Audio frequency 2 -- 5 Hz - SciForums.com
There are 3 major regions in human brainwave spectrum - Alpha, Beta, and Gamma. ... Binaural beats and other brainwave gear has been around awhile. ...
www.sciforums.com/Audio-frequency-2-5-...
static.scribd.com/docs/dhaovrglgysos.t...
... 2006 rg /cd (roland mc505, audacity beta) 3 + text by robert grassi || text go ... live 12 + text about hemisync || binaural beat technology || cd cover / live 13 ...

<question from>



hafwen
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 2404 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



The future of live classical music performance...what are your thoughts?



The availability of DVDs and other "home entertainment" devices have effectively sent the old "drive-in" cinemas into oblivion...the internet is pushing secondhand bookshops/antique shops towards extinction...

What about live classical music performance? With the dizzying rate at which technology keeps evolving, what do you think the future holds here? Will people ultimately prefer to stay home with their DVDs, home-cinemas and YouTube for their "virtual" classical music experiences? What effect would decreasing concert attendances have on the world of live classical performance?

And of course, on top of this, there's the worsening oil crisis...this will surely affect the mobility of both performers and concert-goers...

Will live concerts eventually become a thing of the past? Or will there be some kind of technological meltdown, and we'll ultimately be forced to abandon our hi-tech existences and seek our musical pleasures elsewhere?

I'm curious to hear your thoughts here...



Hafwen



</question>



<answer from>



Paulllll C
Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 839 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think live music will ever fade out.

I love Daft Punk and watched hundreds of live footage of their concert before I eventually went to see them last year and nothing could compare to actually being there.



</answer>



<answer from>



snide762...
Member since: 12 November 2006
Total points: 4754 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You know, the same issues were raised about 100 years ago with the advent of recording. Who would see a live performance when they could listen in the comfort of their own home?

Of course, no such thing happened. Similarly, attendance at sporting events remains strong, even though most games can be watched on television.

Ours is, after all, a "live" art form. To truly experience great music, one needs to experience it live. Recordings are great, obviously, but with "acoustic" (unamplified) music, you just can't beat the "live" experience. There is something visceral about hearing a trained singer, a brilliant pianist, or a fine symphony orchestra live and in person.

I think the future is bright!



</answer>



<answer from>



Can music save your mortal soul?
Member since: 11 November 2006
Total points: 5090 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think being @ home on youtube can beat a true concert experience.
For me it is the excitement and suspense (and nerves if you are performing) that make live concerts awesome.
When I go to a concert I immerse myself in all the sounds, I don't think you can truly do that at home.
But some theater systems come pretty darn close. lol
I don't think live concerts will ever become a thing of the past, I think there will always be people who appreciate real music, who are eager to perform and eager to attend.



</answer>



<answer from>



mamianka

Performing Arts

<answer>



Wherever we go on vacation, my husband seeks two things - good concerts and museums, and live baseball.  I recently saw "live" a famous painting that I had known for years from many high-quality prints.  I was stunned at what I had been missing - at that is only 2 dimensions!  We attend MANY live concerts, and make a great deal of live music ourselves.  Now, I hate baseball.  I go with him - because I do.  We could sit home and see EVERYTHING up close, on our big TV, sitting in AC comfort on a leather couch, drinking a Scotch.  Instead, we sit in teeny seats in the broiling sun, with the players the size of Barbie dolls, and always somebody spills beer on us.  You just can't get that at home . . .  Nothing beats the live experience, even if you do not AGREE with, or enjoy the live experience.  People will seek live performance, not only because of the performance ITSELF, but because of our inherently gregarious nature.  Sometimes I listen to a Tanglewood performance, or a Met performance, and then drive there a day or so later to hear it live.  It's NEVER the same -that is why it is ART.



</answer>

<answer from>



i. jones
Member since: 06 January 2008
Total points: 8625 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Classical



</answer from>



<answer>



I think there will always be a place for live performances of music. Nothing else comes close. I was skeptical when Fantom Events broadcast (narrowcast) live performances from the Met to movie theaters nationwide last summer.



I was pleasantly surprised that those concerts, at least out here, were capacity crowds ... and that the one-time events actually went into repeat performances. Okay, it's not live music but it was 100% affirmation that there is a public that wants to see live music, opera, symphony concerts. (I don't think those would fly so well.)



If its a relief: when I shop for music CDs I want to handle them, I want to hold the package in my hand, read the jacket, listen to cuts on listening stations. I don't do that on the internet ... I go to the store.

My wife does the same with books ... and she reads a lot of them.



Instruments: same thing, I go to the store I handle them, decide if what is available is better than what I have and work a deal (always seems to be in their favor) to take my old gear in trade.



Sheet music, on the other hand, I get by one of three means.



1. Download from the Internet. Both purchased and free public domain just because stores just don't sell sheet music any more.



2. Transcribe by ear ... time consuming, but often the only means available to get out of print titles.



3. Get it from the morgue ... friends with filing cabinets of unused, ready to discard music. Latest acquisition was from Canada.

---
Getting on your movie kick ... that I see being a problem for two very sound reasons. Ticket and concession prices and the crack cleaning crews they have at the theater. I don't want to spend $50 for a family of three to see a film and sit in the lap of sticky popcorn encrusted luxury. (Oops, last weekend we saw two films)

... but I didn't like it. :-)



</answer>



<answer from>



Ian E
Member since: 06 July 2008
Total points: 2900 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Classical



</answer from>



<answer>



The days of Music, Art Music, as an evolving and contemporary Art form, where recent, genuinely 'new' compositions are performed before a vast audience comprising all strata of society, who are eager for these 'new' sounds; these halycon days are long gone.



Today, perforners tend to 'specialise' in Music that is becoming older and older with every passing day.



Don't blame them, though.



They need to eat as much as Insurance Salespersons do!

Two hundred years ago, music composed much over 20 years previously was heard, but was mostly heard as a curiosity.



Today's situation cannot auger well for the continuity of live performance.



Unlike other cultures, the West has a prescription for all of its Arts that demands continuous evolutionary [and even occasionally revolutionary] change!



Today, live performance is merely a 'museum' format.



There are, sadly, no signs that this is about to change.



It means that, as a relevant aspect of our society, Music that is being composed and performed today in a style notably different to that of the past, a style responding to today's situation; this Western style of creative music has 'virtually disappeared'.

If a significant group in our society says, e.g., "I prefer the 18th (or 17th, or 19th, or, damn it, 20th!) century to the 21st." when referring to Music, this is evidence that I am correct.



Many. many people, people who are passionate about music (!), will say this, if asked!



How I wish that I was wrong!

I realise that your question is slightly different.



You ask if the situation as we find it today will continue.



I claim that, because the sitruation today is as it is, the seeds of its demise are already present, and are growing!



Because concert goers only admit 'new' music that is reminiscent of  older styles of music, the future is, I'm afraid, exactly as I say.



(I speak only of the European strata of music, a strata that thrives on continuous change, continuous evolution!)



Your points (fuel prices, youtube, DVD's, CD's, new technologies, etc.) are all most valid, and, added to the very nature of what concert goers regard as 'Classical"  Music (the very word 'classical' is very significant, surely?), the situation seems to spell the effective death, in 'Western' terms, of all but Commercial Music.

If there is little or no demand for 'evolution' of style, the very nature of European creative music has been, perhaps accidentally, thwarted.



(The search for easy money [ - U.S.A., Japan, etc. -] will be blamed, but I am not sure that this is the complete story.)



In this altered form, I cannot envisage it surviving.



Already, many people regard those who passionately adore 'classical' music as "Old Fogeys".



(It says something peculiarly spectacular about the people saying this, of course!)



The truth is, however, that Music Lovers don't support 'new' music.



Even the progressive genius of last century is largely unappreciated!



It is only quirky, oddball types that have even heard of Stravinsky, or Webern, or Bartok, e.g., let alone are familiar with their (now quite old) music.

Apart from the Church (it rarely requires anything but 'extinct' styles of music), cinema (hardly a major supporter of genuinely contemporary music), and an occasional federal government subsidy for composers, there is no way for composers of today, with an interest in music of today(!), to earn a living.

Unless a composer of today is content to write symphonic music for (the 19th Century's)  orchestra,  revert to diatonic harmony, etc., etc., who is there willing to listen to the composers' music?



So-called  'music lovers' are not likely to change their reactionary attitude to music of today, surely?

We are left with 'museum' music.  Old music, or music written now, but in a style acceptable to the type of person that claims to love European creative music.



A sad situation, a situation for which it is hard to point a finger of blame.

Something like this, but less extreme, exists for the visual arts, I guess. .



Our 'classical' audiences now are aging, their tastes are notably reactionary, (i.e., more extreme than merely 'conservative'!), and their demands upon performers are increasingly onerous (due to the spread of technologies, as you have outlined!), and these performers are rapidly following composers toward extinction.

Who is to blame?



Nobody, probably.

What a gloomy creature I have become.



How I wish someone could point out that I am wrong!



(Vent your anger by supplying lots of thumbs down, perhaps?)



</answer>

<answer>



I'm not as pessimistic as some of your responders.  All performers need audiences; money provides nutrition for our bodies, but sustenance for the soul needs affirmation.



Julliard and Curtis are still with us; and harder than ever to gain admittance to.  One avid classical music buff, rather opera-lover in particular, tells me that the Met. performances are usually sold out.



If one watches or listens to "From the Top", which provides an opportunity for outstanding young musicians to be heard in front of a live audience, one is assured that there are many fine young performers, readily and willing to take up the mantle of the reigning big name instrumentalist and vocalist when they retire.



The hedonistic fungi of "pop" culture, has not infected everyone in our modern, western culture; there are still a sizable portion of the populace whose minds are not yet utterly controlled by the mass media.



As long as there are those amongst us who care about the truly beautiful, the uplifting experience of  witnessing great works of art, be they visual, sound or the written word, there is still hope for our species; and by extrapolation, live classical music performances.



Alberich

P.S.-Great question; thanks for asking it.



</answer>



<answer from>



michanso...
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 312 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Being a classical pianist, I hope to keep the performing tradition alive!  Nothing beats a live performance of great music, and every person I've ever dragged along to their first live performance has loved it.  It's not a question of its worth...there is no doubt that a live concert is better than youtube, recordings, etc.  It is a question of reaching an audience.  People are sometimes indimidated by classical music, but don't realize how easy it is to enjoy.  One one hand we need to educate the public...at least a little.  Just enough for your average Joe to understand how to listen to the piece.  On the other hand, we have to entertain them and keep them from being bored with the music.  There is a healthy balance.  I feel that every program I put together should be appealing to both the layman and the professor.  I'm currently giving a concert of all Rachmaninoff preludes (not all 24).  Highly demanding and musical, virtuosic, fun, singable, impressive, emotional, and lots of varitey.  (Really, I just love playing it, but I think it meets the criteria also.)  Anyway, it will be my job to ensure that live performance doesn't die!



</answer>

<answer>



This may be a silly way to put it, but compare going to a concert to going out for a meal.

Sure, cooking your own meal can nice (as is sticking in a CD by your favourite band/artist), but you can't beat going out and being treated to a meal cooked by a professional there and then, and not having to do then washing up.  We can cook like it,but it's not quite the same, is it.

Same principle applies to live music.  Sure it sounds good, all edited, mastered, re-mastered etc, but listening to raw live music gives you atmosphere, and it feels more personal, more alive!

I think until humans (or computers for that matter), become perfect, I don't think there's much to worry about.  Besides, robots can't replicate human emotion like humans, yet!



</answer>

<answer>



Hello Hafwen,  I hope you are wrong, but I find the quality has dropped unbelievably over the last 6 or 7 years. Once upon a time,one could go to an outdoor performance on a summer evening and hear pieces by Walton, Butterworth, etc., with other pieces by Smetana or Dvorak (not the Largo or something that has been used to advertise toilet paper on hte T.V!), and fireworks finish.  I was at a concert organised by the National Trust a few weeks ago - it was a farce.  Over popular pieces just to put bums on seats.  Even the guest tenor said to the audience that he had never before seen, " A conductor in red lame tails wearing a pink cowboy hat, bare his backside to the audience during a performance of,"The Hall of the Mountain King". I will be keeping indoors in future. Chester Cathedral has some very good concerts for the early summer.  Try there.



</answer>

sexysici...

<answer>



One cannot beat the exuberance of the outdoor concert.  Everyone out there with their picnic baskets, Champagne and strawberries etc. having a good time.  The Fireworks displays at the end of the evening - so fantastic!



On Saturday 5 July I saw Katherine Jenkins at Victoria Park, Haywards Heath.  The show was fantastic and the evening ended with the 1812 overture to fireworks.  Most recently I went to see Paul Potts at Stanstead Park (House) near Portsmouth - Sat 19th July.  On the 20th July I returned to see the 'Here and Now' Concert featuring an amazing line up of original artists performing their hits from the 80s: Kid Creole & The Coconuts, Curiosity Killed The Cat, Limahl, Nick Heyward, Toyah, T’Pau, Midge Ure.



The audience was of mixed ages: from tots to OAP's.  There is not anything that can come close to the exciting feeling of being there.  Course you can watch it on TV, listen to it on your iplayer, ipod, the radio etc, etc but it is not the same experience as been at a live concert!



I am going to an ultimate experience on the 19th September - Music on Fire at Sandhurst - I cannot wait.



Source(s):



myself love entertainment. xx
http://www.ukproductions.co.uk/proms_ind...
http://www.musiconfire.com/



</answer>

<answer>



Just recently back from holiday in Norfolk. My grandson who is a rock/blues/jazz guitarist came with us and as always so did his guitar. Technology allowed us to do a web search of music venues in the area and led us to a pub on the broads with a live band. they actively encourage audience participation. My grandson jammed with them and during the course of the evening we had rock, blues, country and a bit of jazz. Live music is still around and always will be, you just have to look around  for it. Oh don't worry too much about running out of oil, as I remember my history lessons the original travelling minstrels got around quite well on horseback. Now theres a thought, Glastonbury with no car parks , just stables.



</answer>

wat3rh0r...
Member since: 03 April 2008
Total points: 1947 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



With live performances being neccessary to record music in the first place, I don't see that technology will make them completely extinct.

For sure a heck of a lot of samples and electronically synthesized sound effects are used more now than ever, but that just makes live music performances such as Classical more desirable, also there seems to be a rise in real guitar music being played live, and the latest technology only wants to compliment that and encourage this generation of 'audience' let alone would be musicians to embrace the live performance experience with the likes of 'Guitar Hero' interactive computer games.

I can see that musicians that master Classical music will demand more money for live performances though, and so that will always set a trend for home entertainment to cater for those that are on a budget...

Ampitheatres to entertain the ancients are still as popular now and will be in the future I feel, and the exciting technology that is being used to project dead stars as holograms utilise live orchestras, such as Frank Sinatra, so that could be a competitive force for the future as more and more artists demand high prices for the privelege...

Live music is always going to be 'in' though, trust me.
As for the oil crisis, there are advances in engineering that don't rely on fossil fuels that are waiting on the patent shelves, when the world oil corporations finally collapse they'll just have to sponsor the greener technologies and stop being greedy.



</answer>

<answer>



Pop is short for popular , ie music that sells and tops the sales charts ie the stuff of the Now compilations

http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/search?ie=UTF...

Alternative is a very wooly genre which usually means guitar groups with suits / t shirts and sylised hair , a sort of pop punk

but by definition of alternative music would be personified by Tom Waits and Captain Beefheart and particularly Swordfishtrombones

Waits
http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/search?ie=UTF...
Beeefheart
http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/search?ie=UTF...

<answer from>



Who Painted The Kitten?
Member since: 24 July 2007
Total points: 6963 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Here's a list of some of my fave songs at the moment...brace yourself!

"The Art Of Feeling Lost", "Before The Chance To Leave", "Making Colours" and "Running Shoes" by Motion In Colour.

"Hear You Me", "Work", "Always Be" and "Carry You" by Jimmy Eat World.

"Trip The Light Fantastic", "She's Got Grace" and "Phoenix Rising" by Chinastyle.

"Forever", "Pretend" and "All I Wanted" by Toby Domoney.

"Save Us", "Fortunate" and "Honestly" by Cartel.

"I Caught Fire (In Your Eyes)", "On My Own", "Yesterday's Feelings", "The Bird And The Worm", "Smother Me", "Earthquake" and "Find A Way" by The Used.

"Incomplete", "Push Me Away" and "This Is The Sound" by The Last Goodnight.

"Superman", "Apple", "I Find The Light In You" and "Getting Away" by Joe Brooks.

"You" and "6 Degrees C" by Stokoz To Moscow.

"Troi Nol" and "Miss Stiletto" by Monte Cassino.

And some random ones:
Just For The Summer - Cursing Caroline
I Know - C Side
All The While - Boyce Avenue
The Center Ring - Chris Ayer
No Reason - The Nites
Goodbye - Faintly
Down And Out - The Academy Is...
When I'm Gone - Simple Plan

And anything by Mayday Parade.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Which is the best Alto Saxophone for learning on, Trevor James or Yamaha



Trevor James Horn Revolution II  £599
or
Yamaha YAS 275



£579



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks, yes we rent the Yamaha YAS 275 and wish to buy one but not sure between the two I've mentioned.



</additional details>



<answer from>



skotch
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 182 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



yamaha is a really good brand get it.



Source(s):



my friend has one and he's first chair at school



</answer>



<answer from>



jriley38...
Member since: 14 June 2008
Total points: 199 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



rent one until you are sure you want to spend the money on either



</answer>



<answer from>



Alex
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 5067 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have a Yamaha, and personally they sound and work very well. I would  go with the Yamaha... enjoy!



</answer>



<answer from>



King John
Member since: 26 February 2007
Total points: 2182 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yamaha's a more popular brand. Usually the popular brands are the good ones. I mean, if yamaha's weren't that great, then people would talk about how bad they were and nobody would buy them. 
Basically everyone uses them, and I think they have a great sound. If your really not sure though even after this, then ask your band director. Most band directors have a lot of knowledge about this kinda stuff. Like even if they play the flute, they still know how to fix a problem with a basoon or some other non-popular instrument. It's like they're magical, almost.



Oh, and a great place to get alto sheet music is 8notes.com
It's free too. so... well most of its free. Some pieces you have to buy, but anyway, most is free. You should check it out. They have sheet music for almost every instrument. Well, good luck making the right decision and all :)



</answer>



<answer from>



saxmanj
Member since: 24 December 2007
Total points: 1049 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't just settle on those two just because they are low in price. Try others as well. I have an Antigua SX392 Alto saxophone and have been successful with it ever since Beginning Band. I have 3 years of experience and already have the skill of a college student. Try both out and see which one suits you better. Don't settle on price, but settle on sound.

Hope I helped! =)



</answer>

<answer from>



Synacky [Gabey isn't ugly]
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 4024 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ooh, this is a hard one. I couldn't ever pick an abosolute best, or favorite song by Evanescence. They are just so amazing it's impossible. Their lyrics are haunting, chilling and refreshing. Amy's voice is so beautiful and with metal it sounds awesome. Evanescence is very unique, I've never heard another band just like them. I know several that kind of resemble them, like Within Temptation, Lacuna Coil and Nightwish, but they are all in another genre. No band is as good as Evanescence in their own way. Yes, their are better musicians out there than the ones in Ev. (with an exception of Amy) but Evanescence is one of a kind and how the music works together is what sets them aside from all those other bands. Sorry this is so freaking long, I'm obsessed with Evanescence. =]



Source(s):



Hardcore Evanescence Fan



</answer>

<question>



Do you think I could learn to play the piano?



I am 17 and I want to learn an instrument, is the piano a hard thing to learn and if I was to learn it would I have to learn to read music or do plenty of people learn without knowing how to read music? Do you play the piano? If so how hard did you find it was to pick it up? And how long does it usually take to get pretty good at it? Any other info would be useful! Thanks for your answers.



</question>



<answer from>

Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 1483 (Level 3)

R-Mister

<answer from>



JennyBen...
Member since: 06 March 2007
Total points: 289 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



basically anyone can learn to play the piano. just practice practice practice. normal people would learn to read music. Talented people would learn to play by ear. I play the piano - somewhat. I started when I was 8. unless you are a musical genius, it takes months or even years to be good at it. you can go to a local music store to pick up some starter stuff.



</answer>



<answer from>



brodythe...
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 966 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm sure you can.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mordent
Member since: 18 June 2006
Total points: 13870 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Anyone can learn the piano. Anyone could become very good at it. BUT those who aren't children find it much harder to learn than younger people. Past about 14 if you have no training in music it becomes a lot more difficult to learn an instrument - or to learn anything at all.



I've played the piano for 16 years, since I was 4 years old. Because I've been playing it about as long as I've been able to read I didn't find it hard at all, I found it was just one of those things that you learnt to do as a child. Learning at 17 will be challenging, and you will have to put in more work than a younger person would, but it is far from being impossible. Invest in a good teacher and you will definately be on the right track.



</answer>



<answer from>



slim b
Member since: 09 July 2006
Total points: 210 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Piano isn't difficult but maybe a good idea would be to start with a keyboard with the one key chord function so you get used to the sound of the melody and chords being played together. Also it'll help you practice playing with two hands. I've always wanted to play the guitar and started 2 years ago. Now I'm starting to record my own stuff and I'm 35. All it takes in inspiration, dedication and practice. Good Luck!



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



hafwen
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 2404 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Is that tune Mozartian, Mozartesque or Mozartic? The art of creating adjectives out of composers' names...?



As both musician and wordsmith, I'm intrigued by the peculiar practice of transforming composers' nouns into adjectives - and the apparent lack of rules surrounding this practice.



It seems that all one needs to do is stick a suffix like "-esque," "-ian" or "-ish" onto the end of a famous name - and abracadabra - you have a colourful new adjective!

I've come across an incredible kaleidoscope of examples...for example, I've seen Beethoven's music described in six different ways - "Beethovenian," "Beethovenesque," "Beethovenish," "Beethovenic," "Beethovenistic" - even "Beethovenese!"

Some trip off the tongue more easily than others - don't you think "Purcellian" and "Haydnesque" sound more graceful than the somewhat cumbersome "Rimsky-Korsakovesque" or "Khachaturianesque?" (and yes, I've seen these written!)

I'd be interested to hear your thoughts on this subject...please, share some of your theories, or some weird and wonderful examples you've read somewhere, or even some you've created yourself!



Hafwen



</question>



<additional details>



EDIT:

Maybe you can take a favourite composer (or two) and see how many adjectives you can create with his/her name...be as crazy and imaginative as you like!



</additional details>



<answer from>



prowberr...
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 667 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mozartian exists in dictionary.com and the other two don't, so I guess it is the only proper form. However none of them are in the Yahoo spell checker!



The great thing about language is that people are inventing new words all the time.



Source(s):



http://dictionary.reference.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



Mary M
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



This question made me laugh. I was just talking to a friend about this. For years I have noticed that we have started using proper names with a slapped on suffix to describe something (think Kafkaesque) as the norm. It appears that in our ever evolving vocabulary we have become overly generalistic and lazy. Imagine a writer once said "the piece was remniscent of Beethoven" now shortens it to "the piece is Beethovenesque" 
I personally blame Joss Whedon's writing and the pervasive desire of the American psyche to glob onto perversions of the English language. Besides it's more fun to say these descriptors. It has the unusual ability to make you sound both pretensious (hell, just knowing who Rimsky-Korsakov is seems impressive) while at the same time making yourself seem modern by bastardizing an artist's name for the purpose of description.

Maybe I am putting to much thought into this. ; ) But funny question.



</answer>



<answer from>



Isolde
Member since: 25 June 2008
Total points: 784 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hafwen, your questions are always so creative and an absolute pleasure to read the answers!  So fun!

When I'm writing a more serious work, I usually use the "ian" ending, unless I'm talking about a French piece, and then any composer mentioned gets the française ending "esque."  If a piece of music is a hybrid, I usually describe its qualities as "ish." For a lighter tone, I'd use "istic."  Funny, but I've never thought about it before now.

Now you have my head whirling!  :)



</answer>

<answer from>



rdenig_m...
Member since: 26 November 2006
Total points: 22938 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



History



Rail



</answer from>



<answer>



Fasctinating question Hafwen! When I read it I pulled my Chambers off the shelf to see what it has to say. There is no entry for the -ian suffix, althought there is for the -esque 'in the style of manner of, similiar to, as in Kiplinesque'.  )Comment. You wouldn't say Kiplingian because it sounds too ugly.)

So I then looked up 'Victorian'  'adjective of, contemporary with, typical of, the reign of Queen Victoria....'.



I then looked up a architectural description - 'Romanesque' 'adjective of the transition from Roman to Gothic architecture...'



So I have the following thought. Both '-ian' and '-esque' can be correctly used as suffixes when converting a noun to an adjective - for that is what is being done. My personal view is that -ian is used when speaking of persons - as another example historians refer to the reforms of the Anglican Church liturgy under Charles I as 'Laudian', making an adjective out of the name of Archbishop Laud who promulgated them. Similarly, an inhabitant of Latvia is a Latvian. However, if you are talking of abstract concepts you use the -esque suffix - for example ladies of a certain type used to be called 'statuesque' But here my theory falls down as such ladies are also described as 'Rubenesque'. And see my comments above concerning Kipling. So I draw the conclusion that it depends on how the adjectivised noun sounds. 'Elgarian' is perfectly acceptable, but 'Vaughan Williamian'? No! In fact in that case, and that of the Russians you refer to my personal view is that the adjective becomes so clumsy that it should be avoided and if one wanted  to compare you would say something like 'music that sounds like V-W, R-K, etc' A little more circumlocutory, but sounding so much better!

As for 'ese' I (again personally) think that is wrong applied to an individual. It does appear in Chambers as 'denoting a relationship with a country or region as in Japanese, Maltese, or the literary style, jargon etc. of a particular group, as in journalese, officialese'



'-ish' can be used (although, again it can sounds clumsy when attached to the wrong noun) and, again from Chambers 'adjective suffix signifying somewhat, as brownish, like or similar to, sometimes implying deprecation, as outlandish, childish, or roughly, approximately, as in sixish'. So Beethovenish could be used, although it is very ugly.

'ist' is defined  as 'suffix denoting the person who holds a doctrine or practises an art, as Calvanist, chemist, novelist. artist, royalist'  So I would argue 'Mr X, the pianist is an excellent Beethovenist' (meaning he is a great interpreter of Beethoven)  is wrong, whereas 'Mr Y is an brilliant violinist' is right. And 'Smetana was a Czech Nationalist composer' is right but 'his music is Smetanaist' is totally wrong.. But you could say 'Smetana wrote music that is nationalistic in feeling',



To sum up '-ian' and -esque' are interchangeable, and their use depends entirely on how the the adjective sounds. Thus 'Chopinesque' is fine, but 'Chopinian' sounds wrong. 'Lisztian' sounds fine, but not 'Lisztesque'. Once a name gets beyond a couple of syllables, then don't use a suffix at all, but 'in the style of'.....Rachmaninov, Shostakovich' etc.



</answer>

<answer from>



Teaim
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 8106 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here are what I, and many others, consider the top shelf in jazz singing...

Sheila Jordan
The Try her album called Portrait of Sheila. Its an absolute classic vocal jazz recording of the 1960's. Great band on that album too.

Sarah Vaughan
Try her self titled album (aka: Sarah Vaughan and Clifford Brown). Another huge classic vocal album.

Carmen McRae
Try her album called Sings the American Song Book. Features the great Joe Pass on guitar.

Billie Holiday
Anything by her is great. I suggest the early stuff (1930's), with Lester Young, Roy Eldridge, Teddy Wilson. These people created singing jazz, for the most part. Get anything and everything you can by Billie.

The instrumental players that you listed are of such a wide variety that its really hard for me to narrow my answer down to just a few that you might enjoy. 
If it is funk you are looking for, I can't help you much. The answer that I gave regarding JAZZ singers is from lots of experience, and I can confidently suggest what I have suggested.



</answer>

<question from>



fire_haw...
Member since: 01 May 2007
Total points: 135 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Could someone tell me what piece of music this is?



it features on trailer 1 of "I Am Legend"

Here is a link to where u can find the trailer:

http://www.apple.com/trailers/wb/iamlege...



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It's Death Is The Road To Awe  composed by Clint Mansell and performed by Mogwai & the Kronos Quartet. It's on the soundtrack to a film called The Fountain.

The blog below has a link to the song. It's not quite the same version as what's on the trailer but it's still great :)



Source(s):



http://theplaylist.blogspot.com/2007/12/...



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Ciao! Io ho sentito la canzona, e ho capito quasi tutti i parole in inglese....
I want You
I need you
I give my freedom just to be with you
Together(poi no lo so- c'e una ragazza parlando sopra)
Song I want to hear again
Know that I belong here by your side
Love is something you cannot hide
Come to me, set me free
Love can last an eternity
Play your part, reveal your heart
Let your love show (yeah)
Love can change everything
Turn you into(poi non lo so)
Spero che questo e sufficiente (e mi dispiace per il mio Italiano..sono Inglese, e traslocavo in Ingleterra an'altra volta in 2004 dopo tre anni a Roma..Ho dimenticato un sacco...)
Edit- Prego! Sono stato un Insegnante di Inglese, allora se vuoi aiuto, mi scrivi. Buona serata



</answer>

<answer from>



cjhardy

<answer>



There are a number of great laces to get online sheet music YOu might want to try the following:
http://www.sheetmusicplus.com/enter.html
 I have typed in My Heart will go On and they have this particular sheet music in a number of levels of advancement. This is a paying site.
Free downloads might be had at:
http://www.rowy.net/sheet_music.html
 Hope this was helpful to you. Good luck.



</answer>

<answer from>



Ranteate...
Member since: 10 August 2006
Total points: 1970 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's a good question, but I don't think the answer is that simple.  I grew up in the 50's/60's and many of my friends will only listen to music from that era.  Over the decades there have always been good new performers, but other factors have come into play.  Once live music gave way to disco's, the era of "dance music" arrived.  Basically music split between stuff that was good to dance to, and stuff that was worth listening to.  Add to that the need by some "insiders" to create artificial labels to different types of music and you just get more confusion.  In the end there is just good and bad music, so why the need for all these labels?  It's partly the fault of US radio, who seem to play only one type of music rather than a broad spread as in the UK.
In the end a good musician will stand the test of time no matter what, but I do wonder how many of current "stars" will achieve long-term success - it's all about "now".  And the sad thing is no-one seems to care whether these "stars" are the real thing or not.  If one of them passed away tomorrow, would they be remembered?  The Buddy Holly/Jimi Hendrix type is a rare thing.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Is 1.5 to 2 hours (sometimes 2.5) hours a day of piano practice good? is it really good? or just ok?



</question>



<answer from>



hollywoo...
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



ok if u just want to play just to know an insterment than its fine but if u want to be profeshional you need a lot more a day



</answer>



<answer from>



Ritus
Member since: 27 December 2007
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



hafwen
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 2404 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree with the first two answerers - it depends on what your musical ambitions are. If you're aiming to play professionally, you'll definitely need to put more hours in each day.

It's important to consider the WAY you practice, too. If you're spending 1.5 - 2.5 hours a day working in a focused, structured way, then that's far more valuable than just "noodling" about.



A good, solid practice session (whether it's 1.5 hours or 5 hours long) should also incorporate some technical work - scales, arpeggios and other exercises. I'd do these at the beginning, then follow with studies - they help limber up mind and body, and prepare you for the work you'll then do on your pieces.

Just remember - 1.5 hours of focused, analytical practice achieves far more than 5 hours of "mucking around."



Good luck, and happy playing!

Hafwen x



Source(s):



B.Mus (Honours) in performance



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=AmBe8ZyP9p9UeQSiPssB03GxBwx34fe.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk37216.txt</current file name>



<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Keane
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What makes a truly great cover version and why?



Yahoo! Staff Note:  This is the real Keane.



For further details about how you can see them live in concert check out http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



</question>



<answer from>



jay29erb...
Member since: 27 May 2006
Total points: 563 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There has to be a combination of a great choice of song (NOT necessarily a great song), a great artist and the song should be covered in a way that makes the new version a good recording in its own right.  It's pointless covering a song if you're bringing nothing new to the table.

A great cover version is very rarely better than the original, and neither should they often be considered to be, but it may compare and enjoyment of the original should not be hindered by the existance of a cover.

Deciding how to cover a song and making a good job of it should follow similar principles to writing and recording an original song.  The effort levels often compare and often need to for the cover to be a success.

To sum up, for a cover to be great the artist must be great, the choice of song must be great and the cover should be created and not carried out.



A carbon copy will never a great cover make.

Greatest cover ever?  Well it's a pointless argument because everyone knows that if Nirvana had actually CREATED a fully-mixed and mastered studio-recorded version of My Sharona nothing else would've come close.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Really liked your answer Jay29erboy.  Thanks for answering and hope to you enjoy the gig this Thursday!  Richard.



</asker's comment>

Helen
