<answer>



Hiya Keane -



1.



I think the original song has to be great, but its no good if the song was played to death the first time round, like Kylie - Can't Get You Out Of My Head.

2.



It should be a song that spans the years, im waiting for a good cover version of "say hello, wave goodbye! by soft cell, (sad I know), sorry David Gray fans but I wasn't keen on it with the guitars.

3.



When you do a cover version you take on a little bit of the original singers identity, i.e, you really wouldn't want to cover a Gary Glitter song. Hehe. So if you pick a song, try to pick a song by a really cool band, or a neutral band.

Here is a list of my favourite cover versions, afterwards I will try to analyse whether there is a determining factor;

a) Mariah Carey - Without You 
b) Cher - Walkin' In Memphis 
c) Skin/Skunk Anansie - Teenage Kicks
d) Will Young - Light My Fire
e) Wet Wet Wet - Love Is All Around
f) Comfortably Numb - The Scissor Sistors
g) Housemartins - Caravan of Love 
h) Soft Cell - Tainted Love
I) Pet Shop Boys - Always On My Mind



These songs are all not my favourite songs but I give them credit because they are all artistic and have individual stamps - if someone says the title of the song - if I think of the cover version first - I know it's successful.

Also this list shows that a song with a huge reputation - like Always On My Mind - can be taken and turned into a new classic. It also shows how songs which aren't that well know can be made well known by a good covers.

You have to cover something that no one would expect - something that will sound totally different - but still good - in your style.



.........................................



Here is a list of my least favourite cover versions;



a) Ronan Keating - Iris
b) Westlife - The Rose
c) Westlife - Mandy
d) Atomic Kitten - Ladies Night
e) Atomic Kitten - The Tide Is High
f) Sheryl Crow - Sweet Child Of Mine
g) M People - Itchycoo Park
h) David Gray - Say Hello Wave Goodbye
i) Sam And Mark - With A Little Help From My Friends



These covers depress me because they are thoughtless. Ronans version of the Goo Goo Dolls is awful, anyone who loved the original could not possibly like this version. None of these covers have been changed much when they have been recorded - it's simply like hearing them sing kareoke versions of their favourite songs.



Never pick a song that is treasured, like The Rose, unless you are going to completely rearrange it, people just get angry.

.........................................



But y'know something, Keane, darlings, I think, the most important thing if you do a cover version you have to put your own stamp on it and I dont think you would have any problem doing that with your unique and wonderful voice,just please please please dont do Mandy or Unchained Melody!!!!!!!

Look forward to your next gig,



love ya's loads

(just to let you know, if I win the tickets I will scream and probably bare my breasts) shameless bumlick over.....tee hee



Helen

Del Shannon - Run Around Sue (always gets me dancing and I think you would sound F&gt;A&gt;B singing it) , Erasure - Love To Hate You, (it has such a catchy tune that would lend itself to any genre and I'd love to hear you sing it) or Phil Collins - Invisible Touch, (a song I love but I don't think Sir Phil nailed it properly).

Good Luck Again x x x

<answer>



Got to agree with the others. It's about taking a song and adding to it. It's not enough just to re-do it as was.



This is where, in my opinion, Robbie Williams went wrong with his swing album. Exactly the same music which might have been okay, but he can't "swing" which just led to a flat performance. Fine if your a Robbie fanatic, but musically very poor.

Production can sometimes make a big difference. Leaving aside Whitney Houstons showboating, listening to her version of "I will always love you" against the original fills the song out more.

One of the best cover versions I've ever heard, although it's only part way a cover as the original artist is on there, is the duet Ray Charles did with Elton John of "Sorry Seems To Be The Hardest Word". He blows Elton away. He's sounds like he's actually living the song and Elton manages to sound like a pub singer.

<answer>



I am not usually a fan of cover versions, especially of well loved songs, and those are the ones that artists cover . From time to time I am pleasantly surpirsed.

If a song was done with a powerful voice ,it seems wrong to have some naff voice trying to recreate it. I am all for making it your own , but the aim should be to make the song better , otherwise what is the point.

Adding a bit of dance music, may fool some people for a short while, but in the end the song is short lived.

To make a great cover version , you need excellent vocals and to have won the public's admiration already, before trying to honour someone else's music. When newbies come on the scene and do lifeless covers , I lose interest in them quickly, thinking they lack originality.

I agree with the person above who said that Fine Young Cannibals have done great covers. I also love Simply Red's covers. He has enough talent to make his own music , but now and again improves an old song, some of them less well known.

The mother of your number one fan.

</answer>



<answer from>



DreamWea...
Member since: 06 July 2006
Total points: 1165 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bringing your own unique voice and style to a song while respecting how and why it was created - perhaps in a way that make people see it in a new light, or even gives a whole new meaning to the lyrics without changing a word.

Simply singing it the same is at best a tribute, at worst karaoke.

Examples:
Gary Jules "Mad World" - took a fairly obscure piece of electronica and let the lyrics ring out, both literally and metaphorically... beautiful and melancholy.

Fugees "Killing Me Softly" - stripped back and laid back, again this brings a piece of classic Motown back to life, making it slinkier and emphasising the sexiness...

Art Of Noise / Tom Jones - "Kiss" - introduced the Great Voice Of The Valleys to a whole new generation of fans - and making him a thoroughly modern artist  to boot with all new songs - but also gave the song itself a brasher, brassier twist that's instantly memorable and embarrassingly danceable. There's lovely for you!



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 19 October 2006
Total points: 103 (Level 1)

mjmelich

Total points: 862 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Definitely a great cover is one that includes some dramatic variation from the original version of the music, and brings out a mix of unique style from the band that's covering the song.  In the end, a great cover is one that takes the original tune, but generates a new & unique piece of music from it.



I think that mash-ups of different instrumentation & vocalalisation can really bring out great things in an old tune (and I don't mean just putting distortion on a guitar track).  When a band puts their own style into an older song it brings out something that you would not have heard from the original musical source.

Best two examples I can think of are Hendrix definitive 'cover' of Dyan 's original, All Along the Watchtower.  Also, a cover sticks in my mind of The Walrus by the Beatles, which I saw covered by Frank Zappa and his band on Frank's last tour in 1988.  Splendid renditions of already great music.  In those cases, even though the 'cover' barely resembles the original, it bring out things in the music that are so innovative as to create a new piece of music that's original in and of itself.



</answer>



<answer from>



Geri M
Member since: 29 September 2006
Total points: 260 (Level 2)

sarcasti...

<answer>



What does work:



- making the song your own (see Soft Cell's 'Tainted Love')
- sound like you mean the lyrics - even though they're not yours (see Johnny Cash's 'Hurt' / Jeff Buckley's 'Hallelujah')
- make it fun (see Weird Al's back catalogue)

What doesn't work:



- cover versions of 'Goodbye Yellow Brick Road'



</answer>

<answer from>



theredal...
Member since: 09 October 2006
Total points: 930 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Saw you at Hull Arena on Tues 17th Oct.  Fantastic performance guys!!

Cover versions eh?  There's gotta be a certain amount of respect shown to the original, but there's gotta be something extra added (or possibly taken away) to it to make the song your own.  Personally, I think your own version of The Sun Ain't Gonna Shine Anymore is good, but not a truly great (no disrespect intended).

I think that lesser known tracks often make better cover versions than mainstream tracks for the reason that people aren't constantly comparing it to the original.  Sometimes that's a good thing, it's gets the song noticed and people talk about it, but it doesn't make the song any better.  You've also gotta choose tracks that suit the voice of the person singing.

My own personal favourite cover versions:

Hallelujah - Jeff Buckley
Frontin' - Jamie Cullum
Comfortably Numb - Scissor Sisters
(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction - Devo
Mad World - Gary Jules
All Along The Watchtower - Jimi Hendrix



</answer>



<answer from>



gvih2g2
Member since: 14 August 2006
Total points: 8247 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



A great cover version should not just be different from the original, but bring out a feeling or meaning that wasn't in the original version.

Sinead O'Connor's "Nothing Compares 2 U" is probably the ultimate, but I also love Aswad's "Don't Turn Around".



</answer>



<answer from>



Madfan
Member since: 05 September 2006
Total points: 1245 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cover versions should sound nothing like the original, Always On My Mind by Pet Shop Boys, Satisfaction by Devo etc. Personally i would like to see more covers of less well known songs, instead of the endless Unchained Melody remakes! There are so many great songs that weren't hits.



</answer>



<answer from>



Fiona M
Member since: 05 September 2006
Total points: 283 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Make it your own, dont make it sound like the original version, jazz it up a bit, make it colourful and something to remember for years to come. 
Take time to come up with different ways of singing it, maybe add a little to it, make it the best song ever to be re-released.

I would pick a song that was a top ten hit years ago, and bring it up to date.



</answer>

peltonwh...

<answer>



I always assumed he was a sailor.Iwas born in Co. Durham ,it is a local song.Could be he was an historical figure who went off to seek his fortune ,?



</answer>



<answer from>



The Saint
Member since: 15 July 2008
Total points: 5387 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is no proof that Bobby Shaftoe actually went to sea, it was probably a rumour put round, so that he could marry Anne Duncombe, instead of Bridgette Belasyse.



Source(s):



I live five miles from his old house.



</answer>



<answer from>



Quizard
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 65196 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



The song is said to relate the story of how he broke the heart of Bridget Belasyse of Brancepeth Castle, County Durham, where his brother Thomas was rector, when he married Anne Duncombe of Duncombe Park in Yorkshire instead. Bridget Belasyse is said to have died two weeks after hearing the news, although other sources claim that she died a fortnight before the wedding of pulmonary tuberculosis.

He married Anne Duncombe on 18 April 1774, and is said to have spent her personal fortune. In Baron Feversham's opinion the countless young ladies whom he jilted on his return from his travels enjoyed "a lucky escape".



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bobby_Shaft...



</answer>



<answer from>



Bear
Member since: 10 November 2007
Total points: 10689 (Level 6)



</answer from>

</answer>

Celia H

<answer>



Well - he was probably a Geordie, so he would have gone to sea in a collier ship.  The silver buckles on his knee tell us he wasn't an ordinary seaman.  So maybe he was an apprentice, or a shipowner's son (he could have been both, of course).

And I hope he did come back and marry his girl.

<answer from>



stratpla...
Member since: 12 April 2006
Total points: 5942 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



there doesn't have to be a title of "lead" or rhythm player in a band.  You could play lead parts in one song and the other guy play lead parts in the next song.  In my band we usually go by who can make the part sound the best or who wants to play the lead part on any particular song, as long as it's not the drummer.



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AppnvHmkNcFl5yb84JlinpgTOxh347c.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk38917.txt</current file name>



<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Bob
Member since: 02 March 2008
Total points: 386 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Any 1920's music enthusiasts, looking for something more in the "Mooche" style?



I've been studying the 1920's for a book I'm working on, and like to listen to period tunes to capture the mood.  I recently ran across Duke Ellington's "The Mooche" from 1928 and really fell in love with it.  It is quite different from other songs of the period that I've found.  Kind of dark, melancholy, and sophisticated.

I'd like to listen to more tunes of that type, but obviously I can't sample every song put out between 1920 and 1935.  So I'm hoping for some pointers from those of you (if there are any of you) who know about music of this era.  I'm  regular I-Tunes buyer, so if the song is available there, so much the better.

Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



mamianka
Member since: 30 May 2007
Total points: 12623 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Classical



Performing Arts



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You need a little Bubber Miley in your life - he was the trumpet player on the best-known cut of The Mooche.  www.redhotjazz.com/bubber.html should get you some good clips.

Also - Cab Calloway - most anything, but the obvious is Minnie the 
Moocher.  Even the soundtracks of the OLD Betty Boop cartoons would be evocative.  There's more - but this should be enough fun for you tonite.



Source(s):



Taught jazz history overview for many years.  Check out the Ken Burns series, too!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Perfect.  I just purchased Black and Tan Fantasy, Doin' the Voom Voom and East Saint Louis Toodle-oo.  These are exactly what I was looking for.  A shame Bubber Miley died so young!  Thanks for your help!!



</asker's comment>

Entertainment & Music



Music

<question from>



hafwen
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 2404 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Entymological Expositions...Music about Insects?



Recently, I chanced across a wonderful Renaissance chanson by Josquin des Prez, entitled "El Grillo" - "The Grasshopper!" What a fantastic, colourful little song - a perfect musical painting of a grasshopper. All those leaps and jumps - and even the insect's relentless chirping was depicted in this 16th century gem.

What other pieces of music have you encountered, inspired by the insect world?

Oh - and other invertebrates are welcome - maybe even the Arachnids have inspired a few, er, brave composers...



Hafwen



</question>



<additional details>



"The Italian" - thanks for that.

But there are two accepted ways of spelling this word - "entymological" and "entomological" (BTW the second version contains 3 o's, not 2.)



To "The italian" - if you care to Google both spellings of "entymological" you'll find that you really have to accept that your argument is not waterproof. Language is a mutable thing.



And take note, there is no word that's spelt "entomilogical." The correct spelling (of that version) is actually "entomological." THREE o's, not 2.

Cheers :o)



And I thought that Yahoo Answers was actually about ANSWERING, not being argumentative for the sake of it.



</additional details>



<answer from>



bearcat
Member since: 23 September 2006
Total points: 18662 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Classical



</answer from>



<answer>



The most obvious would be "Flight of the Bumblebee" by Rimsky-Korsakov. Also "The Spider's Feast" by Roussel and "The Wasps" suite by Ralph Vaughn Williams.

Tchaikovsky composed a piece titled "Chorus of Insects" for a projected opera which was never completed.

Musician, composer, teacher.



</answer>



<answer from>



Alberich
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 13260 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Classical



</answer from>



<answer>



Would the opera "Moses in Egypt" by G. Rossini, qualify?  I've never heard/seen it, but it would surely have some of the plagues(one of Locust) mentioned in this story, referred to some place in it.



In the Levine, Met. DVD(s) of Wagner's "Ring", in Act II when the "dragon(?)", that comes out of its cave to see who's(Siegfried's)horn call has awakened him, he looks like a gargantuan "spider" to me, rather than what a dragon is usually depicted as looking like.



Would this qualify?  Thought not.  Boy, this is a hard question to answer.



Sorry, but I'm stumped.



Alberich



</answer>

<answer>



Scriabin's Tenth Sonata, also known as the "Insect" sonata due to its trills. I believe there is a "Cockroach" sonata which is composed by Franz Liszt. And of course, there's the "Flight of the Bumblebee" by Rimsky-Korsakov. There may be others though.



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



ღI Loveღ SAMiches
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 1047 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



How much does a bass guitar cost



How much does a decent 4 string electric bass cost?

Does the cost go up with the amount of strings?

My friend's band need a bass player and I usually pick up instruments well so if I learn how to play he will let me join.



Please if possible have the price in dollars and not euros.



</question>



<answer from>



guitaris...
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 149 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Sorry to say this, but prices of any instrument vary according to which country you are in. Expect to pay between  £60 to £500 depending on how much you are prepared to spend on quality. Look for makes like Squire or Fender, Ibanez or Steinberger. Hohner, Aria. The names are many multitudinous and varied. The choice is yours ENJOY!!!!



Source(s):



Musician for 38 years.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for the help.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Xavier W
Member since: 27 January 2008
Total points: 222 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you can get one for about 110 or as much as 1100. it all depends.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris C
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 163 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A very comfortable and versatile bass is the Ibanez Soundgear. They range from 250-1200 dollars, but they all sound pretty good. I would suggest the SR500 series, which are about 500 dollars. They have Bartolini Pickups and active preamps as well as comfortable necks and good fret work. If you want to be in a very traditional jazz band, you might want to consider an upright bass, which is at least 750 dollars for a beginner/student one.



</answer>



<answer from>



himyname...
Member since: 06 November 2007
Total points: 46 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Inexpensive decent basses are squiers, you can get them for about 180-300. Ibanez also has some good cheap basses too but most cheap basses have a really boring tone and frankly alot of string buzz. I can't say im a big fan of the standard mexican made fenders either try getting something from fender a little more expensive like 600+ those are good.



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Gug N
Member since: 08 January 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can I perform for my school's jazz band with bass guitar?



I'm just entering my junior year and I've been playing bass guitar for about 2 years. I'm not that good since I can't read music and I'm not good at improvising. Jazz Band is a second semester class, so I might be able to change to it but it would require alot of work....

If I ask my bass teacher about this and start learning music theory and other stuff, will I be able to make the audition for jazz band? I don't even know what to expect...



</question>



<answer from>



Cjax
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 230 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go for it. Jazz is a great genre of music (for bass and just in general) that will really help you get a better grasp of music and build on your improv skills.



</answer>



<answer from>



m wood
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 166 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can do this. When I started highschool I couldn't read music at all. The bass player had been a senior the year before and when the try-outs came I was the only one so I entered as a freshmen in a band full of seniors who had just won a nation Jazz band competition the year before. By the Christmas concert I was ready to go.

Work with you private instructor and talk to the Band director about getting some of the charts to practice now, if anything he/she will be impressed by your effort.

Don't stress out over improvising because most highschool jazz charts don't require a lot of it. You'll learn to make up jazz bass line by learning ones other people have written.

Good luck!



Source(s):



I'm a bass teacher.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ryell
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depending on the type of jazz your school band plays it can be easy or difficult. If it is more of big band jazz the bass player usually reads a written out bass line from the chart and can improvise from there when you feel comfortable. So for that all you have to do is learn how to read music which your bass teacher can teach you in a short amount of time. 
If it more of a dixieland band you will be doing more improvising than anything because usually all you get is a lead sheet with chords and you have to make up a bassline to fit the chords. For this you need to know your therory like the back of your hand...ive been playing bass for 4 years and still have a hard time with theory but it just comes to certain people better.
The last thing i suggest is listening to the style of jazz that ur school plays and get to know the different sound the bass has in jazz and maybe find a professional player that you like and try to mimic their style at frst.
Jazz is so much fun to play, but you also need great dedication to make the audition by next semester! Good Luck!



Source(s):



personal experience



</answer>



<answer from>



Anthony S
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its exactly as Ryell stated, we are friends and we both played in jazz bands at our school. For me, I learned theory in sixth grade and it just came easy and for others its really hard to understand.  A personal tip from me would be to take the circle of fifths and learn all the keys, learn their chords(major,minor, diminished,etc..) and just learn it and become very familiar with it. This plays a great deal in all styles of jazz u play. Also, it would be a good thing to go out into your community and find a local jazz society and get involved. This is how i have learned everything and its great practice for your playing. Good luck with your jazz band! Its a great thing to get into, and it will lead you to a lot of things! Im gonna be a jazz major cuz it was soo much fun! Just remember, stay calm and just be your self and show it in your playing.



Source(s):



personal experiences



</answer>

<current file name>yqa_uk40739.txt</current file name>



<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



mmm.citr...
Member since: 28 October 2007
Total points: 1091 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



When doing piano grade exams and pieces are really boring?



but you really love piano and you need your grades how do you stay focused and interested in the piece...



</question>



<answer from>



cjhardy
Member since: 18 May 2007
Total points: 461 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



As a classical pianist many years ago I identify with this. Think of yourself as an ice skater doing figures and imagine how focused you'  have to be as you do these fundamental exercises. Remember, no matter how boring they are for you, someone else is hearing it for the first time. I used to mentally put lyrics to pieces that didn't hold my interest. Or imagine someone dancing to it.  Something else you might do is reward yourself with a fun piece you really enjoy after practicing a boring piece. Try to remember that the "boring" pieces have a skill that might turn up in other pieces down the road.
 I remember when I was given Shostakovich's piano concerto to learn as a high school student. It was so hard to get into at first, very modern and dissonant. Today it's my favorite concerto, by far.
 Hope this was helpful. Best of luck in your musical pursuits.



</answer>



<answer from>



totallyh...
Member since: 29 August 2007
Total points: 1821 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



there only boring if you let them be, i always like to pretend i'm playing them for the first time for someone new, so it had to be perfect. But not all pieces are boring in the new grade 8 book, it has alligator crawl by fats waller, i love it, can't stop playing it! but the A & B section always seems to lack that extra something, just stick with it ! good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



duhmight...
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 448 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yea grade pieces are rather boring and i won't say stick with it cause u want the grades...i think that although the piece is boring but consider ur audience or examiner...they may not have heard the piece and would be eager to see wat kind of magic can u produce from it...Just let the music flow into u and get into the music...Try not to think of them as a simple everyday boring piece but something that u can share with other ppl...



</answer>



<answer from>



starfire...
Member since: 09 November 2007
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



try choosing pieces that interests you. my teacher always let me do that. i enjoy my exam pieces, & usually accept my 20th century pieces. (i really don't like them that much). btw, scales are ABSOULUTELY boring!!!! =)



Source(s):



years exams



</answer>

<question from>



Ali
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What do multiple notes on top of each other on sheet music mean?



</question>



<answer from>



psymon
Member since: 18 April 2007
Total points: 5170 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



That all those notes are played at the same time, creating a chord or a harmony.



</answer>



<answer from>



Singing Crow
Member since: 01 November 2006
Total points: 2776 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



On concert band instruments, it means there are two parts of the music that cant be played. Like a first and second part.



On piano, you are supposed to play both notes.



Source(s):



hope I was helpful



</answer>



<answer from>



roseopal...
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it usually means that there are two ways to play it. or it could mean that theres a harmony.



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music

<question from>



hafwen
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 2404 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



So what IS Michael Phelps listening to before his big races?



Let's imagine it's something classical...

So what piece of adrenalin-pumping music do you imagine it is? Is Phelps inspired by one of Beethoven's works? Something by Mahler, perchance? Monterverdi? Or something calming, maybe by Vaughan Williams or Palestrina?

What musical work(s) would psyche YOU into winning seven gold medals?



Hafwen



</question>



<additional details>



Ummm - I did specify "classical" in my question, guys - thanks!



:o]



Actually, Phelps has now won EIGHT gold medals - wow...that hip-hop really must have something in it...



</additional details>



<answer from>



Antelope...
Member since: 14 June 2008
Total points: 970 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Unfortunately, I did read that he listens to hip hop before the races... BUT I'd like to imagine that he's listening to the final movement of Tchaikovsky's 4th Symphony, or Prokofiev's Scythian Suite; yes, I can picture it...

Anything Beethoven would psyche me into winning. I know it's a little cliché, but the 3rd symphony or the 5th (that ending is pretty inspiring!), or maybe the 8th - it always makes me happy. I would definitely NOT listen to anything calming: high adrenaline all the way! Maybe some high-charged Verdi, or selections from Tchaikovsky's Swan Lake...  :)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



An excellent mix of "high adrenalin" music! Beethoven's symphonies would certainly get me pumped, too...a good selection, Antelope!

Hafwen x

<question from>

Member since: 21 August 2006

</question from>



<question>



What innovation could change the face of music during the next decade?



Yahoo! Staff Note: This is the real Pete Tong, please see the Yahoo! Answers blog for further details: 
http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



</question>



<additional details>



How we discover, buy, listen to and enjoy new music has been changing rapidly over the last decade. The rise of MP3s, music blogs and forums, virtual bands, music-focused social networking sites – all of these advances have made a massive difference. But nothing stands still, so what the next seismic shift in music culture will be is a hot topic. Where do you think we’re headed?



</additional details>



<answer from>



alex g
Member since: 02 October 2006
Total points: 157 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



i think it would be somthing like abelton, somthing with a very easy interface which can perform live editing on the fly, or mabe the innovation could be somthing that is used with abelton like a touch screen system which could make live editing much quicker. personaly i love using vinyl and i think you cant beat the feel of mixing in that way and with all this new technology it might get forgotten. i hope not though!



</answer>

<answer from>



Foxy the music teacher
Member since: 23 June 2006
Total points: 351 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The direct publishing, marketing and selling of recorded and written down music by the composer/performer via the Internet, cutting out the big music businesses.  This may be a more democratic way of producing music. It will mean that a great deal more poorly produced or performed music will be available as well as giving a chance to performers and composers who deserve a hearing but never get past the A+R man.



I wonder if this will be an entirely good thing.  Consumers of music may find that sorting their way through the greatly enlarged choice is bewildering, time-consuming and tiring.  In the past, much of the choosing has been done for us by record companies and radio and TV producers.



In the not so distant future we will have to have our own media filters in order to sort out the dross from the danceable, the trite from the tuneful and harpies from the harmonies (or something).

Maybe we need the established media more than we think.  Or maybe we will need to accept a world where the very best is no longer picked out for us (according to a record company's view of public taste) and instead we will have to listen to hours of the mediocre in order to come across the truly sublime.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 04 May 2006
Total points: 12553 (Level 6)

<answer from>



blank
Member since: 18 May 2006
Total points: 2293 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most of it is already happening.

The move away from the need for a publisher and hard format media. The rise of user content creation sites on the internet.

All that is needed now is for affordable composer software or hardware devices that hand-hold the musical novice through the process of creating original music (rather than expensive studio grade sequencing/mixing/sampling kit or mickey mouse amateur, stitch-it-together dance loop software).

With musically 'intelligent' software that we can all afford and use, anybody with a tune in their head or a lyric on their lips can compose, publish and distribute new music.

There will be those who will see this as being the death of real music but that's what everybody said back in the 90's with the rise of electronica & dance music. The fact is that there will always be a discernable difference between the mediocre and genius, ergo; the cream will always rise to the top.



</answer>



<answer from>



Foghorn
Member since: 18 July 2006
Total points: 5766 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Let us firstly examine what constitutes as music. Without entering into the realms of a Thesis, I feel it can be taken as reasonably accurate that music, of whatever genre, is constructed from melody, harmony and rhythm.

Innovations in music are nothing new. Mozart intoduced the clarinet in to the Classical orchestra, Beethoven introduced the Trombone in to the Symphony, Wagner extended the ideas of Liszt that chords should not resolve with immediacy, and thus created a musical debate that continues to this day. Schoenberg dispensed with tonality completely, whilst his pupils, primariliy Berg and Webern, sought ways of getting tonality back into music without it being too obvious. Pierre Boulez, Karlheinz Stockhausen and Luigi Dallapiccola developed the idea of Schoenberg to the extent of creating excellent music out of nuances of indeterminate chordal and linear equations, that can, however, be deciphered by the aware cognoscenti.
 Currently, Harrison Birtwistle is completing this process, to great effect. The use of electronic media was pioneered by these avant-garde artists - the fades, electronic repetitions, and the programmed juxtaposition of the three elements of melody, harmony and counterpoint by electronic means, well predates the atrocities of drum and bass.

The innovation that could most radically change the face of music in the next ten years would be the uttermost rejection by the consumer of the so-called 'pop' (vide popular) sub-culture. This sub-culture, aimed and targeted in particular, to those who do not have the maturity to judge anything,including their own immaturity, by marketeers who purposively pander to adolescent angst by producing material that appeals only to the most primitive instincts, is currently causing serious rifts in society between those who value tranquility and those who, in pursuance of their own immaturity, seek to destroy peace. Posit it as you will, excuse it as you want, the marketing of music destroys both musicianship and musical appreciation, and its exploitation as a marketable commodity derides the Art in totum. The destruction of industry-led 'pop' musical 'culture' could be the best innovation since Milton Babbitt used the computer to generate sound, long before either of us were born.



Source(s):



I'm a musicologist.



</answer>



<answer from>



kirsun10
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 1307 (Level 3)



</answer from>

Music is like art, appreciated from all around the world, we are one we are the future. The future is is the world not countries. When we realise this life will be at pease, but music is the starting point..... This will sen the message



</answer>



<answer from>



Twiggie

Total points: 776 (Level 2)

<answer from>



Nicole C

</answer from>



<answer>



"A Night at the Opera". 
Not only was it my very first Queen album, but it also contains what I consider some of their most unique music. It's so different yet classic. 
A lot of personality and evidence of life's struggles show through in most of the songs.
I also like the fact that I am the only person I know who can literally sing that entire album through verbatim without tiring. I am a dork!



</answer>



<answer from>



Angel of Music
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 1911 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



A Night at the Opera. Classic.
It has Bohemian Rhapsody, Death on Two Legs, Sweet Lady, You're My Best Friend, The Prophet's Song...songs that really make Queen unique and wonderful. And it showcases Freddie at his best. R.I.P.



</answer>

<answer>



Innuendo



Becuase its one of their most Underrated records IMO, it had some of the “Deepest” lyrics on it such as the title track which is my favorite song from by the way, there were musically some the darkest elements than any Queen record, I mean it also had its positive elements like all Queen but IDK with regard to Freddie’s decline in health I just feel something bizarre about it just something more dark I just cant explain it, and last it was Queens LAST record of Composed original material before Freddie’s death, oh and also I was in my FIRST band at the time and we were really doing good and I had the privilege of opening a show at the Mason Jar (my band that is) for my favorite band Fates Warning in that same time frame, so OVERALL it just has a personal sentimental value



</answer>

<question>



Has a song ever....?



lost it's appeal to you because it's gone mainstream?

Not that i'm "too cool" to like something other people like... I just burn my cd's so that they are something that most people don't listen to. What's the point if it's on every radio station around?



</question>



<answer from>



a_collin...
Member since: 16 November 2007
Total points: 830 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yeah, I know exactly what you mean.  I like the song "Paper Planes" by M.I.A, but ever since she's been getting more publicity I feel like I lost the "soul" of the song or at least lost the feeling that it was exclusive to a small group of people that included me.  Maybe it's silly but I like to have songs that no one else listens to; it makes me feel like I have a secret or something hehe.
Maybe that's how you feel too!



Source(s):



I have the same feelings!



</answer>

<answer from>



auryngir...
Member since: 30 March 2006

<answer>



I don't think it's ever completely lost its appeal, but sometimes I start to not like it as much. I get what you mean, it's not like you don't want to share other people's interests, it's just that sometimes it's nice to feel like you have a song/band all to yourself. Radio/television play can turn my favorite song into something that I only listen to a couple times now and then. It's unfortunate.



</answer>

<question>



What do you think of the made in mexico fender basses?



I'm using a squier affinity p bass right now and it sounds ok but i wanted to get something better. I can't decide if i want to put better pickups in them or go for something like a standard mexican p bass and put better pickups in them. Overall do you think the quality of the standard basses are good? Like no fret buzz, smoother playing, and stuff. I was also considering buying an american vintage reissue J or P bass what do you think of their quality?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



mexican P-basses are a huge step up from a squire.

I put a Baddass II bridge and Duncan 1/4 pounders on mine and it kick the snot out of almost everything.



</answer>

<question>

Curency - Music to fly too

</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



seprough
Member since: 19 May 2006
Total points: 11 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



limewire,



</answer>



<answer from>



Kaylie M
Member since: 03 August 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



What I do is in a way complicated, but this is what my friends and i do....We get on Windows Movie Maker. Then get on Youtube (or any music playing website.) and search for the song. Don't play the song yet, but pause it about a second before the song starts (that is if it has a long begining before the song) Then pull WMM (windows movie maker) back up and add any picture as if you were making a movie...only add one and make it 5 seconds longer then the song (timeline) Then click on the narrate button...on mine it is a little mic. right above the timeline. Then make sure that the audio input source is set on either wave out mix or stereo mix. then click record...then press play on the youtube song. You'll have to listen to the whole song. But once the song finishes...click...stop narration. Then save it to your music! There ya go!



</answer>

<question>



Bands!!!!!???????



?



i was wondering if anyone  could suggest a few rock bands. i like 
"sum 41", "three days grace", some of  "audioslave", "miss murder" by AFI, "the used" and other stuff like that. plz suggest a few bands i might like. thank you

<answer from>



qris
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 265 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Okay, this may seem like an ad, but its not.  I'm seriously recommending that you check out the website Pandora Radio.  You put in music you like and it will suggest songs.  Then you go through the songs it suggests and say whether you like them or not.  As you refine your search, it gets closer and closer to what you like.

You can check my history, I don't normally do stuff like this, but I strongly recommend Pandora to everyone.

Oh ya, and its free =)



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



There are several CDs available by Elgar, Walton, Holst, Vaughan Williams.
Walton composed the Battle of Britain film music, as well as music for the Henry V film.

EMI Classics is a good label to look at, and they have a British Composers series dedicated to British music.

<answer>



Stone The Crows,till Les Harvey,her lover at the time was electrocuted on stage via an unearthed guitar.I believe that took the wind out of their sails..and split up. (Les was Alex's brother.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Silver *  Rose ~ Wolf
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 52823 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



She was the lead singer of Scottish band Stone the Crows.
The band was founded by Les Harvey {brother of Alex Harvey}.



She has been described as 'the Scottish / British Janis Joplin', because of her vocal style.



She is probably best known here in Britain for singing 'No Mean City', the theme song to our longest-running TV detective series "Taggart" {she also appeared in an episode "Evil Eye", playing a gypsy}.



~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ ~*~ 
HeresyIsLovely : 
Actually, Maggie Bell has never worked with Mike Oldfield.

You're thinking of the other Scots singer Maggie Reilly, who sang a majority of his songs from 1980+, most notably  'Moonlight Shadow' and 'Family Man'.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 29 April 2006

<question from>



Emma Bunton
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is it about your favourite song that makes it so special to you?



Watch my Yahoo! Answers question live on video here: http://uk.video.yahoo.com/video/play?vid...

For more information on the Spice Girls http://uk.launch.yahoo.com/spice-girls/



</question>



<answer from>



peterf19...
Member since: 14 July 2006
Total points: 328 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The music and lyrics combined, can sometimes reach right in to your heart and really pull you, and make you feel that the song was written specifically for you, even though the song was written about something the writer was feeling at the time. Thats the mark of a good songwriter, they will have some kind of empathy with the audience. It doesn't have to be a well known well loved song. It's easy to answer this question by stating a well known song, as some have, but that doesn't really explain the why.

One that does it for me is 'Is it any wonder' by the Chamelons, who you probably won't have heard of, yet the song might have been written about a situation I faced some yeard ago. Beautiful song.



Source(s):



Me.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Wonderful answer, many thanks.



</asker's comment>

<answer from>



Martin
Member since: 06 December 2005
Total points: 1901 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



There's something so incredible about music. Even though we all enjoy it, explaining exactly why we love our favourite song is hard to do. Music seems to bypass cognitive thoughts and go straight to our emotions.



Each of our favourite songs does this to the max, reminding us of moments of love, heartbreak, anger or joy. That's what makes it so special.



Source(s):



John Coltrane, Dizzee Rascal, El-B, Kode9, Aretha Franklin, Specialist & Tru Skool, Photek, Mala DMZ, Lata Mangeshkar, Sizzla...



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 21 November 2007

<answer from>



yggdrasil's gardener
Member since: 11 December 2005
Total points: 1263 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



"L'amour est un oiseau rebelle" ("Love is a rebellious bird" in English) i.e., Habenera, from the opera Carmen by Bizet.  Most English speakers don't know the name of the song, but anyone would recognize the melody.  It's been said to be the first song with a tango beat.  I usually don't like opera, but Carmen combines the rhythms of traditional Spanish music with classical music brilliantly, to produce something utterly memorable.  This piece may be parodied all the time, but that's only a reflection of its genius; it's sophisticated, yet anyone can enjoy it.  In addition, the song has not become one bit less seductive over more than a century - it gives many modern pop songs more than a run for their money.

Excerpt from the great movie version of the opera:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jYw_d4isS...

You never thought opera could be that sexy, did you?

Lyrics:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habanera_(a...



</answer>



<answer from>



Lady Stormy!
Member since: 06 August 2007
Total points: 9782 (Level 5)

<question>



Good hard rock bands?



Does anybody know of any bands that have songs that are like 3 days grace and breaking benjamin and bands like that?



</question>



<answer from>



hawaiipa...
Member since: 03 September 2007
Total points: 403 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I love 3dg and bb so here are some others that i like:
Atreyu (their old stuff is better, new stuff is still good though)
Avenged Sevenfold
Bullet for my Valentine
Disturbed 
Linkin Park (new stuff is really mellow except for a few songs, older is better)
Papa Roach
Seether
Trivium (new stuff is softer, older is harder)
10 years (mellow, but not bad)
Theres a ton of lesser known bands that are really good too like Alexisonfire, The Black Maria, Black Tide, The Butterfly Effect, Dark New Day, Earshot, The Human Abstract, Oh Sleeper, Red, Trust Company, Under The Flood.
And for even less known bands check out www.garageband.com
Sometimes the best ones are the least known.
But anyway, even if you don't like all of these, hopefully you'll like atleast one. Hope I helped!



</answer>

Crazy For You lyrics



Swaying room as the music starts
Strangers making the most of the dark
Two by two their bodies become one

I see you through the smokey air
Can't you feel the weight of my stare
You're so close but still a world away
What I'm dying to say, is that

[Chorus:]

I'm crazy for you
Touch me once and you'll know it's true
I never wanted anyone like this
It's all brand new, you'll feel it in my kiss
I'm crazy for you, crazy for you

Trying hard to control my heart
I walk over to where you are
Eye to eye we need no words at all

Slowly now we begin to move
Every breath I'm deeper into you
Soon we two are standing still in time
If you read my mind, you'll see

[chorus]

It's all brand new, I'm crazy for you
And you know it's true
I'm crazy, crazy for you

<question>

Verse B(flat) F and C. 
B(flat) for 2 count, F for 2 count and C for 4 count. 
Looking for chords for bridge and verse or bridge or verse.

<question>

</question>



<answer from>



TayGo
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



like rock/alternative music that is independent....meaning it doesnt have constraints as well as a label. although now a days there are indie record labels which is odd hahah.

Bloc Party
Death Cab for Cutie
The Airborne Toxic Event

</answer>



<answer from>



marz
Member since: 05 February 2008
Total points: 624 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



indian?? lol j/p

iss short for independant music... (or film etc)... iss music by artists who arent signed to major labels... who dont have the commercial backing of big labels, companies etc like the majority of the popular artists we know, whose labels who pay to have their artists faces on every wall, billboard etc... basically, a d.i.y artist...



</answer>



<answer from>



Paul G
Member since: 25 October 2007
Total points: 5054 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Originally it meant music on independent record labels or bands that weren't on major record labels.. these days it has come to mean something else... there are major "indie" radio stations with major sponsors...  and "indie" bands on major labels..

its more a type of generic music then being independent... the most popular "indie" bands are probablly the killers, the kooks, the white stripes, the vines, the strokes..the hives... the "the" bands



</answer>

<question from>



Delilah&lt;...
Member since: 23 February 2008

</question from>



<question>



Guitar chord progressions?



what is a good chord progression for a song im writing?
its on my electric guitar but it needs kind of an acoustic sound?
kinda like 'with me' by sum 41. or 'your guardian angel' by the red jumpsuit apparatus. about 5 chords would be good/

please help.x



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



C to D to G to E to F
EDIT: 
C for 4 bars, D for 4 bars, G for 4 bars, E for 2 F for 2.



</answer>

<answer from>



Saul
Member since: 04 April 2007
Total points: 18461 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Music



Performing Arts



</answer from>



<answer>



You mean the "Jesus Christ, our Lord and Saviour", etc part in the second verse didn't give it away?

It's crap. No dynamics, no story, simple musical parts + melodies, etc.

Like a lot of christian praise music, it has a simple, slow beat that encourages its listeners to shut down and veg out to the music. They called it "blissing out" when it was done in the counterculture, but really its the same concept - it really is a form of brainwashing. You could be more diplomatic and call it a way to help you affirm your faith, but it's the same thing.

Look at all those people in the audience praying like pagans, I said to myself.... for after all, that's how pagans prayed in those days. The christians just copied the pagans. Good times.

I doubt that you aren't a christian. I don't think a non-christian would use the phrase "trying to save souls". But, hey, whatever... you got me to watch 30 seconds of christian drivel about how much God loves me, at least how he would if I was a christian and said that Jesus was my lord and savior and all that daddy-complex bullsh.

EDIT: "There's a lot of great music out there that get's ignored simply because its christian"

Seriously? You think Hillsong writes great music? Your taste in music is shallow, biased, and woefully ignorant. If christians would bother to write fewer songs that *have* to revolve around God, and praise God, and talk about God (and/or Jesus), and how they feel like poo and don't deserve God, blah blah blah, and actually wrote some songs that other people could relate to, then MAYBE they'd have a shot.

Every christian artist that has become popular with the mainstream has done so by not being so g.d. jesus-centric, loosening up, and either writing about God in a very vague way, or writing about stuff that the rest of the population might actually give a crap about.

Some people hate to be preached at, and I get bored really fast by songs about something that I have no reason to conclude (ie, a complete lack of factual, literal, objective truth) that could possibly exist. Maybe it's good for them to day-dream, maybe they need to put down the bibles and come back to reality.



Saul



</answer>



<answer from>



Gracie
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 431 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I used to go to Hillsong when I lived in London, they have a lot of good songs, it's like going to a pop concert, but not to forget that's not why we should go to church!

I love Third Day, I don't think you'll get a better love song, and that's what it's called.



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LurIKmNrI...

They're amazing live too.



</answer>

<answer from>



Lew
Member since: 21 November 2006
Total points: 33231 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Yahoo! Answers



Edinburgh



Other - United Kingdom



</answer from>



<answer>



After his appearance in court for setting fire to a bailiffs car and being sentenced to 11 months jail Wayne Fontana (Glyn Geoffrey Ellis) was allowed to walk free from court immediately after already serving the equivalent of his term while held under the Mental Heath Act.
Speaking earlier in 2007, before his "Lady of Justice" appearance, he said: "I'm selling up and pushing off as soon as I've dealt with this issue.
"I've had enough of the ruling classes, even though I love England. It's making us ill. My family and I can't take any more of this government."

He now lives in Spain.



Source(s):



http://www.britishinvasionbands.com/the-...
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-...



</answer>

<question>



Can you ace my 80's rock quiz?



1) What band is fronted by Alice Cooper's ex bass player?

2) What band was started by KISS's ex hard rock guitarist?

3) What 2 guitarists did Steve Vai replace in the 80s?

4) How many Van Halen albums featured Sammy Hagar in the 80s?

5) What guitarist substituted for George Lynch during Don Dokken's first solo album?



</question>



<additional details>



Good answer 2nd guy!  I forgot about Yngwie Malmsteen and Alcatrazz but there's another one too.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Rikitiki...
Member since: 20 February 2006
Total points: 15584 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



1. Winger
2.Vinnie Vincent Invasion
3. Ynvgie Malmsteen in Alcatraz , Vivian Cambell in Whitesnake. David Lee Roth went Solo and hired Vai but I really wouldnt consider that being a replacement.
4..5 Counting their live release
5.John Norum and Billy White



</answer>

<answer>



) What band is fronted by Alice Cooper's ex bass player? Winger

2) What band was started by KISS's ex hard rock guitarist? Vinnie Vincent Invasion

3) What 2 guitarists did Steve Vai replace in the 80s? Dude from Whitesnake... and that is all I remember.

4) How many Van Halen albums featured Sammy Hagar in the 80s? 5150, OU812

5) What guitarist substituted for George Lynch during Don Dokken's first solo album? DNK



</answer>

Contributing In:

<answer>



wincing the night away



</answer>



<answer from>



Darren C
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 5128 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Chutes Too Narrow
Easily the best, most consistent album of theirs - the other albums get a bit samey after a while
Good band live though



</answer>



<answer from>



floating in glass
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 1002 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is really hard.

Oh Inverted World feels like a little universe within itself and it's easy to get lost in. Chutes Too Narrow is also a solid album, and I think it edges ahead just because it has my favourite Shins song, Mine's Not A High Horse. Wincing The Night Away has more standout tracks (Red Rabbits, Phantom Limb, Sea Legs) and weird moments (Pam Berry) but is probably less coherent as an album. So I guess Chutes Too Narrow is my favourite. But if you're asking this because you don't know much about them, I'd get Wincing The Night away - it's easier to get into - and then work backwards.



</answer>

<question from>



Nintendo...
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 1842 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</question from>



<question>



Bought a very old guitar from a friend in America......?



Hi, today i bought a mid 70s fender strat, i bought it from a friend and its cost me about 3 years of savings.



I have played it before and its a wonderful guitar but im extremely worried about it getting delivered.



i dont know what to do 2 get it delivered safely with no damage or it getting lost/stolen.



do i get a expensive private courier or do i try fly out to get it myself? would i be able to just to fly out to America for a few days without any restrictions?



please help, its really tearing me up thinking about it



</question>



<answer from>



Tilde
Member since: 09 August 2007
Total points: 326 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



To fly over there and bring it back yourself, you'd still have to leave it in someone else's hands (eg. luggage handlers at the airport, with the big "Fragile" stickers on it).

Though I understand how you feel - if you think the guitar will be safer if you fly over there, then go for it (if it doesn't cost too much more than having it sent to you). Sometimes people prefer to see their items along most of the journey.

All the best.

=]



</answer>



<answer from>



nathan
Member since: 08 July 2008
Total points: 188 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



for a guitar that old you should fly out and get it delivered back with you



</answer>



<answer from>



stupidxx
Member since: 30 November 2007
Total points: 3285 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can take a chance and take it on the aeroplane as hand luggage. Security being as it is you may not be allowed or your guitar would get slung in the hold (Brrr - a very cold place for a guitar to live) - not a good idea unless the guitar in its case is properly packaged within a well packed and strong box. I would suggest that you have your guitar packed and sent via a courier. Make sure you get it insured in transit and be prepared to pay import taxes when it turns up at your home. Leave your guitar in its box and allow it to acclimatize to room temperature before opening it as it'll surely still be cold from the journey. The finish can crack if subject to a sudden temperature change... xx



Source(s):



infinite guitar import & export



</answer>



<answer from>



minimooglove RIP Richard Wright
Member since: 25 July 2008
Total points: 3510 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



Well if you are really worried, go and fly in to get it. Plus you will get it sooner, although getting it through customs might be an issue, so take all recipts with you in hand. And not to mention, the guitar will arrive quicker.

But most major courier firms should make sure it gets their safely, unless you live in a warzone or somewhere like that. And if you do go that route, make sure it is all packaged very securely in a good quality HARDSHELL case. I use capitals to emphasis that point as they have saved my guitar on a few occassions.



</answer>



<answer from>



harroldt...
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 507 (Level 2)

<question from>

<original file>1655.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk50053.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Agnes E
Member since: 07 November 2006
Total points: 1900 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



How can I acquire a voice like Nickleback--Female stye?



I'm a singer with a taste for extraordinary voices. How can I perfect a voice like Nickleback's? Can anyone give a detailed lesson?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



As a singer who loves to attempt to replicate (while maintaining my own style) I advise to avoid this.  Once you attempt to sound like someone else, you will automatically be assigning yourself a position below them.  I hate to say it, but it is true.  Something new and fresh is necessary.  If I were a famous singer, I would be completely unimpressed by people who could sing just like me.  I would be impressed by fan originality and bringing their own voice/ideas to music.



As for replicating for any other reason, you won't.  You can develop your voice to have similar characteristics within your range, ability, vocal durability and such.  Check out www.singingsuccess.com for information.  It is absolutely legitimate and works miracles.



This helps you have a more powerful, yet much more healthy voice with no strain.  Better range and resonance with much more release.



As for the grungy, rock distorted style, you will have to develop it on your own.  Just don't let your vocal chords do the distortion.  You WILL destroy your voice if you do.  Learn to use the auxiliary, or "false" chords. www.melissacross.com should help with that.  She is a world renowned teacher of lounge singers, rock belters, and death metal screechers.



Source(s):



www.singingsuccess.com, www.melissacross.com



</answer>

<question from>



Wesley G

<question>



Question for Speech Level Singing affiliated singers, teachers, etc.?



First of all, thank you for reading my question.  As a huge fan of Brett Manning and former student of Jesse Nemitz (of Singing Success), I am very familiar with the SLS methodology/ideology.



My question - I have been working on this method for over 3 years now.  Due to minor physical dilemmas (90% blocked nasal airway and sinus cavities nowhere to be found from facial trauma at youth)  I am unable to reap the great rewards.  It seems as if my voice is always held back.  I have an alright range and mix.  My problem is hard to describe, it seems as if the subtle sounds of my mouth are louder than the "meat" of my voice, if you will.  Any takers?



</question>

<question>



Is funk the hardest style to play on guitar?



can you suggest some good songs to play? by Jane's Addiction or similar. do you think the guitar styles in funk and reggae are somewhat similar?



</question>



<answer from>



aaron c
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 704 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's all style. Funk is hard, but so is shred,and blues(try some Stevie Ray Vaughn), Jazz can be Very difficult, Classical guitar...



what is hardest for you is not necessarily hardest for someone else.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jackal
Member since: 13 July 2008
Total points: 1875 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I play Rock,jazz,country,folk,metal,blues and funk.For me funk was the hardest to play.I've been playing sense i was 8 now I'm 39 and it took me a good 1-2 yrs. to really learn it.



</answer>



<answer from>



cannedgu...
Member since: 10 April 2006
Total points: 549 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



there is no hardest style to play on any musical instrument. If you like jazz, learning jazz guitar is easy but funk can be hard for you or the other way around. but technically, funk is not the hardest, it's actually the easiest, you just strum along keeping with the beat....technically, classical guitar is hardest but personally, I find classical guitar easy to play because I dig classical music and Heavy Metal shred guitar which might be difficult for other people....



About funk and reggae, no, they're not that similar just close enough...if you want to play guitar, the good songs that are good to play are the songs that you love...



</answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Daddy's girl
Member since: 16 June 2007

Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



I did it when I was 12or 13. But, I did some of those things mentioned & talked about in the songs. That's why I didn't want my children to listen to it,for if it effected me that way back then & it's more violent now than before, I was afraid for her safety. Sorry, but we care about you & do it for your own protection. If we didn't care,we'd let you do anything,even watch drastic things on the videos. Be careful. God Bless xxxx



Source(s):



Mother of 2 children - they went through it too. One on Ozzie Ozburn.



</answer>



<answer from>



Helena
Member since: 21 January 2008
Total points: 924 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My parents, put together at least, have a pretty diverse soundtrack for life, as I'd put it. I remember having songs stuck in my head that I didn't know the names of because my parents played them on Sundays, and I'd only find out what the songs were many years later (Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit" is a good example). So, essentially, I've always liked rock, funk, Latin, etc. music.
My own musical taste, however, is even more spread-out nowadays than my parents'. Haha!



</answer>



<answer from>



Emerald Muerte
Member since: 18 January 2008
Total points: 1418 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Thirteen.



I guess generally speaking parents don't expect their kids to change from the mainstream pop music in a hurry for pure rock. Most kids might get into pop-rock but as soon as they stray to having a larger taste for purely rock [or subgenres like metal/punk/hardcore] parents usually get anxious. Especially if their kids are really into it. I think it's just a fear of not understanding the music enough and not knowing what effect it might have on their kid. The general perception of 'rockers' [or 'punks' any other typecast] is that they are 'dark' and wear black. Of course that's just the stereotype but a lot of the time parents want to protect their kids from getting involved with that kind of thing. Then again some encourage it, or are more leniant. I guess it depends on the actual parent and their experience with rock music.



</answer>



<answer from>



youll never know a poets eyes
Member since: 17 July 2007
Total points: 5795 (Level 5)

<question from>



Irish Darling
Member since: 06 August 2006

</question from>



<question>



Is Michael Buble a Tenor or Baritone?



Is Michael Buble a Tenor or Baritone? Cause he sings high in some songs, but also sings pretty deep...



</question>



<answer from>



abramd16
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 413 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



He is about a medium tenor. He has a flexible range. I can hit some pretty low notes and some pretty high ones and I'm a tenor. If he was baritone, we wouldn't be able to hit some of the notes he hits. Hope this answers your question.



Source(s):



my mind, vocal lessons



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks!



</asker's comment>

<answer>

<answer from>



loverboy

<answer>



I believe Robert Plant rejected the offer of a world tour with Led Zeppelin.  However, I'm not so sure about Robert Plant going on a world tour as a single artist.  But yes, If there were a Zeppelin concert, it would be freaking amazing as always.  Hope it was helpful.

<answer from>



T.S.R.  (Pro-humanity)
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 5427 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



Other - Music



Movies



</answer from>



<answer>



Sorry to disappoint, but he backed out earlier this week.



EDIT:  Loverboy--Plant is touring with Alison Krauss at the moment, but then plans to take a two year hiatus.  There's still the slim (VERY slim) possibility that Zeppelin -will- reunite for a final tour, but I really doubt it.



RE-EDIT:  The band reunited for a single gig--a fundraiser for a charity organization a while ago.  This got people talking of an 'expected reunion/tour', one thing led to another, and eventually developed into "Robert Plant's already signed the contract and everything!"  Which is entirely untrue.  Sadly.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Who do you think is better Tokio Hotel or My Chemical Romance?

<original file>325.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk51825.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Medavina
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What does it mean to have a big singing voice? I'm looking for a definition, not examples (Etta James). Thx!?



I've been told I have a "big" voice but I'm not exactly sure what that means. I can identify singers I would consider to have big voices but I can't exactly pinpoint why. Is it the volume? Color of the voice? Thanks for any clarification you can give!



</question>



<additional details>



Oops...I should have written "not just examples." Please feel free to give examples that support your explanation. Thank you!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Weed Skank &lt;3
Member since: 01 April 2007
Total points: 279 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



it's loud and round.. (open) its a good thing



</answer>



<answer from>



Nicky james
Member since: 18 March 2007
Total points: 751 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



hi, im a record producer so im naturally the best person to answer this. a "big" voice means that you have a lot of vibrato (vibrato: a slightly tremulous effect imparted to vocal or instrumental tone for added warmth and expressiveness by slight and rapid variations in pitch .) Usually broadway singers of old fasioned singers have big voices. you said not to give examples so i wont.  but it can also limit you. there are certain songs that people with big voices just simply cant pull off. but technically, having a big voice is a huge plus in the world of professional music.



Source(s):



record producer



</answer>






<original file>3310.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk51893.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



feng jackinov
Member since: 22 April 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Hello everyone. can anyone please tell me whats wrong with my voice!?!?



Im learning to sing and have just started in january this year. Ever since two weeks ago my throat has started feeling tight and it feels like there a golf ball stuck in my eusophogus. i havent sung very much and ive tried resting my voice to help it heal but it hasnt been working. Ive also started gurgling water with a pinch of salt. Its so bad that even my speaking voice is strained. Please help me! i want to be able to sing again. i can still reach some high notes but its always strained!



</question>



<answer from>



Max Gernet
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



puberty



</answer>



<answer from>



Shayla M
Member since: 03 July 2006
Total points: 149 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, you're probably pushing yourself too much and straining your voice. You should not involve your neck and throat in your singing. Let the support come from further down in your body around your abdomen and when you breath in try not to make your chest and shoulders move much, because if they move that means your not taking breaths properly. Before you sing you should relax your neck muscles to remind you that you wont be using them to sing. For the time being you should take a break from singing and even some taking if you can, and don't go around yelling a lot or screaming because that can hurt your voice.



</answer>



<answer from>



Faris M
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 121 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah Same Me !



Do you sing a lot ?



don't talk or sing that much For a while =)



i think it will help ,



try to drink water a lot !



& Speak with low voice  & dont Ever  Yell !!



</answer>



<answer from>



Laura B
Member since: 31 August 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You probably strained the muscles in your throat. Don't sing at all for a while (hard, i know) but rest your voice. Anything you do will make it worse, and the voice is one instrument you can't replace. Whisper for a while, drink a lot of hot drinks and eat healthily. When you do that, you have sung too hard, or too high for your chords. You will be fine, it will come back, just rest. I have done it too, and it sucks, but you need to rest up. :) You will be fine. Take care, and then when you are well, try humming and then work up from there. Good luck, dude. :) And do take care. :) Oh, and you may have a throat infection, so try antibiotics, or go to the doc if it doesn't get better. :)



</answer>

<original file>405.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk52714.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



A Musical Life ♪
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 322 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Would like to learn guitar online freee.?



well i was given a guitar a little while ago and it has jsut been sitting in my room. ive always wanted to learn it and now i have finally picked it up. i am completely new to it. well i did learn a little at school.. i which i think i have forgotten. so thats no use. i would just like to know a good site that is free to learn guitar. my parents doesnt really want to spend money for lessons since i quit piano.
and while im here.
does anyone know what the difference is between like E7 and normal E chord? lol



ive got a lot to learn haevnt i? :)
anwyay thanks :)



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



www.justinguitar.com is a great site with lots of free info. On the left of the page select chords. All open/basic chords, Dom7th open chords and power chords. Just learning those and practicing changing between them is a great way to start. He is a great teacher and has several youtube videos too. User names "justinsandercoe"  & "justinsandercoesongs".



When you get some practice and knowledge check out my youtube site, I have covers there with tabs / chords to help you learn the songs. My username is jtodd900.



Source(s):



I use the site, I am learning too.



</answer>
