<question>



What exactly is guitar shredding?



i haven't understood the term properly...



</question>



<answer from>



barry ho
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 125 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



well pretty much this



The art of Technically and rhythmatically hammering out amazing and lightning-fast solos on a guitar.
or To play so amazingly fast on guitar you almost destroy it's strings.



</answer>



<answer from>



laineywa...
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



not totaly sure on this but i think it had something to do with sliding the pic (plectrum) down the string of the guitar side ways to kinda drop the note like water going down a pipe.



Source(s):



i used to be in a band but got tired of the travel so quit and now play twelve string acoustic and when i play ,if i do that, it sounds like a shredder.



</answer>

<answer>



OK, I agree with the other poster on Kings of Leon.  They are bigger now, but still a lot of people don't know how much they rule.



I myself just looked up a Black Keys song ("I Got Mine") which is pretty sweet, so I think I'm gonna check them out some more.



As for my suggestions:
Broken Social Scene - You Forgot It in People (album) Cause = Time (song)



***RXBANDITS*** = great band.



1. The lyrics and music are just above and beyond what good music should be. Actually thought provoking and gets you moving.
2. Talk about nice guys.  I've met a few of the band members on different occasions and they are down-to-earth and sweet cool guys.
3. They play smaller venues to keep ticket prices low (i've never paid more than $25. I think the cheapest was $12).
4. Started their own record label to control their music. It's purely their sound, unfiltered. They could have gone mainstream, but they are in it for the music. Truly.  I mean, these guys look HUNGRY.



Obviously you can tell I am a huuuge fan.  I have nothing but respect for these guys and have seen them 7 times. I swear they are always touring. And they kill their live show!



check out:
Decrescendo
Recapitulation (Overcome)
Only For The Night
Crushing Destroyer
ANY SONG



Source(s):



ME!



</answer>

<answer from>

<answer>



Oh ya !! Toughie ! I do think they were a little over rated, though Nevermind was a superb album and still sounds as fresh and vital as it ever did, and the Unplugged album proved that they weren't just volume merchants ! The other albums, In Utero, Incesticide and Bleach were for most part great albums and he was a great songwriter but like many other greats he had problems with depression and drugs !!!



When first using Heroin, he was escaping his mental torment because that's what it does, it's the ultimate anaesthetic ! He'd be chasing the dragon and feeling ecstatic, but like most users he moved onto the needle and from then on it's a fast spiral downwards and you're no longer using it to escape, you're using it to try and feel "normal" !!! And unless you've experienced it or know someone who has, to a lesser extent, then you really have no idea just how hellish it is !!!  If he had lived on, there was a massive chance of him never writing anything half decent ever again unless he got totally clean and there was little chance of that partly because he was rich and could afford it very easily, partly his addictive personality and partly because of his depression !!! I believe that's exactly why he killed himself with a bullet in the brain, because there's no chance of being discovered and saved !!! Drugs and Depression can take anyone regardless of fame, fortune, class or creed, they're truly wicked !
If he had lived i think he might've been sectioned and we would probably talking about him being a wasted talent !!!
He was a great, i think, but a young death tends to make people almost mythical !!!
Still love them though and i was lucky enough to see them 3 times, the best one being an unannounced gig in a wee pub in Edinburgh after their main tour date was over .....brilliant !!!
At least his pain is over, that's the main thing...bless him x



Source(s):



itsalongstory.commie



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

The kind of popularity bands/artists like Radiohead, Beck, and Oasis now have.

<original file>6695.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk55652.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Nicholas (Manson Freak/Pro-Goat)
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 2599 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</question from>



<question>



How many rock/metal bands can you name that have druggies as members?



List as many as you can.



</question>



<answer from>



Jeff
Member since: 29 August 2006
Total points: 2625 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Other - Music



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Earth - Dylan Carlson was a drug dealer (Kurt Cobain's dealer, too)
Nirvana - See above band
Hole - According to Dylan Carlson in the documentary Kurt and Courtney, he also sold to Courtney Love
Megadeth/Metallica - Dave Mustaine had a pretty bad rough patch in his life, Cliff Burton also did cocaine somewhat often.
Lou Reed-See his song "Heroin" (actually by the Velvet Underground, but written by him)
Eric Clapton-His song Cocaine is about his drug use
Jimi Hendrix
The Beatles-Lucy In The Sky With Diamonds (LitSwD), they did LSD
David Bowie-Space Oddity and Ashes To Ashes (I think there's another one) are about "Major Tom", aka Bowie himself.
The Stooges-I read the liner notes to "Fun House" and they described the process of recording LA Blues as "we all got high... then recorded it", or something along those lines.
Grateful Dead-I heard that they also sold drugs
Neil Young-His song "The Needle And The Damage Done"
Janis Joplin
Jim Morrison of The Doors
The Rolling Stones-Brian Jones died from a drug overdose I think, and I'm pretty sure Keith and Mick have both admitted to using something.
The Who-Especially Keith Moon
Sex Pistols-As well as, I'm sure, many other punk bands



Why do I get a thumbs down?  I'm sure of every single accusation on this list, except where noted as "I think"



</answer>



<asker's comment>



/



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



sos_brig...
Member since: 02 July 2008
Total points: 2867 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Electric Wizard's fifth member is probably cannabis. Black Sabbath (particularly Ozzy) was huge on the sweet leaf too, and cocaine I think. David Bowie is well known for being a huge cocaine addict at one time. The Beatles famously took LSD. Jim Morrison was on everything and then some. I forgot what Jimi Hendrix preferred. My list is extremely far from complete.



</answer>



<answer from>



minimooglove How does it feel?
Member since: 25 July 2008
Total points: 4455 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



Depeche Mode - Dave Gahan had a pretty vicious heroin issue in the 1990's. Untill he went to kill himself and got revived, then arrested for possession.



The Clash - Topper Headon got fired for his addiction, his rehab bill was supposedly picked up by Pete Townshend



Cream - Supposedly the only gigs they never did sober were the reunion ones.



The Pretenders - Both Pete Farndon (heroin overdose) and James Honeyman-Scott (Cocaine induced heart-attack) had drug related deaths.



The Ramones - Dee Dee Ramone died of a Heroin overdose in 2002



</answer>



<answer from>



Jimmy Jazz
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 9152 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop

<original file>8365.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk57508.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Metalswo...
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 91 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Are you agree that My Chemical Romance saves people's lives?



I agree. They actually saves my live but I didn't notice that until I read about in the internet.Why do they save my live? bcoz mcr songs such as helena-realising me about death(it's sad n we should respect the departed) n cancer n also welcome 2 da black parade, the songs give me spirit to continue to live though I always lonely, sad and depressed.I have not many friends and since I know them, I feel a little happy and find some new friends.



</question>



<answer from>



Emerald Muerte
Member since: 18 January 2008
Total points: 1428 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I do hope this isn't a sarcastic question.



Music can save lives, and it can ruin them. For me, My Chemical Romance didn't literally save my life, in fact I wasn't actually on the brink of suicide when I started listening to them. I was however, really insecure about myself and I'll grant that My Chem did help me to change my value within myself in order to be who I am today.



Songs like "I'm Not Okay [I promise]" "Famous Last Words" and "Our Lady Of Sorrows" would have to be the one's with the clearest messages. One, that it's okay not to be 'okay', or not to fit in all the time. Two, everyone should believe in themselves and 'stand up ******* tall' [as Gerard says in OLOS], that's something I find very important- self-belief. And three, to be unafraid to keep on living your life regardless of the obstacles you may face in it. [the major theme in FLW.] Without my listening to those songs in particular I feel that I would not have the faith and confidence I do hold within myself at current.
So to answer your question, My Chemical Romance do not literally save lives. They don't grab the noose from around your kneck, take the blade from your wrists. No. But through their lyrics they proivde their fans with an understanding that can help them change their lives in order to become better people and to believe in themselves. So essentially they are helping kids 'save their lives' through giving them a way to change them. That's the way it works. They can believe in us and we can believe in them. The core MCRmy would agree with me.



My Chemical Romance changes lives, their true fans would acknowledge that. As for the emo crap, none of that matters. All that matters is that the fans 'Keep The Faith' through believing in MCR's lyrics and My Chem can then believe in their fans.



Source(s):



MCRmy soldier;
Keep The Faith 2008



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you very much.. god bless you. you are anice people.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Elizabeth P
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 750 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



...You need to learn how to type.  Perhaps they could teach you that too?



I do agree that some lives are saved by My Chemical Romance.  If you actually listen to the songs and what they say during interviews, their lyrics actually are very hopeful.  Also, they are good musicians and having an interest in common is a good way to meet people.  And they really aren't 'emo' as the haters say.  If they were, they wouldn't be leaving messages on their website saying not to commit suicide.



Source(s):



www.mychemicalromance.com



</answer>

DramaQue...

It's important that some bands out there don't promote cutting, suicide, depression but instead, influence a more positive outlook on life for today's youth :]

<original file>8458.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk57611.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



albertco...
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What's the best method to learn and perfect a piano piece?



Some good methods for learning a piano piece fast and getting really good at it in a short time...



</question>



<answer from>



bubble wrapping
Member since: 24 March 2007
Total points: 5593 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



oooooo I had the same problem as you a while ago where I didn't have long to learn a rather fast piece.  What I did was really just PRACTICE!  Honestly, I had about two weeks to perfect a song which would usually take me about six weeks due to other commitments and such, and so I spent about 5 hours on each weekend day and about 1.5 - 2 hours on weekdays just practising.



What you should do is break the piece into smaller sections, and practice them very slowly until you feel confident in picking up the tempo, and when you do, only do it very gradually so that you barely hear any difference in the speed.  Then when you feel confident in putting the whole piece together, do it.  That's what I did and I finally got it great :)



You might not be willing to spend as long as I did on your piece, but you should also break up your practice when you start to get frusterated (because you probably will) and go and find something relaxing to do.



If you're after perfection, remember it takes patience, dedication and practice :)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks



</asker's comment>

Entertainment & Music

</category>



<question from>



chain gang
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How long it takes to improve my singing voice?



i want to know how long of time it needs to improve the singing voice



</question>



<answer from>



Laura B
Member since: 31 August 2008
Total points: 233 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, it depends how good or capable you are now, but it takes time! Don't force it, and just stick with what sounds good for you. It will take about 1 to 2 years to get into it, to develop good vibrato and technique, and then go from then on. just remember, some of the best singers and songwriters never had singing lessons, or developed their voices. it is goodd, because you get vocal range, strength, tone quality and more, but the most important thing is heart and soul- if you have this, you will be great no matter what. Just work on breathing techniques, hum a lot to gain strength and have confidence! be happy with the gifts you have, and work from there. You will rock!! :) Good luck, dude.



Source(s):



8 years singing lessons... :)



</answer>



<answer from>



99%angel
Member since: 17 January 2006
Total points: 459 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



depends on how much you work on it..



</answer>

<question>



Guitar G-String tuning?



Im sure its not only my guitar because i have heard and seen this on other peoples guitars. But why does the G string always seem to loose its correct tuning more quicker than other strings? I hate mine, to the point where its become personal now!!! Is there some scientific reason for this to happen? something to do with wave frenquencies etc???  Does anyone else suffer from this problem and is there any kind of tweaking that can be done??



Cheers :)



</question>



<answer from>



Nat
Member since: 13 June 2007
Total points: 1623 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



hhmm interesting question...I never have problems with just the g string on my guitar...maybe take it to a music shop and get them to check it out...when was the last time you changed the strings?



</answer>



<answer from>



bradland...
Member since: 28 June 2006
Total points: 1140 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Must just be you. Make sure you stretch your strings good. Also make sure that they are properly installed at the tuning keys. Check your bridge and make sure that it is smooth in the grooves.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rossko
Member since: 29 June 2008
Total points: 260 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i hate that! it's annoying hey? that's happened with every guitar i've had for the last 15 years until i recently bought a PRS which doesn't as it has locking tuners. sorry i don't know why it happens exactly but i just wanted to reply because it's always bugged me too!
maybe get high quality tuners or something like that? good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



garbleju...
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<original file>996.html</original file>

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



watashik...
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 86 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



For all those who hold rock music dear: what feelings do you get when listening to "Stairway to Heaven"?



For me, it transports me to about 40 years before, where people could rebel all that we wanted, dress up in 'trash' and look cool: didn't care about where their lives were headed. The LZ concerts were the best part of my life, I had their posters plastered over my room when i was a kid; had all their records; wore their t-shirts with pride. Its unfortunate that there aren't any cool rockers left in the world today. Not even rockers, generally people. I miss the days where girls used to wear their one zip jeans, guys had long hair; we used to smoke and actually had a life.



</question>



<additional details>



i am feeling very nostalgic, and listening to today's music and talking to people makes me want to go back to the good old days. Someone please reminiscing something about the good days, the 70s, the best days of their lives. Share some interesting experiences from back then.



* sorry for the typos, typing very quickly.



Edit:



An interesting excerpt from a rock fan from Birmingham, UK.



"---Of course, I was one of those boys and that was the moment when I fell properly in love with Led Zeppelin. I knew about them already: my elder brother had a couple of their albums, which I'd listened to, and their music was in the ether. But this was when I realised just how good they were, how exciting, how alive.



Theirs was physical music, music that made you want to move, shake, break free, fly, and that's what we were trying to do in that musty brown front room in 1971.---"



http://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jht...



Whenever i hear the guitar riffs/solo from 4:40, i remember a day when my friends and i were driving superfast, and we almost fell off a cliff.



"flipperwaldt"



Thank you for the wonderful answer. It really pleases me to read posts like yours.



Edit:



A link to the guitar riffs/solo from the "Stairway to Heaven":



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UCZqIx0iw...



Edit:



Also, I dont see any really exciting girls these days. Many girls today dress up as sl**s (no offense), the girls from the '70s were rad as ever. They would dress up like trash, and look sumptuous. They had the most amazing hairstyles. They wore the best jackets, and torn,tight jeans. They were most of all rebellious, protesting against everything wrong in the society; having the best experiences in their lives. The girls today dont have any of that, and certainly none of the spunk that their elders had in their primes.



</additional details>



<answer from>



flipperw...
Member since: 07 August 2006
Total points: 251 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



its nice to hear from someone who lived through the 70's and the led zeppelin days. wow you actually got to go and experience those great led zeppelin concerts!! i heard stairway the first time when i was 15 and at first didn't like it much. but as i listened to more and more of it it just got better and better. and now i just can;t get enough of it. somehow every time i hear it it sounds so new. and i never get bored of it.  during the solo and outro part i would jump around playing air guitar pretending to be playing next to a great live audience.  the song also helped me to chill out and relax a bit and was one of the songs which made me take up the guitar(although its wrong to say that the guitar is the best thing in the song)



anyways sorry for the long answer and i'm sure it doesnt help answering your question but this really got me back to my good days(not to long.. just about 1 year ago).



thanks. its been great answering your question.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



excellent post!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Zach J
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 147 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



makes me feel relaxed because it has a chill guitar
when the singing happens i feel a little sad though because to me it just gives that feel to me.(probably because of the emotion robert plant puts in it when he sings it).when the clean electric guitar come in it makes me feel of back in the day before i was born. wondering about how life was when my dad was a kid. I love when the drums come in.
robert plant's rhythm in 4:20 i really like how he sang it. led zeppelin truly is a classic that's what i feel when i here this song



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music

</category>



<question from>



abood4ev...
Member since: 29 December 2006
Total points: 79 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What and how could i recored my first album ?



i'm thinking for very high goals , i want to recored an album the problem is i cant find any player for any instrument ( hoe can i find ? )  and i cant figure the steps , and after recording the album , where should i go ?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



man, thats a loaded question. well. start on craigslist looking for musicians. if you live near me id be glad to help. but what are the odds of that? you need to get into a recording studio which can be pretty expensive. and the recording studio will take care of distribution and such. look on craigslist. put up a wanted ad for someone that can record you. they can probly even supply other musicians. im a record producer which is why i know all this. i live in southern california. hope this helps. :)



Source(s):



record producer



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Favorite contemporary alternative band?

<answer from>



Holden McGroin
Member since: 08 October 2008
Total points: 268 (Level 2)

<original file>1352.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk76104.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



rickyd
Member since: 13 September 2007
Total points: 313 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Best Picking Technique?



I've been playing guitar for 3 years and I was wondering, what is the best way to hold your pick? I am looking for speed and control because my left hand is already REALLY fast.
Thank you all,
HD



</question>



<answer from>



KYLE- [In Flames We Trust]
Member since: 27 May 2007
Total points: 9024 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



This is how I hold a pick
http://www.theguitarsuite.com/images/pic...



Though if you REALLY want to challenge yourself, look up how Michael Angelo Batio holds a pick. It's insane.
http://www.angelo.com/assets/images/Live...



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qG74eVb6V...



</answer>



<answer from>



Xe7Lda
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 29 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



To hold it? Just between your thumb, and the side of your index finger... pick each string with as little movement as possible! Moving your wrist and NOT your elbow / arm, or fingers.... it helps alot with speed!



</answer>



<answer from>



Wire & String
Member since: 06 September 2007
Total points: 11079 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



finger picking- the more fingers you can pick with the more versatility you can play with.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cheska M
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 389 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



hold a pick properly...partly slanted and you can use your pinky (place it below the e string)  as a guide by leaving it up and all the other fingers down except for the pinky and 1st 2 fingers holding the pick so when you pluck..you will have a less tendency to pluck wrong strings..this can help because the pinky will serve as your guide because as you pluck a certain string you will feel them getting lower or higher other strings when it is close to the pinky



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



q_dog385
Member since: 04 October 2008
Total points: 288 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Electric bass help please?



Hello, Ive ben playing on an electric bass, and about every 1/4 time I hit the low E string, the string hits the pickup and makes a popping noise. Is there a fix to this, am I just hitting the string to hard, and is it bad for the bass



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I wonder if the neck could be warped a bit backward and need adjusting, but then you'd probably notice trouble tuning.  Or whether you could replace the bridge to raise the strings, but then that would throw off tuning a tiny bit.  I don't know if the string hitting the pickup is going to do any damage or not.



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music

<question from>



someidio...
Member since: 26 May 2008
Total points: 257 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What are some jazz stereotypes?



please help i need this for school



</question>



<answer from>



Phil Inhere
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 150 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



1. That Jazz musicians are born with talent instead of having earned from countless years of practice.
2. That Jazz is "made up". If a jazzer doesn't know what he is about to play he is "fakin' it" jazz is just memorized melodies sung on an instrument.
3. That Jazz sucks, which it doesn't.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thnx it  was really informative



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



St Petersburg native
Member since: 17 March 2008
Total points: 3436 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Many of the responses can be simplified to the notion known as the "noble savage" which I've heard Wynton Marsalis use in rants decrying the accusations of moral depravity as contrasted with cultural achievements among jazz musicians.



Speaking of cultural achievements, I find it ironic that Swing-era musicians such as Louis Armstrong and Benny Goodman were among the vanguard of integration in the United States, yet the adverse bi-lateral racism that Jazzriff references is sadly true. Why must some musicians taint the art form which is a buffet for the ears with such ultimately meaningless observations based in the sense of sight? For me one of the most beautiful things in musician culture is acceptance based on one's musical output rather than on one's age, gender, race, politics, or even personality (for example, I have nothing but reverence for the music of Stan Getz in spite of the fact that he thumped on all three of his wives; read the Donald Maggin book "Stan Getz: My Life in Jazz" for corroboration).



Source(s):



Read up on the historic perspective of the noble savage at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noble_savag...



</answer>



<answer from>



Sky H
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 1726 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



A common stereotype is that you need to be hooked up in some heavy substance to be a good jazz musician.



A large number of pot heads in jazz were mediocre to lousy musicians. While Duke Ellington -my all time favorite- was clean, and not only that. he had to deal with a bunch of druggies in his orchestra and managed to make them sound as the tightest unit ever.



</answer>



<answer from>



memedoub...
Member since: 21 September 2008
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you have to have a really strange view on everything
you play sax
you don't like classical
you are secretly implying sexual things in your playing
you cant do anything else
weed grows out of your horn



</answer>

Jazzriff
Member since: 31 July 2007
Total points: 197 (Level 1)

<question from>

<question>



Does anyone know a good jazz artist?



I'm new to it, so I don't know anything. Any recommendations for bands or anything?



</question>



<additional details>



preferably someone that uses a jazz guitar



</additional details>



<answer from>



Johnny Hammond
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 483 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Grant Green.



Anything on the Blue Note label from 1955-1968.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



This is exactly what I'm looking for. thanks a lot!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



sodakian...
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 707 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OuCXJlfeq...



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rgyHqJ4U1...



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oqf6xuOp2...



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-U5fbCEgm...



The first link is Medeski, Martin & Wood (MMW).  They don't have a guitar but the organ player (Medeski) is renowned as one of the best in the world.  They are a much more modern jazz.  Great stuff.  The second link is MMW with John Scofield.  Scofield used to play with Miles Davis.  He has since put out many great solo albums.  The third link is a band called Soulive.  I'm not sure of the guitarists name, but they're an awesome band.  The fourth link is Greyboy Allstars.  They are more of a groove based jazz, but damn, those guys are good.  If you like these bands send me an email and I can recommend many more great jazz bands.  Enjoy!



</answer>



<answer from>



Sky H
Member since: 24 April 2008
Total points: 1726 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Duke Ellington.



It's not guitar based music (there are rhythm guitars here and there), but it's simply the best jazz ever written. Worth the try.



</answer>



<answer from>



Vm
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 449 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<category>



Entertainment & Music

</category>



<question from>



Lolgalz (Dizzywood name)
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the opposite of the bass in a song?



</question>



<answer from>



Danny R
Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 3168 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bass and treble are the tonal extremes, but if you're referrring to the bass line or instrument, the opposite will depend on which instruments are used. It could be a picolo or a synthesiser. A Guitar harmonic or a crash cymbal.



</answer>



<answer from>



chaoticf...
Member since: 08 March 2008
Total points: 471 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



probably treble



</answer>



<answer from>



angelwit...
Member since: 20 June 2006
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



well if your talking about like the bass like on a staff then it would be treble. if your talking about what instrument is opposite from the bass it would be lead guitar. maybe rhythm guitar



</answer>

<question>



Paramores best album?

Which album is better,
All we know is falling
or
Riot!



?



</question>



<answer from>



Holden McGroin
Member since: 08 October 2008
Total points: 268 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



Maid_Mar...
Member since: 20 January 2007
Total points: 3683 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lol.
It's hard to tell because they are both good but sooo different.
I used to be such a massive Paramore fan but I don't know, I kind of went off them.
I'd love to say All We Know Is Falling because they were less commercialised then, but I actually can't decide because I think half of the records off Riot! were awesome but then again half from AWKIF are amazing too.



They are both different stages of Paramore's development so I can't chose. XD



</answer>



<answer from>



Mimie-2

</answer from>



<answer>



I think the Riot! album is better, but i do like the song "Emergency" from All We Know is Falling. I Love Paramore too!! i have their videos on my ipod and my BFF tells me its all I listen to...i've never seen them in concert though. :( oh well.. hope that helps you out.

-Mimie

<answer from>



Cheska M
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 395 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Riot! ...this album brought them to the top



</answer>



<answer from>



Christine N
Member since: 19 April 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



They're both amazing. Personally I think Hayley's voice has a lot more emotion to it in All We Know Is Falling, and it's more of a helpless edge to the album, like All We Know Is Falling really captures the genesis of the band, like when their bassist left and they didn't know how to deal with that, they didn't know if they were gonna make it as a band. It really captures the youthful stage of the band and makes you realise they were just a group of teenagers who made it big, and how much that scared them. It starts with "All We Know" being the first track on the album, how scared they were, and ends with "My Heart", which I think is a song about putting their trust in God and Fate and letting the chips fall where they may, it's a great album with a lot of emotion behind it.



Riot! is exactly that. It's Paramore standing up, and saying they know they're gonna make it now. Riot! is aptly named. It's an explosion of the colour and power and strength that Paramore held back in the helplessness of the first album. While All We Know Is Falling is about questions, Riot! is about having the answers and having confidence, enough so to scream the word RIOT! and know, in their hearts, that they are gonna make it. It's a great album.



The very best of luck to you



xxx



</answer>



<answer from>



FueledB...
Member since: 27 April 2007
Total points: 202 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<question from>



scattere...
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 149 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What Pink Floyd was better?



Not many people notice this but there is considered to be three different stages of Pink Floyd.



They are:



Syd Barrett, Roger Waters, Richard Wright, and Nick Mason (1965-1968) Albums: The Piper at the gates of Dawn,A Saucerful of Secrets&lt;3



Roger Waters, David Gilmour, Richard Wright, Nick Mason (1971-1983)
Albums: Meddle, Obscured by Clouds, The Dark Side of The Moon, Wish You Were Here, Animals&lt;3, The Wall&lt;33, The Final Cut (OH G&lt;3D)



David Gilmour, Nick Mason,Richard Wright (1987-1994) Albums:
A Momentary Lapse of Reason&lt;31/2, The Division Bell&lt;3



Out of those eras which one do you like the most? What albums out of that era do you like the most? Whats your favorite songs on them?



!!!TUNE IN, TURN ON, DROP OUT!!!



</question>



<answer from>



ben_of_m...
Member since: 04 April 2006
Total points: 16071 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



"Momentary Lapse of Reason" was my favorite album, so I'd have to go with Gilmour, Mason, and Wright.



</answer>



<answer from>



Darth 2.0
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 557 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This was by far, Floyd's best Lineup and Era



Roger Waters, David Gilmour, Richard Wright, Nick Mason (1971-1983)
Albums: Meddle, Obscured by Clouds, The Dark Side of The Moon, Wish You Were Here, The Wall



Actually Rick Wright wasn't on The Final Cut



This version of Floyd, all together, all contributing was the best to me. And made almost all their best albums.



</answer>



<answer from>



bleed_th...
Member since: 24 July 2006
Total points: 355 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



71-83 years is the best



</answer>



<answer from>



Peace Frog☮
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 3894 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well I LOVE all of Pink Floyd's stuff, but I think my favorite was the second Pink Floyd. I absolutely loved Syd Barrett, but you can't beat albums like The Wall, Dark Side of the Moon, and Wish You Were Here.



</answer>



<answer from>



Geri9394...
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 6420 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would be really hard-pressed to narrow it down to only one, but I think the era of 71-83 would have to be my favorite.  Dark Side of The Moon is so incredible.  But then again, so is The Wall.  I don't think anyone has every made better music than Pink Floyd.



</answer>



<answer from>



Da Gonzo Man Can
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 93 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am biased here...  Always liked Syd, and what the band did to him (not picking him up for a gig and then firing him during a mental break down) was low and lame.  Syd's Floyd was more playful musically - and not as depressing as Water's or Gilmours version.



I do like Water's - Dark Side, Wish You Were Here and The Wall are classics - but due to radio - they have been oevr played!



Gilmour's floyd was ok - liked Division Bell - though most critics didn't like it.  But those who can't play are critics.



So, for me,  give me Syd Barrett's Pink Floyd.  Or his solo work is also nice, weird, and catchy!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jacob C
Member since: 14 December 2007
Total points: 351 (Level 2)



</answer from>

Albums: Meddle, Obscured by Clouds, The Dark Side of The Moon, Wish You Were Here, Animals&lt;3, The Wall&lt;33, The Final Cut (OH G&lt;3D)



ALL DAY

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Amber B.
Member since: 04 March 2008
Total points: 174 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Where to find cover songs?



Does anyone know where I can find cover songs? like, songs that doesn't have singing in it so i can record over it?



thanks in advance!



</question>



<additional details>



ps. are these kinds of songs just called cover songs? i'm not exactly use what they are called...



</additional details>



<answer from>



Zena Tonks
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lots of places like Best Buy and others



</answer>



<answer from>



MLUV80
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can try iTunes for some karaoke version or instrumental versions of popular songs. You can also try a local music store. But it can't be just any one though. Maybe a music store that you know sells karaoke or instrumental versions of songs.



BTW, cover songs are songs that are sung by another person other than the original artist who sung it. For example, Joss Stone did a cover version of The White Stripes "Fell in Love with a Girl" but is Joss's case "Fell in love with a Boy" The White Stripes is the original singer of the song...



</answer>

<question from>



Leon D
Member since: 06 December 2006
Total points: 2 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What Is The Song Hysteria By Def Leppard About?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It's about the drummer Rick Allen and the many things going on in the aftermath of his car accident that took his arm. They also named the album after it.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hysteria_(D...



</answer>

Entertainment & Music

<question from>



hobohunt...
Member since: 04 May 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What kind of horn players do i need for a ska band that plays stuff like reel big fish and less than jake?



</question>



<answer from>



Rorie
Member since: 12 October 2008
Total points: 665 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Looks like, as far as horns, you need trumpet(s), trombone(s) and maybe a saxophone.  Here's a list of all the instruments each band uses:



Reel Big Fish-
Guitar
Vocals
Trumpet
Bass
Trombone
Drums



Less Than Jake-
Vocals
Guitar
Bassist
Saxophone
Trombone
Drums



Hope that helped :)



Source(s):



http://wiki.fuse.tv/page/Reel+Big+Fish?t...
http://www.lessthanjake.com/about/



</answer>



<answer from>



Sarah W
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



try to get song here http://westsounds.com



</answer>



<answer from>



EddieX
Member since: 15 May 2006
Total points: 3220 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Everything rorie said plus an organ, Im a big ska fan, I remember they used organs



</answer>

http://www.playlist.com/results.php?site...



</answer>

<question from>



Dragonfl...
Member since: 30 July 2008

</question from>



<question>



Question about transition from ragtime to jazz?



What are the *FIVE* main events that happened in 1917 that showed and end to 'ragtime' era and beginning of 'jazz' era?



thanks.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



ragtime is a genre,jazz isn't



jazz is a group of musicians improvising without breaking the rules of the music theory.
rag time is a genre.



</answer>

"""I've been searching myself for the entire soundtrack to MotoGP via the songs listed in the credits on the Internet
, and have found over half of them but have hit a glass ceiling. Taking an educated guess, I'd say the menu theme and the one featured on the credits are both by Thrumm, but that notion's based purely on the fact that I found a single damn thing about them anywhere. Here's a list of songs it could be (Ones I've failed to find):



Chad Jackson - Scum Dogs
Teruishi Nagatomi - Confusion
Nathan Cross - 10 Dollar
Andy Brookes - Sucker Punch
Richard Alter - Feel
James Dexter (a.k.a. DJ Dex) - Move With It
Mark Crew - Pump
??? - New Formula (Forgotten the artist, sorry)
Thrumm - Grind Control
Thrumm - Humanic



One of the songs I'm looking for is amongst them. It's got a banging saw-cut bassline, driving beat and has a female vocal in the last half. There is a deep male vocal that speaks but I can't make out what he says except for at the end of the song, when he says "on and on and on..." followed by two bleeps. If anyone can give me the title, or even figure out what he's saying it would be a big help.""""

blunt$ to my dome

<answer>



Rudyard Kipling
If
If you can keep your head when all about you



Are losing theirs and blaming it on you;



If you can trust yourself when all men doubt you,



But make allowance for their doubting too;



If you can wait and not be tired by waiting,



Or, being lied about, don't deal in lies,



Or, being hated, don't give way to hating,



And yet don't look too good, nor talk too wise;



If you can dream - and not make dreams your master;



If you can think - and not make thoughts your aim;



If you can meet with triumph and disaster



And treat those two imposters just the same;



If you can bear to hear the truth you've spoken



Twisted by knaves to make a trap for fools,



Or watch the things you gave your life to broken,



And stoop and build 'em up with wornout tools;



If you can make one heap of all your winnings



And risk it on one turn of pitch-and-toss,



And lose, and start again at your beginnings



And never breath a word about your loss;



If you can force your heart and nerve and sinew



To serve your turn long after they are gone,



And so hold on when there is nothing in you



Except the Will which says to them: "Hold on";



If you can talk with crowds and keep your virtue,



Or walk with kings - nor lose the common touch;



If neither foes nor loving friends can hurt you;



If all men count with you, but none too much;



If you can fill the unforgiving minute



With sixty seconds' worth of distance run -



Yours is the Earth and everything that's in it,



And - which is more - you'll be a Man my son!



</answer>



<answer from>



Elanshaw
Member since: 20 January 2007
Total points: 37773 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



I read poetry sometimes..I like Edgar Allan Poe's poems..



But this poem is my favourite:



Walter de la Mare
"The Listeners"



‘IS there anybody there?’ said the Traveller,
Knocking on the moonlit door;
And his horse in the silence champ’d the grasses



Of the forest’s ferny floor:
And a bird flew up out of the turret,



Above the Traveller’s head:
And he smote upon the door again a second time;



‘Is there anybody there?’ he said.
But no one descended to the Traveller;



No head from the leaf-fringed sill
Lean’d over and look’d into his grey eyes,



Where he stood perplex’d and still.
But only a host of phantom listeners



That dwelt in the lone house then
Stood listening in the quiet of the moonlight



To that voice from the world of men:
Stood thronging the faint moonbeams on the dark stair,



That goes down to the empty hall,
Hearkening in an air stirr’d and shaken



By the lonely Traveller’s call.
And he felt in his heart their strangeness,



Their stillness answering his cry,
While his horse moved, cropping the dark turf,



’Neath the starr’d and leafy sky;
For he suddenly smote on the door, even



Louder, and lifted his head:—
’Tell them I came, and no one answer’d,



’That I kept my word,’ he said.
Never the least stir made the listeners,



Though every word he spake
Fell echoing through the shadowiness of the still house



From the one man left awake:
Ay, they heard his foot upon the stirrup,



And the sound of iron on stone,
And how the silence surged softly backward,



When the plunging hoofs were gone.



</answer>

<answer from>



nitesead the giant hobbit
Member since: 31 December 2007

</answer from>



<answer>



I love poetry.  I'm learning a lot about poetics in a class right now, and it's blowing my mind.  Good poetry is extremely difficult to write, and most folks are not very adept at reading it.  I'm finding out how poor a reader I am.  But I love language, and the best way to read a poem is out loud, to really get the music of it.  It's a lot more subtle than what's usually in rap, and more complicated in meaning.



So count me in as a major poetry fan.  My personal favorite is Robert Frost's "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening."  And there's a brilliant one by e.e. cummings that reminds me of presidential campaigns, called "next to of course god america i."



Source(s):



http://www.ketzle.com/frost/snowyeve.htm



http://www.cs.rice.edu/~ssiyer/minstrels...



</answer>



<answer from>

Total points: 3940 (Level 4)

<answer>



Good Morning Bonnie



I read it and write it.  Nothing wrong with poetry.  Chuck, suck a left one.



My favorite poem...
If You Forget Me by Pablo Neruda



want you to know
one thing.



You know how this is:
if I look
at the crystal moon, at the red branch
of the slow autumn at my window,
if I touch
near the fire
the impalpable ash
or the wrinkled body of the log,
everything carries me to you,
as if everything that exists,
aromas, light, metals,
were little boats
that sail
toward those isles of yours that wait for me.



Well, now,
if little by little you stop loving me
I shall stop loving you little by little.



If suddenly
you forget me
do not look for me,
for I shall already have forgotten you.



If you think it long and mad,
the wind of banners
that passes through my life,
and you decide
to leave me at the shore
of the heart where I have roots,
remember
that on that day,
at that hour,
I shall lift my arms
and my roots will set off
to seek another land.



But
if each day,
each hour,
you feel that you are destined for me
with implacable sweetness,
if each day a flower
climbs up to your lips to seek me,
ah my love, ah my own,
in me all that fire is repeated,
in me nothing is extinguished or forgotten,
my love feeds on your love, beloved,
and as long as you live it will be in your arms
without leaving mine



</answer>

<answer>



My old man's a white old man



And my old mother's black.



If ever I cursed my white old man



I take my curses back.



If ever I cursed my black old mother



And wished she were in hell,



I'm sorry for that evil wish



And now I wish her well.



My old man died in a fine big house.



My ma died in a shack.



I wonder where I'm going to die,



Being neither white nor black?



-Langston Hughes



</answer>

<answer>



rap, that is well constructed and delivered is really cool.. sry, i dont do poetry becauce i have to read it, and i usually dont get it all when i do that.. whereas rap is delivered to me, packaged like, and by the writer who spends lots of time on emphasis and timing.



a well placed rap tune can do wonders for me.. it goes in and makes a difference...



its not all retards attempting poetry... and mostly done by kids with serious things to say about life... who are commited to what they do.



we run a mobile stage and rapfactor.co.uk where we give an outlet to young rappers.. and we constantly get people who think they dont like rap saying things like ''actually its really good''.... some rap is bad coz of the content and that can spoil it for the rest of the bois out there..



we find that once we have a stage up and running, and its flowing then rap is a real powerful tool for putting a message across.. we just think somtimes that the major pumpers of rap dont do it the justice it deserves and will pump negative out because it sells...



there are some really good,young commited poets out there.



check out cstrikez on myspace..  his rap is clean. and he can also do a serious street poetry set, which has the audience hanging on to his every word...



we will be doing more with rapfactor next year.. look out for us..



rapfactor is run by www.dropzonestage.com in the uk.......



</answer>

<answer>



To Be In Love



To be in love



Is to touch with a lighter hand.



In yourself you stretch, you are well.



You look at things



Through his eyes.



A cardinal is red.



A sky is blue.



Suddenly you know he knows too.



He is not there but



You know you are tasting together



The winter, or a light spring weather.



His hand to take your hand is overmuch.



Too much to bear.



You cannot look in his eyes



Because your pulse must not say



What must not be said.



When he



Shuts a door-



Is not there_



Your arms are water.



And you are free



With a ghastly freedom.



You are the beautiful half



Of a golden hurt.



You remember and covet his mouth



To touch, to whisper on.



Oh when to declare



Is certain Death!



Oh when to apprize



Is to mesmerize,



To see fall down, the Column of Gold,



Into the commonest ash.



Gwendolyn Brooks



</answer>

<answer>



Yeah I love poetry I even have a few original pieces to my name. Some of my favourite poets are Seamus Heaney, John Keats, Shakespeare, John Argard, Chinua Achebe and many others. My favourite poem is Footprints in the sand by Mary Stevenson. (see below)



One night a man had a dream. He dreamed



he was walking along the beach with the LORD.



Across the sky flashed scenes from his life.
For each scene he noticed two sets of
footprints in the sand: one belonging
to him, and the other to the LORD.



When the last scene of his life flashed before him,
he looked back at the footprints in the sand.



He noticed that many times along the path of
his life there was only one set of footprints.



He also noticed that it happened at the very
lowest and saddest times in his life.



This really bothered him and he
questioned the LORD about it:



"LORD, you said that once I decided to follow
you, you'd walk with me all the way.
But I have noticed that during the most
troublesome times in my life,
there is only one set of footprints.
I don't understand why when
I needed you most you would leave me."



The LORD replied:



"My son, my precious child,
I love you and I would never leave you.
During your times of trial and suffering,
when you see only one set of footprints,
it was then that I carried you."



</answer>

Say Cheese



Gorgonzola
Cambazola
Happy snappers
Sandwich wrappers
Parmesan
Vacherin
Week old socks
Unwashed cocks
All these
Say cheese

who cut other people open like cantaloupes [SLURP]

then there's no reason that a man and another man can't elope

please stand up, please stand up?

so I can sit next to Carson Daly and Fred Durst

and show the whole world how you gave Eminem VD [AHHH!]

so I have been sent here to destroy you [bzzzt]
And there's a million of us just like me
who cuss like me; who just don't give a **** like me
who dress like me; walk, talk and act like me
and just might be the next best thing but not quite me!

things you joke about with your friends inside your living room

and whether you like to admit it [*ERR*] I just **** it

<question>



To all my Musician R&Pers!! Have you experienced this?



Mainly guitar players for the most part.  Have you ever stumbled into Guitar Center or your local music shop to make that purchase?  You know when you decide it's time for a new amp or guitar or anything.



You enter and soon find that there is a young tween who has discovered the greatness of guitar.  In my book thats great... everyone should learn to play.  The only problem is this!



Have you been in there and soon realized that this "person" has learned one riff!  Possibly a blink 182 song or nirvana or whatever else these young kids listen to now a days, and they have the amp turned to "11" and have the worst tone in the world?



It may just be me, but when i go in to try an instrument out, i keep it at a personal volume.  I dont want others to hear me.  I have been playing since eight and cant stand going in there and blasting music... it may just be me..  have an opinion R&Pers?



MQ:Best guitar in your opinion?



</question>



<additional details>



Shredder: I agree. In my opinion there is always more to learn on guitar.  I am extremely humble and not cocky at all.  I go into the store sometimes and learn new things.  I have been into fusion jazz lately and my hands have been basically cramping.. haha  but this old man taught me a cool trick.. so i am always ready to learn and teach!



</additional details>

<answer>



Yes, just about every time that I've been to Guitar Center it's like that.  Of course you have to play with the amp settings and guitar settings, or even pedal settings to get a good tone--and that usually takes a little time.  PLEASE, take the time!  Good tone is worth it.



I went into a Guitar Center a few months ago and went CRAZY with a Deluxe Memory Man plugged into two amps.  I played with it for about half an hour and had a blast.  I think the workers were getting tired of it though.



That same day I walked back into the room where they have the keyboards and synths and saw some (obviously stoned) dude playing the same stupid riff on the keyboard over and over for about 15 minutes--NO EXAGERATING!  It was hilarious.



My fave guitar is either a Jaguar or a Jazzmaster.

<original file>641.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk81486.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Mojo
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why did Jet Harris and then Tony Meehan leave the Shadows?



always wondered why



</question>



<additional details>



please dont say they went solo - I know that or the records they did together.



</additional details>



<answer from>



vinnieF
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 924 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



They decided to quit separately. Tony Meehan  (drummer) left in 1961, planning to become an A & R guy with Decca. Jet Harris left in 1962, encouraged by the success of Duane Eddy as a solo guitarist.
He had a couple of minor hits on his own, but found the tramnsition from playing bass with The Shadows to playing lead on his own quite tricky, so when a partnership with Tony was suggested, he was all in favour.
After three major hits, Harris was involved in a serious car accident which left him unable to play, so Meehan formed the Tony Meehan Combo, and continued in that direction for a while before going back to A & R. Sadly he died in an accident at home three years ago.
Harris did go back to playing eventually, but the whole scene had changed, and he never re-captured that early success. He can still be found on some of the 60s nostalgia tours.
If you're interested in 60s music, check out www.thevinylfrontier.net and tune in on line on Sunday evenings.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Very knowlegeable Mister.  I could never quite understand why Jet thought going solo as a bass player was a good idea.
I believe he had a fear of flying (may have read somewhere) which didnt help with touring.  Was dating Billie Davis at the time of his accident.



Jet still has his own website.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



sunny
Member since: 01 March 2007
Total points: 10159 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Im not sure with out reading up about it but i think they were together
for about 20 years i could be wrong, most of that time they were the backing band for Cliff Richard
You will find that after 20 years of playing they probably decide there was more to life and got fed up with it&gt; i dont think there were ever any major fall outs with one another.
Hank ? i forgotten his surname the lead guitarist now lives here in Australia he has done for many a year



Source(s):



old lover of the shadows and Cliff



</answer>



<answer from>



A Kiosk of Sorts

<answer>



Well, i'm a big Gazette fan myself xD
But i only discovered them on their 2007-2008 album: STACKED RUBBISH.



So.. i'll give you the old ones for now which are from 2006, i'm guessing?~
-Sugar Pain 5/5
-Kare Uta 5/5
-Miseinen 3.5/5
-Tokyo Shinjuu 3.5/5
-Nausea & Shudder 3/5
-Silly God Disco 6/5 xD~ it's so good.
-Cassis 4/5



Here are the ones from STACKED RUBBISH:
-AGONY 5/5
-CALM ENVY 4/5
-Flith in the Beauty 3.5/5
-Regret 2.5/5
-GENTLE LIE 3/5
(their are more)



Here are the ones from the Guren single (which are also in the STACKED RUBBISH album):
-Guren 6/5! I loving this song like no tomorrow.
-Kugutsu-e 5/5
-Kyomu no Owari Hakozume no Mokuji 5/5



Here are the ones from their new single (Released in November) LEECH:
-LEECH 5/5 (Pv & Song is on YouTube)
-Distorted Daytime 5/5 (You can find Distorted Daytime on my imeem. Just search it up with the Music tab)
-HOLE (haven't listened to it yet)



^The ones listed are all my favourites. The GazettE has very powerful and meaningful songs because Ruki (vocalist and my most beloved person haha) is a master at writing lyrics. I suggest you give them a second chance. But, sometimes, we don't end up liking them, so switch to another group :)



EDIT: I'll rate it out of 5 so, you'll probably might listen to them first haha.



</answer>

<question>



R&P: Have a question for you peeps?



What bands do you consider Screamo out of this list



Underoath

Atreyu
Four Letter Lie

From first To Last
The Almost

<additional details>



Sweet Kyle...you got it right...except I think underoath fits into metalcore a well



sweet ye..I did consider them to be screamo up until Sonny left...now they are more alternative rock

<answer from>



KYLE- [In Flames We Trust]
Member since: 27 May 2007
Total points: 8546 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A Static Lullaby
From First to Last



that's it



Underoath is post-hardcore i think, Atreyu is metalcore, never heard of Four Letter Lie, Aiden I guess could be screamo, The Almost is just alt rock, RJA is alt rock, Machinemade God and Opeth are far from screamo.



Source(s):



Yeah FFAF I used to listen to a lot of these bands back before I started into metal. From First to Last was one of my favorite bands actually, and my AIM sn had FFTL in it a long while ago. I think I called them post-hardcore back in the day as well, though their first album Aesthetic basically was screamo.



</answer>

<answer from>



nick_duf...
Member since: 21 August 2007
Total points: 69 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dragonette: Check out their their first single "I Get Around". If you like Katy Perry then you'd probably enjoy this. Its pop with a bit of an "electro" edge. Very catchy, and you will become obsessed with it :)



Annie: She's a pop singer from the UK and has made some of the best/catchiest pop songs ever, in my opinion. Her single "Chewing Gum" should give you a good indication of wat she's about.



The Veronicas: Again a pop band, but with a punkish edge. Check out their recent song "Hook Me Up". It's very good.



Hope you like these songs :)



</answer>



<answer from>



PradaGrl
Member since: 13 May 2008
Total points: 197 (Level 1)

<answer from>



EM POWERED
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 171 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I consider "Stairway to Heaven" to be the defining song of classic rock. As the absolute best, I don't know. It's pretty good... but I think it's overated.



"Smells like Teen Spirit" is the definitive grunge song. You can argue all you want about how commercialized Nirvana is for a grunge band, but I think that song is by far the most popular and still has a lot of the grunge spirit in it.



</answer>

<question>



Fairly recent hard rock song?



The singer has a gravely voice. It's a recent (within the last 3 years mabye) hard rock or alternative song.



The chorus is some combination of the following:



"nice to meet you.. .. ..good to know me"



-OR-



"good to mee tyou.. .. ..nice to know me"



There are about six guitar riffs in between the two sets of lyrics. Each set of two riffs is seperate by a quick pause. I tried to show it with the



periods above.



Hope someone can make sense of what I'm trying to say!



;)



</question>

</question from>



<question>



To all my dear R&P buds who feel they were born a generation too late : )?



(and I know there are a lot of you) My friend just played this song for me while on the way back from school. I'm not sure if I like the song yet, but the lyrics really hit me, although I do not get the flower part, because a punk back in the 70's would have been beat up for that... ah, well, anyway, have a listen if you like, or just read if you want : )



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vc2jDz6w-...



Oh I wish I was a punk rocker with flowers in my hair
In 77 and 69 revolution was in the air
I was born too late into a world that doesn't care
Oh I wish I was a punk rocker with flowers in my hair



When the head of state didn't play guitar,
Not everybody drove a car,
When music really mattered and when radio was king,
When accountants didn't have control
And the media couldn't buy your soul
And computers were still scary and we didn't know everything



When pop-stars still remained a myth
And ignorance could still be bliss
And when God Saved the Queen she turned a whiter shade of pale
When my mom and dad were in their teens
And anarchy was still a dream
And the only way to stay in touch was a letter in the mail



When record shops were still on top
And vinyl was all that they stocked
And the super info highway was still drifting out in space
Kids were wearing hand me downs,
And playing games meant kick around
And footballers still had long hair and dirt across their face



I was born too late to a world that doesn't care
Oh I wish I was a punk rocker with flowers in my hair



</question>



<additional details>



IDK if that link works, so here is another...



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TEzd58SfO...



Ha ha, i guess I'm late on hearing the song, today was my first time, I just like the lyrics, really...



</additional details>

Peace Frog☮
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 3298 (Level 4)

<original file>701.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk83034.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Abdul Kadir R
Member since: 09 November 2007
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Hi,i want to download the song BEBO from the album monkey business(black eyed pea) from where would i get it?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Dont waste your time looking for it in webpages! Download it directly from Ares or Limewire or mIRC. Download any of these programs and just search for the song. If you get mIRC, make sure to connect onto the "undernet" server and go into #mp3passion there you will find any song.



Source(s):



Experience downloading



</answer>

<answer from>



karlr888
Member since: 23 October 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



In your music library there should be a tab to sort music by Album.  ctr-H should also open up a browser which you can view by album.



</answer>



<answer from>



Vampire Princess
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 3390 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



This can be kind of tricky, okay?



Double click on each song, and click the tabs on the top of that box until you see one with the album name and song name and track number (it's usually what you see first, but just in case).



Clear out all the info. I'm not kidding, because if you downloaded them from different places even if you put all the tracks in order they could still be out of order if one has disk number and one doesn't, or any other additional information.



Then just put in the song, artist, and album, and put ___ out of ___ in the track number part. Do this for each of the songs, making sure the second number is the same in each of them. Add additional information if you want but make sure it's the exact same on all the songs or they'll go out of order again!



Source(s):



I do this all the time in iTunes.



</answer>



<answer from>



fighter of foo
Member since: 18 November 2007
Total points: 1833 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's really not complicated at all. You dont have to clear anything, you dont have to change anything.



1) right click on the song



2)go to "get info", (on the right near



the middle it should say "track number _ of _ ")



3) make it the track number you want



4) hit "ok".



do that with the rest of them. It should save it for you.



see? i told you it was simple.
:]



</answer>

<question from>



viajando :)
Member since: 17 March 2007

</question from>



<question>



This is so irritating, how to get a song out of my head...?



Fidelity by Regina Spektor has been playing non stop inside my head for the past 3 days...



http://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=SGTDRztaCC...
perhaps it will stick to your head and leave me alone :P



How do you get a song out of your head?



</question>



<answer from>



thy-sun-...
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 217 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Just listen to it again until it finishes and perhaps sing along with it as well?



That's my suggestion, always worked with me =)



Good luck! ^^



</answer>



<asker's comment>



ok, I will try :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



brien
Member since: 15 February 2007
Total points: 156 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



NO, DON'T LISTEN TO THEM!



The BEST way to get a song out of your head is to LISTEN TO IT!



The reason it gets stuck in your head is because there's a part that repeats.  You're not getting past it in your head, you're just repeating it.



If you go and actually listen to the song, it will finish, on your player AND in your head!



THEN listen to something else.  Seriously, this works better than anything else.



</answer>



<answer from>



Irene G
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



listen to another song over and over again! something you like!



</answer>

<original file>10664.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk84044.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



21 RaFael [♥ Man Utd]
Member since: 05 February 2007
Total points: 6332 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



How do i use a digital guitar tuner?



I just a bought a electric guitar and i am a newbie... i don't know how to use it to tune..the instruction manual is nothing much of a help.



please help me... it is a cherub wst-520gb



then there are 3 light buttons on top



and



1 button for item/flat
and another called CALIB



a hole for input and output and where should i connect my guitar to?



</question>



<answer from>



Jason A
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 179 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you have an electric guitar you will need to have 2 wires. hook up the wire that is plugged in to your guitar to the input. get the other wire and plug it in to output on your tuner and also plug it in to your amp.
the red lights means it's too deep or too high of a pitch so if it goes to the left it's too high and if it goes to the right it's too deep so just keep trying to get it on the green light. GOOD LUCK



</answer>



<answer from>



chandan
Member since: 08 January 2008
Total points: 2209 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



music tool-



http://mymusictool.info/



</answer>

<question>



What do you think about bands doing side projects?



i hate it i think it takes away from the band, they could use the material they are writ ting for the side project to make the band even better

<answer>



We are not to criticize what they do.however i don't like bands doing side projects.side projects are wastage of time and the band members are not so dedicated to their own band,it also shows their insecureness because having a side project makes others think that the band members are not having into a solid relationship and that they could break up anytime



</answer>



<answer from>



David Brent
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree.My favourite band is Pantera & one of the reasons they broke up was the fact that all Phil Anselmo's side projects (Down, Superjoint Ritual) was creating tension between himself and the rest of Pantera.
Doing a solo album is still okay, but having a side project band is a definite no in my book.



</answer>

<answer>



It's a crappy song, but that one song, The Great Escape by Boys Like Girls, makes me remember this party I was at.  I had moved away from the town years before and I was there with a friend.  Everyone was nice enough to me, but it was a little weird to be the only "outsider."  Anyway when that song came on the stereo I just felt really alienated, and the whole party sucked after that :(
Now any time I hear that song I think of my friend, who tried really hard to show me around, and how much I miss him.

<answer>



What your looking for isn't what I would call metal, and Disturbed and Slipknot's sound is found in a multitude of bands out there. Quite frankly, there are bands, not force-fed to us by the media at large, that have done this type of music before, and far better. ****, I'd even suggest just browsing your local CD shop for a local band that you like. But if your looking for some metal, I suggest Death, Autopsy, Cannibal Corpse on a good day, Slayer, Celtic Frost, Exodus and anything else you can find.



</answer>

I don't konw. It's pretty messed up how it works. Songs brainwash people.
