<question>



Why isn't death metal music mainstream?



</question>



<answer from>



Lyla T
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 277 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i've read that it can have a bad influence on people......... ...and as funny as it sounds... it went on to say that it might influence suicide, depression and erratic behavior.........



i figured maybe cuz some songs are actually morbid and dark...



hope that helps...



</answer>



<answer from>



rob
Member since: 20 October 2008
Total points: 499 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



because it doesn't take much talent.
is too loud.
and overall, it sucks.



</answer>



<answer from>



Larry
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 126 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



most people have different tastes and i can't imagine an 65 year old woman liking death metal music



</answer>



<answer from>
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 184 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can tell you that easily. I'm sitting here in my computer class with five other girls and two boys and one of the guys plays death metal during computer class, and the rest of the class HATES it.



It isn't mainstream because people aren't fond of the screaming. I guess.



</answer>



<answer from>



anonymou...
Member since: 06 March 2008
Total points: 232 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mainstream is a subjective term.  Where the line exists can be argued but death metal isn't mainstream because it has a relatively low listener base.



Also there are a number of people who enjoy listening to anything that isn't mainstream.  Bands know this, so to label themselves as mainstream would be to loose those fans.



</answer>



<answer from>



rswoodso...
Member since: 12 February 2007
Total points: 92900 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Lyrics



Other - Music



Fantasy Sports



</answer from>



<answer>



Much of the subject material found on the lyrics of death metal isn't for the likes of offices, waiting rooms, most department stores, etc. You'd have to convince an older, more subdued crowd that it is okay.



Also, many people like to understand the lyrics without taking time to look them up, such as if they are screamed. That, to me, is why most people don't prefer it in the pop circles. Pop tends to prefer easier to digest lyrics.



Finally, you are discounting the urban influence on pop and mainstream music. Though rap and hip-hop does look faddish to the rock mindset, it is running its course.



</answer>



<answer from>



aniє♥ ☮ღ☮
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 26668 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not enough people listen to it for it to be mainstream...and would you really want it to be? I think the best music out there is definitely NOT mainstream!



</answer>

http://www.guitarcenter.com/Epiphone-SG-...

http://www.overstock.com/Electronics/Pyl...



I was also thinking that it could be the way my equalizer is set up or maybe the controls on my pedal but I am not sure after playing with them for a while.



I'm pretty sure I have the pick held correctly in coordination with my thumb hitting right after the pick.  And I have been trying to get it to come out by picking up and down the string to find a sweet spot.  I am currently playing with Ernie Ball "Not even slinky" that are about 3 weeks old.



Any solutions or tips to point me in the right direction would be great!

<question from>

<question>



Lyrics or title to this song?



I heard the song on the radio and I can't really remember the lyrics all that well. but they go something like this



"Dance baby dance baby"



haha thats all i can remember. Im not even sure if Baby is supposed to be in there but it sounded good. Anyways, the song is fast paced and the sound kinda reminds me of dragonforce... if anyone can tell me the song name that'd be awesome.

<answer from>



Gilbert C
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 283 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Artist - The Senate
Song - Baby Dance



I love to watch the way your pretty maple grows
Squeezing the earth between its little toes
As we listen to the leaves tell the story of the wind
I will know how it begins
Lying down here



So before you die
Baby dance baby dance baby dance
Baby move like you move like you move
Stay the simple sway of my heart
That I get from you



Rollie Pollie comes the sun again



To tuck me to sleep next to my best friend



It was a warm summer night we filled with memories
And your loving wings wrapped all around me
Won’t go nowhere
Lying down here



So before we die
Baby dance baby dance baby dance
Baby move like you move like you move
Stay the simple sway of my heart
That I get from you



Sitting up above the world
Baby dance

<answer>



I think his only number one was "Crazy in love" with beyonce..But i might be wrong..



Its got nothing to do with metaphors...If you knew what a metaphor was, You'd know Jay-Z is arguably the least metaphorical rapper on the planet. His WORDPLAY however is pretty distinct. And a lot of rappers have ripped it off...although some might argue that they got it from say Big L or KRS one or Big Daddy Kane.



But his selling point is that he OPENLY drew the focus away from lyricism as the ONLY WAY to get money in the rap game. He even references it a few times when he says "They don't understand the flow, But they understand da dough". And Reasonable Doubt (his solo album) embraced getting rich through the hustle, Which was like the opposite direction rappers like NaS were going in...



He was like a lyricist that was an anti-lyricist. He knew he could spit, But he concentrated on his swag.



I dunno what circles you run in bud, but Jay-Z headlined glastonbury...Em, Snoop or Dre couldn't do that in their wildest dreams. The guy had fans singing wonderwall AS WELL as his own material...Em,Snoop and Dre don't have that kinda status as rappers.



</answer>



<answer from>



CG C
Member since: 23 April 2007
Total points: 161 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



In hip-hop, billboard charts mean absolutely nothing.  If you have a good flow, and good metaphors, you're going to get noticed by a good company. There's tons of great rappers out there that aren't on the billboard charts.



Read one of Jay-Z's lines



"Can't y'all, see that he's fake, the rap version of TD jakes
Prophesizing on your CDs and tapes
Won't break you a crumb of the little bit that he makes
And this is with whom you want to place your faith?"



Lines like that are what he's famous for.



</answer>

<answer from>



olive
Member since: 09 March 2008

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Wow, sorry to hear that! Yeah, I would say that's being unfair. Sometimes parents are...silly. I'll just use that word, lol.  Where are you applying for jobs at? Even if you had to apply for a job at a restaurant I would, just so you can start getting some cash in while you look for a better job. You could also try the department of employment services. If it's a desperate situation, I'd go with any job until you can find a better one. This totally unfair for you, I'm really sorry.



Also, do you go to college? You will probably be eligible for financial aid and scholarships enough to go to a CC to start with. I would seriously give that a thought as a college education is really needed in today's job market...
Good luck! :)



MA: Good Times Bad Times- Led Zeppelin



*edit: Also most colleges have a work-study programs where they hire you to work and it goes toward your tuition. Or, there are a lot of jobs available for students and only students so you would probably be eligible for a lot of those and the money doesn't necessarily have to go towards tuition.



</answer>

Nirvana V GnR: Nirvana

Queen V Jonas: I don't like either if Queen is without Freddie, but they have the influence of Freddie still, so Queen
Jonas V Roots: The Roots
Roots V Stripes: White Stripes
Stripes V Vines: White Stripes
Vines V Verve: The Verve
Verve V Joy Division: Joy Division



</answer>

<question>



R&P: What Was Your Favorite HALLOWEEN Experience ?



.
DISCLAIMER - I am putting this in R&P, because this is where my Peeps are :)



Mine was when I was about 10 yrs old ?? - and I had all the Right Friends with me and we would Run & Squeal from House to House... Running across Front Lawns and not using the Street.



Eventually (because it was so Dark), we forgot that some Yards have HILLS !!



We ALL (to our complete surprise) went FLYING !! ....Suspended in Mid-Air for Moments, that seemed like Forever -- and then came Crashing-Down the Other Side !!



We were SO GIDDY, that even though we were all Banged-Up -- We just laid there, Laughing like Crazy !!



This was REAL LIFE !!



-- And it comes with Unexpected & Serendipitous Surprises :)
..

<answer>



We were walking down a street, eggs in hand.. (About three years ago) (( we went to a egg farm/factory managed tog et 200 eggs for free))



while walking down, i noticed a guy outside his house, stood there.  I nudged my friend who was talking to the rest of the guys, about egging an house.  We all clocked on to this guy, except our friend 'Lee' who, without hesitation said "LETS EGG THIS HOUSE" .. He ran past us and threw the eg straight at the window and ran down the hill around the corner, confused as to why we we're all stood there in shock.



The window who lee threw the egg at belonged to the guy stood outside the house, the man shouted "LEE I KNOW YOUR DAD"



Was rather amusing at the time =D

<answer from>



misaleia
Member since: 14 April 2008
Total points: 1549 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mine's similar to your's.  Me and my buds always ran from lawn to lawn, laughing like maniacs.  In fact, I think we smushed quite a few flowers.  Since it was so dark outside, I didn't realize that some houses at steps to get up to their door.  I was 12, and me and my friends were racing to get to the house first.  I thought I was gonna be first to this really big scary house on our street, but instead I tripped over the step and went flying into their garden with all my candy pouring out of my bag.  I was laughing so hard, I didn't even realize that I scraped my knee.  I recovered most of my candy, but 2 years later I ended going to that house and finding a piece of my candy still in their garden.



I guess Halloween is never really about candy, more just about fun.  That was cheesy.



</answer>



<answer from>



Silver*  Rose ~ Wolf
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 56630 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



I think Halloween in the US is rather different to hear in Britain, or maybe it's just lack of those sorts of 'group of friends' experiences. Anyway, the only memory I really have is this one from when I was 3 :~



My aunt made a Halloween cake, which had 3 orange marzipan pumpkins on top {different sizes}, and 8 black marzipan cats around the sides.



This cake was beautiful ~ I still have a photo of it!



So, I very happily enjoyed 3 cats and the smallest pumpkin, but it seems all that food colouring is not good when mixed with an over-excited 3-year-old!



But, despite being sick, I still loved that cake!



</answer>

Well, I, personally prefered old Panic! At The Disco.

All I'll say is I don't like the direction they've gone/are going in. xD

<question from>



Sparty on!
Member since: 01 May 2007
Total points: 1199 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Why is Oasis regarded as such a great band?



They've been ripping off Lennon and McCartney (John in particular) for their entire career.  Don't get me wrong, I loved "Wonderwall" and "Morning Glory".  I thought they were brilliant...still do.  But after that, seriously, is there any reason to listen to any other record?  Will they just continue to do the same thing?



</question>



<additional details>



Sabrina, you just kind of confirmed my point.  No disrespect..."Don't Look Back In Anger" is my favorite Oasis song, but wouldn't you agree their musical range is bordering on ridiculous?  I mean they say how great they are...but Radiohead has developed...R.E.M. developed...Zeppelin and the Who developed....but are Oasis?  Here's an interesting side note.  Just think about The Fab Four and the space between "She Loves You" and "Come Together."  We're talking six years...'63 to '69.  Oasis have done nothing in that regard.  That's my point.



</additional details>



<answer from>



David Brent
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It's a matter of opinion.Yes, there hasn't been a drastic change to their sound.That could be because the Gallaghers still believe in true Rock 'n Roll, meaning no unneccesary studio gimmicks or electronic elements being implemented in their songs.They have put out two great albums in a row now & a lot of people still enjoy them.Their not as big as they once were but they'll still sell out shows all over Europe.
Noel Gallagher's comments should be taken with a pinch of salt.It's just his tongue in cheek sense of humour.He likes taking the piss, only nobody realises he's doing it.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



When I saw the Brentmeister General in the Avatar I had to laugh.  Your comments were good, but your Avatar even better...



"It's the team that matters. Where would The Beatles be without Ringo? If John got Yoko to play drums the history of music would be completely different."
David Brent



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Sabrina Is a fan of  Muse
Member since: 31 December 2007
Total points: 15462 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually I love Oasis and it's all a matter of opinion plus all though Noel and Liam have crappy attitudes or whatever.  They still are  a brilliant band.  The Gallagher brothers have a reputation for being jerks but their music and talent makes up for it.  A lot of people love them and a lot of people hate them or dislike them but once again it's all a matter of opinion. I happent to love them. Especially because of their song "Don't Look Back In Anger".  That song si amazing and they are a wonderful band. This is just my opinion but I know some people who would agree with me.



</answer>



<answer from>



floating in glass
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 2049 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



True, and it's unusual to like a band and still say "all their songs sound the same". But i kind of know what you mean with Oasis. They should have disappeared after just the two albums in my opinion. It's ridiculous how much recognition they still get (although someone said not in the U.S. i think. But I can tell you everyone in England gets ridiculously excited when a new single comes out and says it's the best thing ever all over again). I can't see them doing anything different now. I think the only time they really "developed" was between Definitely Maybe and What's The Story, and even then the songs were just kinda catchier. I guess Whatever was different, but even that was just Oasis with some strings chucked over it (which is how I usually describe the Verve). So I guess my main point is I agree with you. For the record I loved She's Electric though. The only song I really like that's not on the first two albums is probably The Hindu Times, from Heathen Chemistry. Not a deviation in any way, just another good song.



</answer>

That's what you looking for! Too much to type, so just watch here's the link http://www.blog-x.in/index.php?q=related...
This small video WILL REALLY HELP YOU!

I closed my eyes and the flashback started

And now I'm crying on my stair case begging you please don't go
And I said

I'll be waiting. All that's left to do is run"
You ignored me, you didn't show me any love
I walked away, feeling good, feeling good cuz
(key change)
I had the right feeling that you wanted her instead
I thought of us but that was all in my head
How could I know if it was really worth it?
It's a love story, pretty please say
Yes
Please, say yes
And don't go, no, no
Once I loved you
But now I can't stand
You

<answer>



Heya I've just had a look through various song finder websites but know luck.  The problem is that there are lots of songs about the weekend and a lot of songs sung by men!  Any additional details would be welcome as there is very little to go on. What I would advise is that you listen out for it again and if you do hear it then try and find out th name but if that is not possible then try and get some more information or lryics.  Once you've done that I recommend that you ask this question giving more details.  Sorry I couldn't be of more use to you - I understand how frustrating it is when you hear a good song and you don't know what it is called.



Oh yeh, if you have a Sony Ericsson then you should had a feature called TrackID on your phone.  It is under the entertainment menu on my phone. Next time you hear the song I would really recommend you use that as it works really well. If, however you don't have a Sony Ericsson then sorry.



Ashley

<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm a guitarist of over 40 years who plays in an all original band.



If you play guitar...you HAVE to check out these albums.  They will make you want to throw your guitar away and say, "What's the use," because none of us will ever be this good...



"Return of the Hellecasters"- The Hellecasters ( 3 studio musicians out of L.A. who are quite possibly the finest guitarists alive, tremendous licks with amazing versitility and originality)



"The Humbler" - Danny Gatton ( Why was it called the "humbler?") Because all other guitarists, even many of those already mentioned in this topic, bow down and acknowledge Gatton as the finest guitarist to ever walk the face of the earth.



"The Ventures Live in Japan '65" - The Ventures  (Don't laugh, this is some red hot live guitar playing...so much so, many of you who listen to this will not believe it was recorded as early as 1965.  Phenominal playing by Nookie Edwards.  This is the school book for learning lead guitar)



</answer>

<question from>



Michael.
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 1562 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Does anyone think the "grunge" label was missused for most Seattle scene bands?



How could bands like Nirvana, Mother Love Bone, Alice In Chains, Pearl Jam, Soundgarden etc have been thrown in the same boat? No wonder Kurt took such offense at Pearl Jam being labeled grunge....because they wern't. Bleach had shades of grunge, but would anyone call Nevermind grunge? It sounds like pop punk with heavy metal influences to me.



Kurt himself said of Nirvana "All in all, I think we sound like The Knack and the Bay City Rollers being molested by Black Flag and Black Sabbath"



</question>



<additional details>



Amy i'm expecting an answer from you  :)



That's my point....Alice In Chains played metal. No seattle band I have heard that was labeled "grunge" sounds similar to me.



Don't ask me what grunge was....listen to Kurt in this interview. He explains it.



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6TwOBGZ3g...



I think ALL seattle bands from that era were unique, not just Nirvana. Mother Love Bone is my personal favourite from that era...they mixed glam rock Queen, T. Rex with metal and early grunge.



How could Nirvana invent "grunge" when Green River were playing it in 1984? It just didn't become commercial until 1991.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Addict For Dramatics♫
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 2991 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I agree. The majority of bands labeled "grunge" were far from it.



and I agree with Kurt. That's basically what they sound like. XD



Source(s):



Any band with influences like Black Flag is obviously amazing.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Agreed my friend, they just threw a whole bunch of bands into the same label because they all came from the same scene, so they assumed they played the same music? It's like Fallout Boy being labeled with MCR etc, because Pete Wentz wears eyeliner that means they make the same music???? Jesus.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Chris
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 1572 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can't disagree with you on that. The Seattle based bands were commonly refered to that out of sheer ignorance. Nirvana started a fuore which put Seattle on the map (people had obviously never heard of Jimi) and needed to group it. I was never really a fan of those bands. I like Nevermind but I agree, is that really grunge?



Early 1990's were my college days and the UK Indie scene was in full swing. I was still rocking out to 'tallica's Black and the new Pantera sound but I was also chilling to The Stone Roses, Happy Mondays and digging it with The Mock Turtles.



Sorry I can't add more.



PS. I actually heard R.E.M. refered to as Grunge in '91 *That was in regard to the Out Of Time album ie.Losing My Religion, Maybe that's what inspired them to totally reinvent with Monster in '94.



Just thought I'd share that.



</answer>



<answer from>



Nirvana Snob
Member since: 17 February 2008
Total points: 1685 (Level 3)

<answer>



I agree! I don't think any of them really sound alike! I especially think Nirvana's sound was way different from the others, but they were all pretty different from each other!



edit: I also think they were all unique.  I think, though, that as far as if you were to sit down and listen to all of them, Nirvana sounded the least like the others, for one thing, I think that Nirvana seemed to have more punk influences, whereas the in the others I heard more heavy metal influences. and your right Nirvana definitely did NOT invent grunge! They just brought it to the mainstream...anyone should know that, especially someone claiming to be a Nirvana fan!

<original file>14720.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk88551.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



piano fan
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 80 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What should I buy... an acoustic piano or a digital piano?



I want to buy a piano but not sure which is better, a digital that I won't have to tune, or an acoustic.  Any help would be appreciated...



</question>



<answer from>



lol fundies
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 326 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Obviously a digital one is more versatile, but if you prefer a more "natural" feel, go for the acoustic one.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tom T
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Although digital pianos are getting better and better at replicating the action and sound of an acoustic piano, most would agree that nothing beats the quality of tone, projection and touch of a real piano.  Lacking vibrations, they can feel quite 'dead'.



However, these instruments do certainly have advantages; they can be played using headphones, never need tuning and are much more portable. You can also connect them to your computer and use sequencing and notation software.



It is also imposrtant to note that digital pianos can hard hard to sell on at a later date because when technology advances, they go out of date, so they are not a good investment.



In conclusions, if you want to learn the piano properly  definately go for an acoustic, nothing beats it.  (Try to get a good one and avoid buy on the internet)



Digital pianos are a great option if it is not possible to have the 'real thing'.



</answer>






<original file>14857.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk88702.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



futuresa...
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do i get in touch with record labels?



</question>



<answer from>



W. Jameson
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 581 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Call them



Source(s):



118 118



</answer>



<answer from>



arsene knows best
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 135 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



have you got lewd sessions lined up



</answer>



<answer from>



Prof Anger (res. curmudgeon)
Member since: 11 April 2007
Total points: 18069 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on what you want to contact them about. If it's about general stuff (questions, comments, job inquiries, etc.) then they should have  a contact link somewhere in their website (maybe on a cd itself somewhere) where you can send an e-mail, maybe a mailing address or a phone number.



Although, if you're inquiring about getting signed, most larger labels have a no solicitation policy unless you go through one of their scouts or through an agent or some representative.



</answer>

<answer from>



Another Internet Hero
Member since: 09 September 2006
Total points: 16264 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Okay I'd have to say their older music is the best. Totally so and its what I first heard of them so when I think LP I think of that era in their life. I totally understand why they changed. They've been playing that sort of music for like 10 years, thats enough to bore anyone so they wanted change.



In the end I will always hope they try resurrect some of their older sounds in any upcoming albums but I do respect some of the new songs (Shadow, In Pieces, Valentine's Day). I don't hate their new stuff (I just don't like it too much), its just a really different sound and I think that upset a lot of us fans. If they could make less angry songs but with rhythm and more melody (like Easier To Run), then I'd be totally happy.



Source(s):



Huge LP fan.



</answer>

<answer>



Some people use guitar pro.I used to use a program called Power Tabs.Except their site got shut down but will be back up and running after some legal matters are settled.I loved their program and I used it to learn songs as well as write them.When the site got shut down I downloaded Guitar Pro and I have used it a few times.I do not like it as well though because the quality of the tabs that you get are not as good as Power Tabs.Just occasionally check out the Power Tabs site and download their program when it is up and running again.Until then though I would just use Guitar Pro.

<original file>14866.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk88712.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Michael.
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 1581 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What are your honest thoughts on Jimmy Page as a guitarist?



Nobody is denying Jimmy's skills in the studio as a producer...he could make anything sound good and in the studio he sounded great. How would you rate him overall as a guitarist, including in a live setting.



</question>



<additional details>



Don't just say "he is awesome" or "he sucks"



I want answers from people who know what they are talking about.



The first answer i'll let go :)



Why is Belicia getting so many thumbs down?



No More



Great answer.



</additional details>



<answer from>



No More
Member since: 18 September 2006
Total points: 19684 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



Marriage & Divorce



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think that he is brilliant. There are people that criticize his playing as being sloppy or muddled and I just don't by that. I say that he is passionate and rooted in the blues... I will take players like Jimmy Page and Neil Young over the clean and sterile notes of Eric Clapton or Joe Satriani any day. Before Zeppelin, Before the Yardbirds, Jimmy was the busiest and most sought after studio musician in London... trust me, Jimmy Page could play it however you wanted him too. Sure his studio prowess is acknowledged but I can't think of anyone that is responsible for more classic riffs, grooves, and solos than JImmy Page... The world is full of great players and Jimmy Page takes a back seat to no one in my opinion. From the Rain Song to Ten Years Gone, from Stairway to Heaven to Achilles Last Stand... from Kashmir to Since I've Been Loving You, from Dazed and Confused to The Battle of Evermore..... and so many countless others... breathtakingly prolific... as Jimmy would say "The Light and the Shade".



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Perfectly said.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Wondering Aloud
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 354 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Jimmy Page is extremely creative.  His melodies triads and chord structures are extremely advanced.  From a theory standpoint, even Zepps simple song "Kashmir" is so far ahead of it's time it makes him one of the truly unique guitarists of our time........however, live, he was often so sloppy in his playing, it's sometimes un listenable.  He often tried to play too fast and slurred his notes.



Page was a genious creatively, but when you compare him to a Mark Portnoy, or Robert Fripp, even an Ed Van Halen, he just didn't take his Genius on stage with him.



He is a bit of a dichotomy.  A genious, but a dichotomy.



</answer>



<answer from>



dances in the doldrums
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 6637 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not going to pretend he was perfect. I'm certainly no expert at guitars, but I know and admit he was not the most technically profficient guitarist of all time (not saying he was bad, though... at all). However, I think he makes up for this in several ways. Like you said, he was a great producer and could write some pretty amazing riffs. But those things aside, the reason he is my favorite guitarist is not necessarily his skill but the way he makes me feel... it's all the feeling and emotion in the blues mixed with even more power and mystery, and I can't get enough of it. You can play cleaner than Jimmy Page and still not sound as good to me because of what he puts into the music, and I think this is even more noticeable live. So although he didn't play everything perfectly, that was never the point... he had a passion I can hear and relate to (which you can't always get with perfection), and that is what I love about his playing.



</answer>



<answer from>



shred  happy halloween
Member since: 25 June 2008
Total points: 10954 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



I think he is Overrated and that's all I really have to say I am not in a fun mood really more serious right now so there will be no Jimmy Page bashing tonight from me.



I think he is over glorified in the mainstream and by obsessed classic rock fans that get overly defensive of him when there are negative opinions stated about him.



he wrote some good songs back in his day and an average lead player at tops



but he is no "God" thats for sure



</answer>



<answer from>



Hoagie
Member since: 12 August 2008
Total points: 1491 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think he's a damn good guitarist. Not the best, but definitely in the top 5. I mean, how can anyone listen to Led Zeppelin and tell me he's not a great guitarist? I personally think Since I've Been Loving You, Dazed and Confused, Heartbreaker, and You Shook Me (Live) are some of his best pieces of work. And of course we can't forget Stairway to Heaven.
I definitely think Jeff Beck and Eric Clapton knew what they were doing when they recruited Jimmy to be in the Yardbirds.



</answer>

<question>

I need a new love.... more than make mistakes

<answer from>



Michael
Member since: 27 April 2008
Total points: 10771 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Basketball



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



"Human" by Human League -- they did that song "Don't You Want Me" too.



I'm almost 100% sure that's it. They sound a bit like Spadau Ballet, and I'm guessing that when you heard "I need a new love" it was actually "I'm only human", but as you said the sound was probably bad.



Also, when you heard "more than make mistakes" it was actually "Born to make mistakes". I've heard that song many times and it's catchy, when I read your lines it just clicked in my mind.



See if this is it. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cH2X5Pole...



</answer>



<asker's comment>

<current file name>yqa_uk89721.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Maroon 33
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What are the best chords for a rock song?



I have been trying to write some songs and i want them to be in the style of rock and i can't seem to find the right chords to play them in. Can anybody help me somehow?



</question>



<answer from>



redneckd...
Member since: 21 January 2007
Total points: 384 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



G - C - D



Sweet Home Alabama!



</answer>



<answer from>



darkprin...
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, depends on what style of rock, but generally if you are going for pure classic rock chords I, IV and V are sufficient, as well as their sevenths. For instance you could have the following progression:



I - IV7 - I - IV7 - V- IV - I



Using guitar chords for example:



A - D7 - A - D7 - E - D7 - A



</answer>



<answer from>



kvox1040
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 176 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Do what I call a minor prgression. Em, C, G, D This is a very common progression and you should recognize a few songs when you play it.



</answer>

<question>



What are some underrated classic rock songs?



Do you know any underrated classic rock songs or maybe some that don't play on the radio too often? I've just been doing some research the last couple years and there's a lot of good ones I'd never heard before. Here are just a few of them.
She's Not There (The Zombies)

Gloria (Them)

Signs (Five Man Electrical Band)
Down By The Seaside (Led Zeppelin)
157 Riverside Avenue-live version (REO Speedwagon)
Tell Me Why (Elvis Presley)



If you know any good ones please let me know!



</question>

<question from>



Michael.
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 1587 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Ritchie Blackmore or Yngwie Malmsteen?



Which guitarist do you prefer and why, I know they are different...but that's what makes it interesting.



</question>



<additional details>



Shred I expect a long answer from you.



Yeah but you guys are just talking about speed...since when does speed make a guitarist better?



Great answer Chris....i could never get into Malmsteens playing, maybe it's because i'm not a guitar player myself and can't appreciate his techincal abilities....I prefer listening to a guitarist play interesting riffs, melodies and guitar lines.



</additional details>



<answer from>



No More
Member since: 18 September 2006
Total points: 19684 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



Marriage & Divorce



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have to go with Ritchie Blackmore. Malmsteen is technically proficient and fast as all get out but to me at least, listening to him gets old really quickly. I find his playing to be limited and he has almost tunnel vision in terms of playing the same things over and over in search of perfection... Blackmore gave us Deep Purple, Rainbow, and even in Blackmore's Night he is expanding on his gift... I just don't find Yngwie's music inviting... I think I still have a copy of Rising Force around here somewhere.....



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Perfect answer again my friend.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



shred  happy halloween
Member since: 25 June 2008
Total points: 10956 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



Well Blackmore is one of the innovators of "Shred" guitar along with Uli Roth in Rock music and Blackmore a huge inspiration and influence on Malmsteen so I have to pay respects to the Innovator



Blackmore is my choice



EDIT: you know M? I really enjoy listening to both players music just about the same too. I mean Yngwie is far more technical for sure but Blackmore is also epic in his own way



Source(s):



Not too long LOL



</answer>



<answer from>



Wondering Aloud
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 354 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



When it comes to memorable riffs, not just diarrhea of the fingers, Blackmore is king.
Yes, Malmsteen is fast, but I like a tasteful player as well.
Riffs:  My Woman from Tokyo; Smoke on the Water; Burn; Stormbringer; Space Truckin; Highway Star; Hush; High Ball Shooter: Man on the Silver Mountain, the list goes on.
Ok, now name a great riff song from Malmsteen.



Both players are undeniably superior, but I just like Blackmore's style more.  When you have two players of this caliber, it comes down to preference.



Cheers!



</answer>



<answer from>



american...
Member since: 01 March 2008
Total points: 5026 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, Malmsteen seems to build ALL of his songs on speed.  When you do that, it seems to get boring and, in fact, Malmsteen's newer stuff really bores me, though I like his older stuff quite a bit (what I've heard of it).  I mean, sure--speed is impressive, but, in rock especially, it gets boring.  I find it more interesting to hear guys like Brad Paisley play with a lot of speed (he's country, in case you don't know--check him out though...he's an outstanding guitarist).



Ritchie Blackmore, with Rainbow, was great.  The only album I have with Blackmore on it is a compilation of songs by Rainbow and he was a great guitarist.



Honestly, I'd have to say that Blackmore is better.  Of course, Malmsteen is faster and drunker.  In fact, I once heard that his crew that would set stuff up (maybe even other band members) would urinate in Malmsteen's drinks because he was a scumbag.  I've also heard that he didn't realize that because he was always drunk.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 1582 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Love the question Michael. It makes such a change to see something championing Richie Blackmore. He always seems to be the nearly man in these polls so kudos for bringing him into the limelight.



I think you can tell by now, I'm a fan of Richie's. I particularly like his DP eras but Rainbow are pretty good. I've only got the Jeff Scott Soto Rainbow albums which 1980 to the split in '84. Richie plays phenomenally well though.



Jeff Scott Soto is a nice transition to bring us back to Yngwie J. Malmsteen. I'm afraid, the rather dull thing is, although I recognise Yngwie's contribution and playing expertise (no one can deny him that) I'm just not into that whole Classical Metal structure of the Rock genre. I do have one of his Greatest Hits albums but it very rarely gets a play.



The answer - Richie all the way.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ace Explosion [Krokodile Shears]
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 540 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This question is pretty interesting, the comparison is weird, and will mostly be opinion.
Yngwie clearly has more skill. He has done so many great things that make him so much better than Richie.



Comparing the bands tho... Rainbow, Deep Purple vs. Alcatrazz and an Amazing Solo Career.
Yngwie is at a level so far above Richie, his skills kill anything Deep Purple or Rainbow have done, the only thing Richie has is original songs with Dio



</answer>

KYLE- [In Flames We Trust]
Member since: 27 May 2007
Total points: 9135 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



I love both but I gotta give it up to Yngwie. I've tried playing a guitar with scalloped frets before and it kicked my ***. The sheer speed he can play one and not make his notes go sharp is just phenomenal.



Well, it's hard to have a Q about Yngwie and not talk about speed.. It's what he's known for. Also, I don't think Ritchie could play a scalloped guitar as proficiently as Yngwie, which is my reason Yngwie is better.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What is the picking pattern for the beginning of Techincal Difficulties by Racer X or Paul GIlbert ?



i can play the rest of the song, its just this part is giving me a heck of alot of problems thx



</question>



<answer from>



shred  happy halloween
Member since: 25 June 2008
Total points: 10956 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Wow I missed this question.



its alternate picking that's it simple as that if you can play the rest the song you should surely know this with all do respect. in fact watch him do it. he uses a series of up and down strokes in 8th and 16th notes.



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T2zXMR2yc...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thx but yea i i dont know why but i always try to stay with the up down up down up down picking style so it gets confusing after a while doing that so yea thx anyways

<original file>16045.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk90023.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Fgbs H
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 14 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Best band??????????do u agree with me????



ok i will name a couple of bands and try to describe them.



guns n roses- obnoxious lead singer, cocky guitar player, good lyrics and ok music



metallica- very aggressive and talented, know how to play instruments, lyrics have never been that different or unique, too many solos, but overall from 1 to 100 i give them a 90.



black sabbath- pretty much created metal so metal bands better kiss their *** e s, lyrics were incredible, very talented band, but got a little boring sometimes, way too many albums



led zeppelin- the reason why axl rose sounds the way he does, jimmy page was just a little overrated, they have one of the best drummers ever, lead singer was good, they created a cool sound, lyrics were brilliant and sometimes not half bad, from 1 to 100 talentwise i have to give them a 98



motley crue- they are very talented, i never liked their singer and think he is annoying, never were able to finish a great song well, from 1 to 100 i give them a 77.



pearl jam- they got too soft as a grunge band with keyboard and piano's, lyrics were ok, singer was really good, but overall a 86.



stone temple pilots- lead singer was great, i think that they might be on top for one of the best grunge bands, their music just resembled grunge so well, 92.



Nirvana- well the lead singer was a great singer who wrote in my opinion the greatest lyrics ever! for a 3 man band to sound the way they did i'm sorry but hands down i think they have a 100



alice in chains- probablly the most talented singer from the grunge era layne staley, the band was very very talented, they have many great hits and they get a 95 from the gunge era



soundgarden- oh my this could be one of the greatest singers ever too, chris cornell and the lyrics were fantastic! the songs were mostly classics and i give them a 100! with Nirvana



rolling stones- very very talented but their hit songs were mainly the great ones. overall a 99. really great band



kiss- different in looks obviously. lyrics weren't ever so great they were mostly about partying. really just classic rock stuff. maybe we need a song sometimes that is deep. but overall i mean it's kiss! 98.



the beatles- kiss the ground they walk on the masters and creators of rock. their riffs actually were talented and the lyrics were pretty cool because they were sometimes deep and sometimes the i don't care feeling. 100!



the doors- talented men and a great band. lyrics weren't half bad, 96.



the ramones- the singer never did it for me. but they are in a way creators of punk



greenday- one of the most unique punk bands, very great and probablly the closest any band of the new age has come to a modern day nirvana. one day they will definetly be in the hall of fame



aerosmith- ok the lyrics weren't ever so deep except in sing for the moment. he made many songs that could be remembered forever and one of the gods in rock n roll. 99.



queen- one of their two songs are known all over the world and they are magnificent. 99



marilyn manson- always stuck out of the crowd, wasn't afraid to write his real feelings on paper. talented band, inspired by black sabbath and very cool band. 98



AC DC- angus young probablly the best guitar god in the world! lyrics were NEVER deep feelings just partying so that's why i thought it was ok with the lyrics. not out of this world. unique singer, overall i have to do this, 100



pink floyd- unique spacy band with one of the best lyrcs of all time. i definetly give them a 99. always loved them and they are gods



jimmie hendrix- GOD!!!!!!!!!! lyrics insane! best guitarist maybe!!!!!!!!!!100!



iron maiden- cool metal band but never loved the singer. i thought in a way a black sabbath impersonator of a band. but 97



zz top- oh man very talented guitarist. lyrics were like country lyrics and you gotta love the beards. 97

the who- one of the other creators, very great sound and so deep sometimes with talent! 99.



bon jovi- oh well one of the most talented rock star like men ever! classic songs and so awesome with lyrics. great man.



lynard skynard- cool lyrics and great vibe and one of the most talented bands around ever



U2- VERY unique and deep and the lyrics were always so awesome. i love this band



so in your opinion  who is the best of all time????????

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



El:.:Scy...
Member since: 27 May 2008
Total points: 75 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



String breaking - help?



I have a problem - i use 10-46 strings on my ibanez electric guitar (its a GRG), and i seem to break the low E string again and again - I tune it down to C# or C very often, and palm mute often as well, and each time ive broken the string, i was palm muting. I dont apply much pressure but still... a with a life of just one week, its getting costly... thanks in advance.



</question>



<answer from>



Danny R
Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 3168 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Where is it breaking? That will tell you whther the problem is at the nut or the bridge. May just need a little graphite lubrication.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ryan King
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When you tune it down it makes the string looser, so there's a good chance it's rubbing against something, perhaps the nut, which eventually causes it to break. You might also need to adjust the bridge.



Hope you can solve it! I hate breaking strings . . . :-)



</answer>

Err- Is this a love song or a complaint about some-one wearing dirty clothes? I have been writing songs since I was 8- and many of them have been used. <answer from>



Irene G
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Monaco [ˈmɑnəkoʊ] (help·info), officially the Principality of Monaco (French: Principauté de Monaco; Monégasque: Principatu de Múnegu; Italian: Principato di Monaco; Occitan: Principat de Mónegue) is a small sovereign city-state located in Western Europe. The territory lies on the northern coast of the Mediterranean Sea and is completely enclosed by France. Monaco is often regarded as a tax haven, and many of its inhabitants are wealthy and from foreign countries, making up a majority of 84%.[3]
Monaco is a Constitutional Monarchy and Principality with Prince Albert II as head of state. The Grimaldi family has ruled over Monaco since 1297 and the state's sovereignty was officially recognized by the Franco-Monegasque Treaty of 1861. Despite being independent, Monaco’s defense is still the responsibility of France.
Monaco is the world’s most densely populated sovereign country, and the world's smallest French-speaking country.



Source(s):



Wikipedia



</answer>

<answer>



Rap first emerged like in 1984. So when people refer to old school it means a song from back in the old days of rap. I think the best period for rap music was the 1988-1996 era. Here are some of my favorite old school artists:



Public Enemy
Run DMC
KRS One
NWA
Naughty by Nature
Wu-Tang Clan
A Tribe Called Quest

1979-1984

93-94

I can go on and on. Point is, there's an entire world of music out there, not just whatever is on the top 40.

<original file>2995.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk91651.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Joanna K
Member since: 26 May 2007
Total points: 316 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



The radio station z100?



what # station is Z100??? i usually listen to it online but now i want 2 listen to it in the car. thx! bye =)



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



FM radio stations have a very small range, so unless that station is in your city/town, it's doubtful that you'll be able to hear it.
That's why so many stations have an online presence - no limitation on range!
If you know that this station IS in your town, try tuning your radio to 99.9, 100.1, 100.3 or 100.5 fm.



</answer>

<original file>3001.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk91660.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



kersal12...
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 31 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can i loosen my bass guitar strings using a truss rod?



</question>



<answer from>



Hawk M
Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 5611 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Other - Music



</answer from>



<answer>



You don't loosen the strings with the truss rod,
you loosen the strings with the tuning pegs.



the truss rod is meant to adjust the tension on the neck, and it can be VERY dangerous doing your own neck adjusting, without the proper training and tools.



I'm not saying you can't figure it out, but I have seen more people ruin their equipment, by trying to fix things they don't know how to fix.



Different basses adjust differently.



It's not hard to show you, but very difficult to explain it in an eMail



on MOST, (not all) basses, turning the rod clockwise, will tighten the neck, the question is just how far, and that we can't explain here.
It's something that you learn.



First, you have to determine what the problem is, and it's NOT always the neck that needs the work.



If your string are too low, and buzz on the fretboard,



it might the nut is cut wrong,



the bridge may need raising,



the pickups might be too high,



you may have a couple of high frets
or the neck may have a backbow.



If the strings are too high, most of the above is still true,
the nut may not be cut correctly (need special files)
the bridge may need lowering.
The may have a bow in it, and need tightening.



No way of knowing which, without seeing it.



Some adjust at the top of the headstock
some adjust at the bottom of the neck
some use a screwdriver,



some use a special wrench,



Some use an allen wrench
Firt you have to determine where the problem is, then you have to figure out how to fix it,



too many things can go wrong,



bring it in to a guitar tech, most will adjust a neck for $10-20,
which is better than ruining your own bass



Have him explain it for you



</answer>



<answer from>



another detroit bassist
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 6154 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://www.BogdonMusic.com



</answer>

<question from>



kramo

</question from>



<question>



I need a great mic for a lead singer in a rock band?



Can someone recommend a fantastic Mic for a female lead singer for playing out at clubs and practicing in my basement?  Its a small basement so we deal with a little feedback from reflection off the walls.  I am willing to spend up to $300.  thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Ale Mih
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have not idea!



But you  can by everyone!



</answer>



<answer from>



Bill C
Member since: 26 June 2007
Total points: 802 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The good olde Shure 58 is a standard for a reason...it's rugged, relatively difficult to feedback, has a response curve that helps the human voice cut through the other instruments, and won't break the bank.



I you are recording vocals or doing TV work, there are a raft of choices, but for your use, that's my recommendation.



Source(s):



Studio 15 years, stage  sound 30 years.  Engineered 12 CD's in own studio.



</answer>



<answer from>



Guitarsl...
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 162 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok, somethings you have to consider first. Unless you just want to spend 300 dollars for a good mic you don't have to. You need to figure out what kind of mic you want. Meaning dynamic or condenser are usually live stage mics, dynamic more so than condenser but that is changing. A dynamic mic requires no power. A condenser mic requires power from your PA board. Its called phantom power its 48v (volts). Just about every PA board manufactured has it built in, so it shouldn't be a problem. A dynamic mic will be less sensitive than the condenser, but stage condensers are not as sensitive as studio condensers. The most common/standard dynamic stage mic thats been around forever in a Shure SM58 or SM57. They run about 100 dollars and do the job nicely and are just about indestructible. There are so many mics to choose from it can be overwhelming. Try going to www.musiciansfriend.com and look at the vocal mics. read the reviews of what people are saying, that will help you decide also. You can even specify your price range.



</answer>



<answer from>



byrde199...
Member since: 12 May 2008
Total points: 7404 (Level 5)



</answer from>

</answer>

<question>



Why don't bands change their names when a member  leaves/dies?



Hello.  Let me start - I love Queen.  They just put out an album - The Cosmos rock.  Taking over for Freddie is Paul Rodgers.  Zepplin are reforming w/ (rumoured) Steve Tyler.  Axl Rose calls his band, w/ no orignal members but him, Guns N Roses.



So Question time folks, or your opion,  Should bands keep their origanl names when a band member leaves/dies/gives up (thinking of Pink Floyd and poor ol' Syd Barrett)?



For a band like Queen - couldn't they call themselves Smile - since Taylor and May formed that band before Queen - and since they are the only two members from the Queen line up?



Whatcha think?



</question>



<answer from>



Stephan...
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 1650 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



i agree i think they shoudl change there name when that happens
but so many people like them



if they keep the name they keep all the good stuff that goes with it
and they still have all the fans of there older stuff even if theydidn't like there new stuff.. whereas if they didnt like there new stuff.. they wouldnt listen to them and the band wouldnt be as well known.. if you get what i mean.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Yep-understood.  I agree w/ most of ya - they have to keep the name so the fans will flock to their shows and buy their releases.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Rikitiki...
Member since: 20 February 2006
Total points: 17209 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Rock and Pop



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree...especially with Queen, GnR and Led Zeppelin. I guess the reason they dont do it is



1.They plan on performing their past material and thay want the band name to still be associated with those songs
2.Name recognition People will buy tickets and cds if its from a band they have known, regardless of who the members are.It eliminates a lot of marketing to promote the new band and to get their new name out there



</answer>

I think if one, maybe even two, members leave it's fine to keep the same name. The band still has a good amount of original members. For example, Jefferson Airplane could have stayed Jefferson Airplane after the first two left, in my opinion. And Pink Floyd was also fine staying Pink Floyd. But the new Guns N Roses and Queen should have different names.

<answer>



oh and don't forget Jerry Cantrell reforming Alice In Chains and Journey w/ the Filipino guy



part of it (I believe) is that people recognize the name, so they will be recognizeable and can/will sell records.........as long as there are some of the major components to the band remaining (i.e. a distinctive sound, important member) people will see the band



May was a big contributer to Queen, besides Freddie he was the most recognizeable member



The same thing with The Who.....the voice (Daltrey) and the creativity (Townsend) are still there so people will do see them



</answer>



<answer from>



panti-sl...
Member since: 29 June 2006
Total points: 5884 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



some do...when Jerry Garcia (one of two people for whom a Ben & Jerry's flavour named) died, The Grateful Dead dropped "Grateful" from the name and now perform (occasionally) as The Dead....also, Bob Weir has a separate band called "Rat Dog"



also, over the years, "Jefferson Airplane" became "Jefferson Starship" and then just "Starship"



but if the band is substantially the same and plays the same kind of music, then why can't they keep the name....since, by your argument, The Beatles would have had to change their name when Pete Best died and Richard Starkey (Ringo Starr) became their drummer.
(incidentally, The Beatles is at least the third name they went by, having previously been "The Quarrymen" and "The Silver Beetles" before they really took off and became well known as The Beatles



</answer>

<question>



Inspired by Snickerz, Let's compare the East Coast and West Coast artists?



Anyone can make a statement, like "East Coast over West Coast" or "West Coast over East Coast", but the only way to logically compare is to compare artists



KRS-One vs Tupac
50 Cent vs Eazy-E
Slick Rick vs Dr Dre
Nas vs Ice Cube
Kool G Rap vs Warren G
Jay-Z vs Xzibit
AZ vs The Game
Big L vs Too Short
Puff Daddy vs Ice-T
Biggie vs Coolio
Big Pun vs Snoop Dogg
De La Soul vs N.W.A



I think it's obvious who's better



</question>



<additional details>



Tahir: Are you implying that I said something along those lines?



Can people stop making their own ones up and answer the original question. I didn't state any of them were similar, they do have different styles. But who has the best style?



</additional details>

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

Edit: but to answer your question... KRS would tear Pac a new one (and don't get me wrong I dig Pac but he's no GOd emcee)
50 would kill Eazy as (I guess people forget this well know fact) Eazy didn't and couldn't write ryhmes...
Slick would weave words around Dre for tha same reason (he's a PRODUCER people! when are we gonna learn that)

<answer>



I don't know why people get caught up comparing everything all the time.



West Coast hip-hop and East Coast hip-hop have different styles and that's why you shouldn't compare them..They are basically different genres to me, that's why you can have an album like The Chronic up there with Ready to Die..they are extremely different albums but it's about their reception by their respective audiences at the end of the day.



It's unfair to say "That West Coast album has sh*tty lyrics, that's not worthy of the lyricism the East Coast has".. because the styles are different..



EDIT: No, I'm just wondering why people compare music from these two places where styles are very different.



Source(s):



Sorry about that rant..



</answer>



<answer from>



TschernS...
Member since: 30 September 2006
Total points: 3618 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok You want to compare artists but why group them as you do maybe you need to rearrange them a bit:



KRS-One vs Tupac Maybe it should be Pac Vs. Nas or Pac Vs. Jay) Eitherway Pac is one of the greatest ever while KRS-One is a pioneer he is not as appealing to the same broad audience as Pac. Pac could legitimatley take down Jay or Nas.



50 Cent vs Eazy-E (This is a good pairing but Eazy is better then 50. His songs were about real issues and contained interesting wordplay. While he didn't write them we all know 50 doesn't write all of his lyrics either. Eazy also put the West Coast on the map and founded one of the most influential hip hop groups in history with NWA and launched the careers of Dr. Dre, Ice Cube and others. These guys launched the careers of: The game, Eminem, Xzibit, Snoop, Tha Dogg Pound, Nate Dogg, Lynch Mobb, W.C. and Mack 10 among others.
Slick Rick vs Snoop Dogg, is a better pairing since they are similar. I'd say it's a wash but Snoop has outsold Rick and continues to be a influential force in hip-hop.



Nas vs Ice Cube. Is this one fair? Are Nas and Cube similar? Why pair them? Cube is great but not on the same level as Nas.



Kool G Rap vs Warren G Why bring Warren G into this? He made one album that was worth listening to. He was not a Pioneer. If we are shuffling Dre crushes Kool G. Xzibit is at least similar.



Jay-Z vs Xzibit. Not at all fair. Maybe Jay goes up against Snoop or Dre. Jay probably wins though.



AZ vs The Game. Why does AZ win? The Game is new and fresh and bringing the West Back. did AZ break any ground do anything worth talking about 10 years later? NOPE.



Big L vs Too Short. NO RAPPER COMPARES TO TOO SHORT. The guy has made records like you make dinner. Always grinding and being relevant. the guy fouded the Bay Area and was influential to Spice One, Tupac, Digital Underground, E-40 and so many others. Big L is famous for what? dying? Short wins.



Puff Daddy vs Ice-T ???? Diddy Vs. Dre is about the same comparision of Diddy Vs Eazy. Diddy built a powerful East Coast label launched the careers of many artists similarly to Dre and even Eazy. Diddy musically doesn't turn the knobs or write his own S**T so he's an executive type. Ice-T at least wrote his own lyrics for that he wins. Diddy Vs. Dre is a wash.



Biggie vs Coolio ????????? How does MF Coolio compare to Big? Big is the best and beats nearly everyone. To the East he is as Pac is to the West.



Big Pun vs Snoop Dogg. Possibly an interesting face off. Snoop howeveron the West is bigger then Pun. Maybe we should send E-40 after Pun. Maybe Xzibit or Warren G or Mack 10 or who cares.



De La Soul vs N.W.A ?? NWA is far more important to hip hop then De La Soul. Wu Tang Vs. NWA makes more sense and is much more similar. De La Soul is maybe our version of West Side Connection or Digital Underground.



I'll say this overall there are far more acts coming out of NY then the West Coast. That's fine the majority of music comes out of the east. The West is a unique place where not everything translates out to the east coast. Heck our projects are flat, have palm trees and it never rains or snows. Where would you rather live?



</answer>

</category>



<question from>



Gregory J
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Dave "Snake" Sabo Guitar Setup?



I am trying to reproduce the free-flying harmonic squeels for that Skid Row sound.  Does anyone know what pickups and pedals he was using to get that?  I can easily produce an artificial harmonic, but just can't get it to scream like that.



My axes are stock Gibson Les Paul DC, Fender Am Strat and I have a Cort LP copy with Duncan JB/Jazz pickups.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



He played ESP Custom Strat and Peavey Wolfgang guitars. Dunlop 535 Wah Pedal, Boss CE-2 Chorus Pedal. Peavey 5150 II Head, Peavey Ultra Head,and 5150 cabinets. That may help you some.



</answer>

<original file>371.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk92446.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



Anniee.
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Song writing for the first time. For GCSE?



For my GCSE music grade I have to write a song.



I was wondering if anyone had any tips or examples to help me get writing a song, because i'm finding it really hard.



Thanks (Y)



</question>



<answer from>



THE Mrs. McCain
Member since: 13 January 2006
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Can it be any style of song?  i.e. instrumental vs. something with lyrics...  I've found the easiest way for me to write is to just sit down at my piano and start tinkering with chord progressions and run with anything that sounds good.  I write down all my bits and pieces, even if I can't seem to get them to work at the time, and refer back to them from time to time.



Source(s):



Master's Degree in Music Education



</answer>



<answer from>



Alex
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 194 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



well, keep it simple first of all. i would limit the song to about 4-5 chords max. have 2 verses, 2 choruses, and intro, maybe a pre chorus, have a bridge, outro. im assuming, your writing like a song where you would play guitar, and sing, band situation/ solo acoustic, etc.
good luck!!!



check out my band



myspace.com/aseasonaleffect music



</answer>

<question from>



Margarit...
Member since: 31 May 2006
Total points: 506 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Which Guitar Should i get?



i'm going to get a new guitar for my B-day today, and i've narrowed it down to these 2



http://i482.photobucket.com/albums/rr183...



http://i482.photobucket.com/albums/rr183...



i like the worn brown because everyone i know has a black guitar, and i like how it looks, it's different, clean earthy, i really like it.



the goth les paul is also awesome, i especially like the Roman numeral 12 on the 12th fret, and the black chrome is also cool



it's between these two, which should i get.



</question>



<answer from>



Johnny V
Member since: 03 December 2007
Total points: 192 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Although both guitars are stunning, pick the one that plays best for you especially for chording and soloing. The one guitar that feels comfortable in your hands is the one. You might like thick & clubby necks or you might like thin and narrow necks. It can vary.



My dream guitar: A Fender Custom Shop '69 Stratocaster w/ Kinman Pickups, rosewood fretboard w/ a matching headstock.



David



</answer>



<asker's comment>



yeah, thanks, i'll make sure to try both of them out.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



jwenting
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 3389 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



never buy a guitar based on some pictures.
Buy it based on actually playing and liking it.



Looks not only can be deceiving, they have nothing whatsoever to do with playability and sound.



</answer>

Member since: 12 October 2008
Total points: 328 (Level 2)

<original file>4403.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk93217.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Music



</category>



<question from>



jfdjflds
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 14 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Guitar help??????????????????????????…



what should I do??? my electric guitar sounds buzzy on the 1st and 2nd fret of the A string and open G string ..... but the others are fine(help me!)



</question>



<answer from>



Rawr!
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 272 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



press harder!!
^^



</answer>



<answer from>



ALEX
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 1036 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe your strings are fucked up.
I had a similar problem on the twelvth fret and it was caused by the 13th fret being higher than the rest. Take it to a music shop the'll let you know.



</answer>



<answer from>



HELLO! My Name is Hugh Jorgan...
Member since: 08 March 2008
Total points: 2994 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



make sure your truss rod is properly tensioned, and check that your frets are level- you'll probably need to take it in if you don't know ow to do this yourself. You could also simply try a heavier string guage- the extra tension will pull on the neck slightly, resulting in higher action.



</answer>



<answer from>



redneckd...
Member since: 21 January 2007
Total points: 326 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



you can either 1) adjust your truss rod (not ideal), or 2) adjust your A and G string saddles on the bridge.  just raise them by a 1/4 turn of the allen key.  failing that make sure they are clearing the pickups.



replace the strings if they are old.



</answer>

<question>



What do the lyrics in this song mean:?



"How to Save a Life" by The Fray

<answer from>



jlowe308

<answer>



Twisted Sister? What kind of a man are you? I carried an M-16! And you carry that sick, repulsive, electric twanger. I never was really into Maiden, but I respect them for how talented they are. And they did contribute Eddie, which a lot of kids at my school would draw. They also stirred up controversy like some other bands by singing about the devil (aka Satan).

<answer>



It's Wyclef Jean



"Perfect Gentleman" is the fourth track released from Wyclef Jean's 2000 album The Ecleftic: 2 Sides II a Book. It is sometimes referred to as "The Stripper song."

<question>



How can you possibly enjoy "good music" of the Beatles or any other genuine classic rock?



All the songs I hear from the beatles are in such a shitty audio quality that I would rather listen to a mainstream song today that everybody says is tasteless, just for the sake of good audio quality. How can people still enjoy such sh*t recording quality in the 60s? (i'm talking about the studio recording, not the quality of the music itself)



</question>



<answer from>



Jackal
Member since: 13 July 2008
Total points: 2290 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well let me put in my input,You suck. Your not a real rock n roll fan if you can't handle any of the Beatles recordings.You have to go "Mainstream". Classic rock is a real rock n rollers music not some of this bull sh*t so called Mainstream,Alternative or Progressive rock.So in Closing i would like to say....Get a better choice in music numb nuts.If you can't handle the classic studio recordings then stop listening.



</answer>



<answer from>



stezzog
Member since: 15 June 2006
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I actually much prefer those old recordings that aren't hi-fi by today's standards, because you can hear the texture of each sound; I hate artificially slick recordings, where the sound-textures have all been varnished over- that fake gloss brings me to doubt the artistic quality of music it's applied to. If a song needs to be lubed up for people to want to listen to it, it must have been bloody awful in the first place!



</answer>



<answer from>



Michael.
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 1548 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Let me put it this way, my mother is a big Elvis Presley fan and she would always play Heartbreak Hotel (1956) on record player and it didn't have the best sound quality..but I loved it! She later on bought a cd with all of Elvis's songs remastered and all the instruments were louder and clearer, and it sounded terrible!!! It sounded way overproduced and lost that raw quality I love. Nothing beats the old authentic sound of real music.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ta Dah!
Member since: 17 December 2006
Total points: 11959 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



the quality of the music explains it all...



</answer>



<answer from>



threetwo...
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You sound pretty close minded there!



Alot of pop music today relies on programming and beats and alot of it sounds the same.  People like Timbaland try to be original and suceed, but most of it sounds manufactured.  Also, todays albums rely on one or two singles, with the rest of the tracks being strictly "filler".



Alot of the Beatles and other classic rock was more about a band, and was raw and energenic. Albums were more well rounded and you could enjoy the whole album, not just a single.



</answer>

<question from>



Sidh .
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I have nokia 5310, i am installing updates but there is some problem hereing a song not getting bass?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



There could be a problem with the headphones? Change your headset & see.



Or else, go to menu&gt;music player&gt;options&gt;settings&gt;equiliser
and then make whatever changes u need to inc the bass.



if it still  doesnt help, then re-install the cell software version. press *#0000# and see the version. if its 3, then you need to change it. mine is 5.81 version. Latest is 8 or something.



if none of ir works, take your cellphone to nokia care. they will help you free of cost..under the warrenty :)



I hope i helped. Xpress Music ROCKS! :D



Source(s):



I have the same cellphone since  a year



</answer>

Helena
